title: Body Composition and Musculoskeletal Health in Older Adults With Obesity and Sarcopenia (Liberty University Thesis)

sections.abstract:
This quantitative randomized controlled trial investigated the impact of resistance training on body 
fat in obese African American perimenopausal women in San Antonio, Texas. The study aimed to 
support the World Health Organization's efforts to combat obes ity and address the 
underrepresentation of African American women in research, a population with over half being 
overweight or obese. Eleven eligible participants completed an intake survey and had their body 
fat percentage measured using an InBody 270 before and after the intervention. Participants were 
divided into two groups: one utilizing weights (e.g., dumbbells, barbells, machines, resistance 
bands) and the other using body weight for resistance training. Both groups engaged in bi-weekly 
sessions with a personal trainer. Statistical analysis (Mann -Whitney U test and MANOVA) 
revealed no statistically significant difference between the two training
sections.methods:
in reducing body 
fat percentage. However, participants in both groups experienced noticeable reductions in body fat 
and overall mass. The findings suggest that while resistance training may contribute to body 
composition improvements, broader, culturally responsive intervention strategies are necessary to 
effectively reduce body fat in this population. Future research should explore culturally tailored 
lifestyle interventions, including nutrition education and physical activity promotion, to address 
obesity and health disparities effectively among obese African American perimenopausal women. 
Keywords: perimenopause, obesity, resistance training, African American women , body fat 
percentage. 

4 
 
 
 
Dedication 
This work is dedicated to the incredible people who have supported, encouraged, and 
inspired me throughout this journey. To my husband, Eric Butler, your love, patience, and 
unwavering belief in me have been my greatest source of strength. Your support has carried me 
through every challenge, and I am endlessly grateful for you. To my family, thank you for your 
unconditional love and encouragement. Your guidance has shaped me, and your support has 
given me the confidence to pursue my dreams. To my friends, your kindness, laughter, and 
motivation have been invaluable. Your presence has uplifted me, and I am so fortunate to have 
you in my life. To all the participants who contributed their time, effort, and insights, this project 
would not have been possible without you. Your willingness to share, collaborate, and engage 
has made a lasting impact, and I deeply appreciate your involvement. This dedication is a small 
token of my immense gratitude. Thank you for being part of this journey with me. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

5 
 
 
 
Acknowledgment 
First and foremost, I give all honor and glory to God, whose grace, wisdom, and 
unwavering presence have guided me through this journey. Without His strength and provision, 
this accomplishment would not have been possible. 
I extend my deepest gratitude to my committee chair, Dr. Orchid George, for her 
invaluable guidance, patience, and encouragement throughout this process. Her expertise and 
dedication have been instrumental in shaping this work, and I am truly grateful for her support. 
To my committee members, Dr. Mallory Ball and Dr. Shalah Watkins-Bailey, thank you for your 
insightful feedback, thoughtful critiques, and unwavering commitment to my success. Your 
contributions have enriched this study in ways I could not have imagined, and I deeply 
appreciate your time and effort. 
A special thank you to my dear friend, Olivia Jewell, whose help and encouragement 
with advertising this study made a significant impact. Your kindness, enthusiasm, and belief in 
my work have meant the world to me. 
Finally, to my loving husband, Eric Butler, thank you for your endless support, patience, 
and encouragement. Your unwavering belief in me, even in moments of doubt, has been my 
greatest source of strength. I am beyond grateful for your love and partnership throughout this 
journey. 
To all who have played a role in this achievement, whether through words of encouragement, 
prayers, or acts of kindness—thank you. This milestone is not mine alone, but a testament to the 
incredible support system that has surrounded me.

CHAPTER ONE: INTRODUCTION 
Overview 
The purpose of this randomized controlled trial study was to investigate how resistance 
training impacts body fat in obese African American perimenopausal women in San Antonio, 
Texas. In chapter one, background information about perimenopause was provided, along with 
an overview of the study's theoretical framework and a problem statement that examined the 
scope of recent literature on the topic. Following the purpose statement, the significance of the 
study was discussed. Lastly, the research questions are introduced, and the definitions of this 
study are provided. 
Background 
The importance of women's health has been increasingly acknowledged as a global health 
priority (Rees et al., 2022). African American women experience a higher prevalence of obesity 
and face an increased risk of weight management challenges (Hall, 2020). According to Sweeney 
et al. (2022), African American women are the least active demographic group in the United 
States. Only 37.4% meet the aerobic physical activity guidelines of ≥ 150 min/week of moderate 
physical activity or ≥ 75 min/week of vigorous physical activity, as compared to 55.1% of 
Caucasian women (Sweeney et al., 2022). 
The menopausal transition, also known as perimenopause, marks the first phase of 
menopause, during which a woman's body undergoes hormonal changes that gradually lead to 
the cessation of reproductive function (Geraghty, 2022; Ilankoon et al., 2021; Panay et al., 2020). 
Perimenopause refers to the period before menopause when women experience irregular 
menstrual cycles (Ilankoon et al., 2021). Perimenopause, also known as climacteric, denotes the 
transition that women experience due to hormonal changes, signaling the end of the reproductive 
phase (Johnson, 2020; Santoro, 2016). The definition of perimenopause remains unclear, 

17 
 
 
 
creating challenges in determining the timing of the transition, signified by menstrual 
irregularity, progressive depletion of ovarian follicles, and decreasing endogenous estradiol 
(Harper et al., 2022; Johnson, 2020; Khan et al., 2023; Santoro, 2016). According to Geraghty 
(2022), perimenopause is determined by vasomotor symptoms. Vasomotor symptoms stem from 
estrogen withdrawal, which perturbs the hypothalamic thermoregulatory neutral zone, a cluster 
of neurons responsible for regulating body temperature (Geraghty, 2022; Khan et al., 2023). 
According to Khan et al. (2023), vasomotor symptoms endure for a median duration of seven 
years and are linked to significant comorbidities, specifically involving cardiovascular disease, 
bone disease, and cognitive complaints. The most common vasomotor symptoms in 
perimenopausal women are irregular periods, hot flashes, weight gain, poor sleep, vaginal 
dryness, mood swings, brain fog, or bladder problems (Harper et al., 2022; Johnson, 2020). 
Diverse subcultures and racial/ethnic groups undergo the perimenopause transition differently 
within specific regions (Geraghty, 2022; Hall, 2020; Small & Fuller, 2021). Furthermore, a 
correlation has been observed between the severity of symptoms, lower educational attainment, 
and African-American ethnicity (Geraghty, 2022; Hall, 2020; Small & Fuller, 2021). 
During perimenopause, subcutaneous fat transfers from the gluteal or femoral region to 
the abdominal area (Karaflou & Goulis, 2024). In addition to the increase in abdominal fat, 
perimenopausal women experience a decrease in fat-free mass and bone mass (Karaflou & 
Goulis, 2024). This phenomenon of weight gain during perimenopause impacts approximately 
two million women in the United States every year, increasing the risk of cardiometabolic risk 
via insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular disease (Karaflou & Goulis, 2024; 
Khan et al., 2023). Individuals with obesity are at a higher risk of developing cardiovascular 
diseases, which can lead to increased mortality compared to non-obese individuals (Porada et al., 
2023). Porada et al. (2023) identified an increasing prevalence of obesity in women in the United 

18 
 
 
 
States with advancing age. Specifically, the prevalence rises from 39.7% among women aged 
20–39 years to 43.3% among women aged 40–59 years and individuals aged 60 years and above 
(Porada et al., 2023). However, Sun et al. (2019) found that perimenopausal women with a 
normal weight (BMI < 25.0) may suffer from central obesity and could be at increased risk of 
mortality due to excessive abdominal fat accumulation. Regrettably, prevailing public health 
directives for obesity prevention and management primarily emphasize the promotion of a 
normal body mass index (BMI) while often neglecting central obesity, which is denoted by 
elevated waist circumference and is prevalent in the general population (Sun et al., 2019). 
Obesity and BMI have a complex influence on the hormonal trajectory during 
perimenopause. Obesity is characterized by excessive fat accumulation and is typically assessed 
using the BMI, calculated from an individual's weight and height (Bray, 2023; Çakmur, 2020). In 
1998, World Health Organization (WHO) established standardized BMI classifications for 
overweight and obese adults, with the classifications being based on the risks of obesity-related 
diseases as observed in European adults (Liu et al., 2021). The national study on women’s health 
found a significant reduction in all menstrual hormones, including follicle-stimulating hormone 
(FSH), luteinizing hormone, estradiol, and urinary pregnanediol glucuronide during the transition 
into perimenopause ( Kim et al., 2020). The hormones interact in a complex feedback loop to 
regulate the female reproductive system (Santoro et al., 2020). The Penn Ovarian Aging Study 
found that in perimenopause, waist circumference and waist-to-hip ratio correlate with increased 
body size and decreases in all hormones (Freeman & Sammel, 2016). 
Obesity, once considered a condition, is now classified as a disease (Porada et al., 2023). 
This change in classification has led to a shift in obesity treatment in clinical practice guidelines 
(Porada et al., 2023). WHO has identified two primary factors contributing to the rising 
prevalence of obesity: increased consumption of energy-dense, high-fat, or sugar-sweetened 

19 
 
 
 
foods, and evolving lifestyles that promote more sedentary behavior (Garcia-Alexander & 
Poston, 2022). Geraghty (2022) reported that behavioral factors contributing to excess weight 
gain include binge eating and drinking, laziness, lack of willpower, insufficient sleep, a 
sedentary lifestyle, and self-indulgence. However, African Americans experience a notably 
elevated prevalence of obesity, particularly among school-age populations, attributable to 
existing disparities (Hall, 2020). 
Hormonal changes during perimenopause lead to an increase in anovulatory cycles and 
variable lengths between two ovarian cycles (Grandi et al., 2021). Szuscik-Niewiadomy et al. 
(2021) states that the regulation of hormone metabolism and menstrual regularity is influenced 
by physical exertion, which is governed by the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Hormonal 
changes result in reduced fertility but an increased risk of unintended pregnancies (Grandi et al., 
2022). Hormonal contraceptives and hormone therapy are widely used by millions of women 
worldwide (Grandi et al., 2021). In 2014, over nine million premenopausal women in the United 
States trusted and relied on the contraceptive pill for effective contraception (Grandi et al., 2021; 
Porada et al., 2023). Grandi et al. (2022) found that one of the side effects of using hormonal 
contraceptives and hormone therapy is weight gain. 
To treat obesity during perimenopause, several women have opted to use 
pharmacological therapy (Porada et al., 2023). The primary pharmacological treatments for 
obesity encompass lipase inhibitors, which impede fat absorption in the gastrointestinal tract, for 
example, orlistat, the combined use of naltrexone and bupropion, and glucagon-like peptide 1 
(GLP-1) analogues—liraglutide and semaglutide (Porada et al., 2023). A few examples of the 
brand names for the pharmacological treatments are Orlistat (Handing et al., 2022), Tripeptide 
(Frías et al., 2021), Saxenda, Topamax, Wellbutrin (Luzi, 2021), and Ozempic (Canadian 
Agency for Drugs and Technologies in Health, 2019). 

20 
 
 
 
Resistance training has been demonstrated to be a highly effective approach in addressing 
the physical and functional changes linked to aging and obesity as a key component of a well-
rounded exercise routine (Beavers et al., 2017; Marinho et al., 2023; Testa, 2021). Resistance 
training, also known as weight training or strength training, is a physical activity aimed at 
enhancing neuromuscular and musculoskeletal fitness as well as physical performance (Marinho 
et al., 2023). This resistance training involves targeted muscle or muscle group training through 
the application of external resistance that has been found to have the best benefits when 
combined with other exercises that will form or maintain endurance, balance, flexibility, and 
strength (Hedrick, 2020; Marinho et al., 2023). 
As women age and enter perimenopause, declining estrogen levels and reduced physical 
activity may lead to an accumulation of excess body fat, increasing the risk of developing obesity 
(Chapman-Lopez et al., 2024). This can trigger the release of certain cytokines and inflammatory 
markers, which in turn may impact the hormonal regulation of fat cell functions (Chapman-
Lopez et al., 2024). During the perimenopausal phase, women may experience a reduction in 
both overall body mass and muscle mass, the latter contributing to as much as 25% of the total 
body mass lost (Chapman-Lopez et al., 2024). Chapman-Lopez et al. (2024) recommended 
resistance training exercises to increase muscle protein synthesis, lean body mass, and strength, 
and to prevent muscle mass loss. 
Historical Overview 
The obesity epidemic has undeniably been a slow but steady process, marked by a 
significant surge that began in the 1980s and persists to the present day (Neeland et al., 2019; 
Temple, 2022). In 2008, evidence showed that 68% of perimenopausal women in the United 
States were overweight or obese (Lovejoy et al., 2008). A report revealed a positive correlation 
between the change in circulating follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels and the change in 

21 
 
 
 
fat mass over a 6-year follow-up period involving 543 middle-aged Caucasian and African-
American women (Lovejoy et al., 2008; Sowers et al., 2007). The report suggested that ovarian 
aging indeed contributes to body composition changes during mid-life (Lovejoy et al., 2008; 
Sowers et al., 2007). During the perimenopausal phase, weight loss and management serve as 
effective interventions for enhancing overall quality of life (Verma et al., 2024). Nevertheless, 
shedding excess weight can pose a challenge during this period (Verma et al., 2024). 
Perimenopausal women are more likely to seek lifestyle modification interventions to address 
and rectify their dietary and physical activity patterns, thereby maintaining a healthy weight 
status (Chopra et al., 2022). The most recent statistics available from the National Center for 
Health Statistics reported that in 2018, 43% of women between the ages of 40 and 59 were obese 
in the United States (Overweight & Obesity Statistics, 2021). 
Health Belief Model 
There have been investigations on whether the weight gain experienced during midlife 
results from aging or is due to hormonal changes associated with perimenopause (Elgzar et al., 
2023; Odunsi & Farris, 2023; Wu et al., 2020). The Health Belief Model (HBM) provides a 
theoretical framework that aids researchers in understanding and predicting individual changes in 
health behaviors (Wu et al., 2020). The HBM model delineated the critical determinants of 
health behaviors, encompassing an individual's perceived susceptibility to illness or disease, 
assessment of the severity of potential consequences, the perceived benefits of taking action, 
perceived barriers to action, cues that prompt action, and self-efficacy or confidence in the ability 
to succeed (Daddario, 2007; Odunsi & Farris, 2023; Rosenstock, 1974). According to Wu et al. 
(2020), the HBM was employed to examine the correlation between health beliefs and exercise 
in order to encourage Chinese residents to initiate and sustain exercise regimens. Time 
constraints emerged as a significant determinant of physical activity (Wu et al., 2020). Moreover, 

22 
 
 
 
the HBM was recommended as a viable framework for investigating the various factors 
influencing an individual's physical activity engagement (Wu et al., 2020). Elgzar et al. (2023) 
used the HBM as an effective tool to identify high-risk groups with low osteoporosis preventive 
behaviors and to develop need-based educational interventions. Elgzar et al. (2023) concluded 
that the constructs of HBM and osteoporosis-related knowledge can predict 38.6% of the 
variance in osteoporosis preventive behaviors. The recommendation of using HBM as a 
framework for osteoporosis public awareness programs may be an effective intervention to 
promote and change osteoporosis preventive behaviors (Elgzar et al., 2023). The researcher in 
this study applied the HBM to examine variations in self-efficacy across age, educational 
attainment, religion, and marital status. 
Theoretical Backgrounds Overview 
In addition to the Health Belief Model (HBM), there are four other theories that provided 
insight into the benefits of resistance training for obese perimenopausal African American 
women. These theories are: self-efficacy theory, the functional benefits of resistance training for 
older adults, life-history of religiousness theory, and the behavioral theory of marriage. Every 
theory function as a compass, offering clarity and deepening comprehension throughout the 
exploration of the impact of resistance training on obese perimenopausal African American 
women. The first theory is self-eﬃcacy theory, exercise self-efficacy refers to an individual's 
belief in the capability to successfully perform and sustain an exercise program, even when 
encountering obstacles, which determines confidence in maintaining consistent workouts (Xue-
liu & Mu, 2021). The concept of self-efficacy was initially introduced by psychologist Albert 
Bandura in 1977 (Bandura, 1977). While Bandura established the overarching concept of self-
efficacy, its relevance to exercise self-efficacy has been the focus of numerous studies within the 
field of health and fitness psychology (Bandura, 1977; Patterson et al., 2022; Xue-liu & Mu, 

23 
 
 
 
2021; Zhang et al., 2022). An example of high exercise self-efficacy is the belief that an 
individual can exercise regularly, even when tired, the weather is bad, or when traveling 
(Bandura, 1977; Xue-liu & Mu, 2021; Zhang et al., 2022). The individual has the confidence to 
overcome challenges and maintain the workout routine (Bandura, 1977; Xue-liu & Mu, 2021; 
Zhang et al., 2022). An example of low exercise self-efficacy is the doubt an individual has the 
ability to stick with an exercise (Bandura, 1977; Xue-liu & Mu, 2021; Zhang et al., 2022). 
Individuals with low exercise self-efficacy often become discouraged by obstacles and struggle 
to maintain confidence in the possibility of consistent physical activity (Bandura, 1977; Xue-liu 
& Mu, 2021; Zhang et al., 2022). The researcher in this study utilized the HBM to enhance 
exercise self-efficacy among participants. Research identified African American women as the 
demographic group with the lowest levels of physical activity in the United States, which results 
from positive body image perception, concerns about hair care, societal gender norms, fear of 
sexual stereotypes, and family responsibilities (Obi et al., 2023; Sweeney et al., 2022). 
The National Strength and Conditioning Association (NSCA) published a comprehensive 
position statement on the importance of resistance training for older adults, emphasizing the 
considerable functional benefits associated with resistance training (E. F. Cavalcante et al., 2023; 
Fragala et al., 2019). Aging often leads to a decline in muscle mass and strength, primarily 
caused by muscle disuse (E. F. Cavalcante et al., 2023; Fragala et al., 2019; McManus, 2024). 
Resistance training functions as a powerful intervention to counteract the effects, supporting the 
maintenance of muscle strength, mass, and overall functional ability (Fragala et al., 2019; 
Ribeiro et al., 2020; Said et al., 2021). Regular engagement in resistance training enhances 
balance, increases mobility, and reduces the risk of falls, significantly improving quality of life 
for older adults (E. F. Cavalcante et al., 2023; Fragala et al., 2019; Ribeiro et al., 2020). The 
NSCA emphasized the necessity of incorporating resistance training into daily routines to sustain 

24 
 
 
 
physical independence and overall health throughout later years (Cavalcante et al., 2023; Fragala 
et al., 2019). 
The life-history of religiousness theory suggested that individuals with strong religious 
convictions tend to participate in activities that enhance long-term health and happiness 
(Međedović, 2020, 2023). However, according to Koenig et al. (2024), religiosity may influence 
genetic factors that affect addiction risk, leading to substance use disorders that can harm 
physical health. There is evidence that higher levels of religiosity may positively affect 
cardiovascular, immune, and endocrine functions (Koenig et al., 2024). Individuals who are 
more religious tend to experience lower rates of heart disease, hypertension, cerebrovascular 
disease, dementia, infections, and some cancers (Koenig et al., 2024; Međedović, 2020). In fact, 
research indicates that unhealthy behaviors contribute to approximately 40% of premature 
mortality in the United States (Koenig et al., 2024; Saint Onge & Krueger, 2017). Brewer et al. 
(2020) found that a significant number of African American members of the Church of God in 
Christ (COGIC) reported experiencing chronic diseases, high rates of overweight or obesity, 
poor dietary habits, and low levels of physical activity. Interestingly, the members of the COGIC 
showed a discrepancy in self-perception: only 55% of participants considered themselves 
unhealthy and in need of making changes, even though 83% had a BMI indicating overweight, 
obesity, or morbid obesity (Brewer et al., 2021). Additionally, 40% of the participants had 
hypertension, and 19% had been diagnosed with diabetes (Brewer et al., 2021). The findings 
aligned with previous research, indicating that African Americans often accept higher body mass 
indices, which may help explain why many participants perceived themselves as being in good 
health (Brewer et al., 2021; Knapik et al., 2025; Manjunath et al., 2021). 
Research shows a link between marital status and overall health, as noted in the 
behavioral theory of marriage (Rosa et al., 2025). This theory proposes that throughout life, 

25 
 
 
 
patterns of behavior and interaction emerge within relationships, influencing emotional 
connections either by reinforcing bonds or generating tension over time (Rosa et al., 2025). In 
recent years, there has been a growing recognition of the deep connections between marital 
dynamics and individual health behaviors (Arvanitidou et al., 2025; Rosa et al., 2025). The 
marital relationship fosters a shared environment that can significantly impact the health-related 
choices and habits of both partners, which has a great influence on weight management 
(Arvanitidou et al., 2025; Rosa et al., 2025). The principles of behavioral theory in marriage 
provided valuable insights into the complex dynamics of spousal relationships and women's 
weight loss efforts (Gorin et al., 2020). The marital environment, shaped by the interactions 
between partners, can significantly influence a woman's motivation, adherence to healthy habits, 
and overall success in achieving and maintaining weight loss (Gorin et al., 2020). 
Society-at-Large Overview 
 The prevalence of obesity among women tends to increase during midlife, a phase that 
frequently coincides with the menopausal transition (Persons et al., 2024). As a result of the 
weight gain, women are at a higher risk of developing cardiometabolic disorders, including 
insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular disease (Karaflou & Goulis, 2024; Khan 
et al., 2023). Additionally, weight gain during perimenopause often leads to an increase in 
visceral fat, which is the fat stored around the abdominal organs (Opoku et al., 2023). This type 
of fat further heightens the risk of negative health outcomes (Opoku et al., 2023). African 
American women may experience the menopausal transition in ways that differ from other 
populations (Abou-Fadel et al., 2022; DeAngelis, 2023). Research indicated that the menopausal 
transition may occur at an earlier age among African American women, with more persistent and 
bothersome symptoms reported compared to Caucasian women (Abou-Fadel et al., 2022; 
DeAngelis, 2023). A higher likelihood of pre-existing health conditions, including obesity, 

26 
 
 
 
diabetes, and cardiovascular disease, has been observed before the onset of perimenopause 
(Abou-Fadel et al., 2022; Williams et al., 2022). The intersection of racial identity and the 
menopausal transition presents distinctive health challenges and experiences for African 
American women (Isenmann et al., 2023; Palla et al., 2020). This reality of racial identity and the 
menopausal transition highlights the urgent need for interventions that are not only culturally 
sensitive but also specifically customized to meet the unique needs of individuals (DeAngelis, 
2023). The health challenges faced by obese perimenopausal African American women in San 
Antonio are further amplified by socioeconomic determinants and existing health disparities 
within the region (Mejia & Blount, 2022). Structural racism plays a significant role in 
contributing to disparities by limiting access to vital resources such as healthy and affordable 
foods, safe environments for physical activity, and quality healthcare services (Lofton et al., 
2023). Data indicate higher rates of obesity and diabetes among African American and Hispanic 
adults in Texas compared to Caucasian adults (Mejia & Blount, 2022; Saenz & Casura, n.d.). 
Therefore, tailoring approaches remains crucial, allowing for a meaningful impact and fostering 
genuine connections with receiving support. 
Problem Statement 
 Research findings indicated that the BMI was observed to be notably higher in 
perimenopausal women in comparison to women who have not experienced the menopausal 
transition, even after controlling for variables such as age, dietary patterns, levels of physical 
activity, and smoking behaviors (Panay et al., 2020). The reduction in estrogen that women 
experience during perimenopause is directly associated with changes in lipid metabolism, 
inflammation, energy consumption, insulin resistance, and other factors that could influence the 
appendicular lean mass (Opoku et al., 2023; Park et al., 2020). A reduction in estrogen is 
concerning, cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the primary cause of death, and the risk 

27 
 
 
 
significantly increases after perimenopause (Ambikairajah et al., 2019; Panay et al., 2020). The 
accumulation of fat mass at midlife is influenced by several key factors, including aging, 
decreased physical activity levels, and sarcopenia, all of which can significantly impact the 
resting metabolic rate (Ambikairajah et al., 2019). Choudhry et al. (2024) indicated that the onset 
of perimenopause is linked to a significant alteration in the distribution of body fat. 
Consequently, women undergoing this transition are more likely to experience fat accumulation 
in the trunk and arms (Choudhry et al., 2024). Previous studies have provided evidence that 
resistance training exercises positively help perimenopausal women reduce the accumulation of 
fat mass (Ransdell et al., 2021; Tan et al., 2023). According to Tan et al. (2023), perimenopausal 
women derive the greatest benefit from engaging in resistance training three times weekly, with 
each session lasting 20 to 90 minutes for a minimum of six weeks. Randell et al. (2021) 
discovered that resistance training in perimenopausal women enhanced functional fitness and 
quality of life by mitigating the progressive decline in skeletal muscle mass and strength. 
In addition to the weight gain at the onset of perimenopause, another problem is African 
American women are underrepresented in research, which is a significant issue that affects 
healthcare, social sciences, and other fields (Abbasi, 2023; Chinn et al., 2021; Forsyth & 
Roberts, 2019; Ransdell et al., 2021). In 1994, the National Institutes of Health established a 
mandate to improve the representation of women and underrepresented racial and ethnic groups 
in research (Abbasi, 2023). Several factors contributed to this gap, such as historical mistrust, 
which results in African American women being hesitant to participate in research due to past 
unethical practices, such as the Tuskegee Syphilis Study and the unauthorized use of Henrietta 
Lack’s cells (R. A. Williams, 2020). Another significant concern is the insufficient 
representation of African American women in clinical trials. Many studies failed to incorporate 
African Americans in meaningful numbers, which can lead to a lack of relevant data and 

28 
 
 
 
undermine the generalizability of research findings (Abbasi, 2023). For example, in a recent 
Alzheimer’s drug trial, fewer than 1% of participants were African American women, despite the 
higher risk for the disease (Special Report: Mapping a Better Future for Dementia Care 
Navigation, 2023). A third factor that contributed to the underrepresentation of African 
American women was barriers to participation. African American women face logistical 
challenges such as financial constraints, lack of access to research institutions, and limited 
outreach efforts from researchers (Brown Speights et al., 2017). Additionally, some African 
American women felt that concerns are dismissed by healthcare providers, making African 
American women less likely to engage in studies (R. A. Williams, 2020). Researchers continued 
to emphasize that research with perimenopausal women and resistance training is sparse and 
inconsistent, which left a gap that needed to be addressed (Forsyth & Roberts, 2019; Ransdell et 
al., 2021). The problem is that the existing research literature not only lacks comprehensive 
guidance on the appropriate resistance training protocols that impact body fat percentage in 
obese African American perimenopausal women but also reflects a broader issue of 
underrepresentation of African American women in scientific studies, limiting the applicability 
and inclusivity of findings. 
Purpose Statement 
The purpose of this quantitative randomized controlled trial study is to investigate how 
resistance training impacts body fat in obese African American perimenopausal women in San 
Antonio, Texas. Singhania et al. (2020) reported that more than one-third of perimenopausal 
women were overweight or obese. Joint and muscular discomfort, hypertension, and the severity 
of somato-vegetative and urogenital complaints increased with obesity (Singhania et al., 2020). 
Singhania et al. (2020) found that aging may strongly influence the development of obesity due 
to decreased activity and a more sedentary lifestyle, leading to a reduction in energy expenditure 

29 
 
 
 
and contributing to the development of overweight/obesity. Resistance training can be used as a 
potential method to reduce body fat percentage, which can help elevate the conditions (Singhania 
et al., 2020; Thomas et al., 2021; Wong et al., 2020). 
To investigate how resistance training impacts body fat in obese perimenopausal African 
American women in San Antonio, this study compared a group of perimenopausal women who 
participated in resistance training exercises with women who participated in bodyweight training 
exercises. The independent variable in this study was the resistance training group, and the 
dependent variable was obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio. The 
resistance training group participated in exercises using external resistance from free weights, 
machine weights, or resistance bands. Haugen et al. (2023) found no differences in the 
effectiveness of free weight or machine-based weight training, while Lopes et al. (2019) 
discovered that resistance bands provide similar results to free weights and machine weights. 
Obese perimenopausal women located in San Antonio were selected for this study; according to 
the 2017 City of San Antonio Metropolitan Health District Strategic Plan, 71% of adults in San 
Antonio are overweight or obese (City of San Antonio Metropolitan Health Strategic Plan, 
2018). 
Significance of the Study 
The study was two-fold: 1) the study was aligned with WHO's acceleration plan to stop 
obesity, and 2) the study bridged the gap of the underrepresentation of African American women 
in research. Approximately 80% of African American women are classified as overweight or 
obese (Miller & Platenburg, 2021). Obesity is a significant public health concern that is rapidly 
increasing globally, with substantial implications for both health and the economy (Hojjat, 
2021). The increasing prevalence of obesity is of particular concern due to its well-established 
correlation with a variety of chronic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, heart attack, stroke, 

30 
 
 
 
kidney failure, decreased life expectancy, and sudden death (Faintuch & Faintuch, 2021; 
Hedrick, 2020). Obesity poses a wide range of health risks and is more prevalent among African 
Americans, contributing to an increased likelihood of developing type 2 diabetes African 
Americans = 13.0%, Caucasians = 8.0%, coronary heart disease African American women = 
5.2%, Caucasian women = 3.9%, asthma African Americans = 9.2%, Caucasians = 8.0%, and 
stroke African Americans = 4.0%, Caucasians = 2.7% (Chinn et al., 2021; Hall, 2020). The 
collective global expenditure associated with overweight- and obesity-related issues has been 
approximated at nearly $2 trillion (Knickman & Elbel, 2019). In addition to chronic illnesses, 
weight gain increases the severity of sleep disturbance and vasomotor symptoms such as hot 
flashes, night sweats, and sexual dysfunctions during perimenopause (Geraghty, 2022; Ozcan, 
2019). All of the complaints have a negative impact on the quality of life. Obesity also impairs 
work productivity, primarily caused by absenteeism, presenteeism, and reduced workforce 
participation (Menon et al., 2022). 
Obesity is also a global issue which have been increasing since the 1970s, with 
approximately 13% of the world's adult population being obese (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 
2022; Opoku et al., 2023). In 1997, the WHO declared obesity a global epidemic (Çakmur, 
2020). This declaration underscored the urgent need for action and widespread awareness about 
the gravity of this issue (Çakmur, 2020). By 2035, global overweight and obesity prevalence is 
projected to reach 51%, with the South Pacific Islands leading the obesity epidemic (Koliaki et 
al., 2023). By 2030, there is an expectation that 50% of the United States' adult population will 
be obese (Knickman & Elbel, 2019; Opoku et al., 2023). Obesity is more prevalent in women 
than in men, especially in the middle and older age groups (Knickman & Elbel, 2019; Opoku et 
al., 2023). Research has shown that the onset of perimenopause is associated with an increase in 
obesity and a decrease in lean body mass (Farahmand et al., 2021; Greendale et al., 2019; Opoku 

31 
 
 
 
et al., 2023). The relationships mentioned have been identified using different measurements 
such as BMI, waist-to-hip ratio, computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, and dual-
energy X-ray absorptiometry (Knickman & Elbel, 2019; Opoku et al., 2023). Obesity is a widely 
recognized risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD), T2D, and chronic kidney disease, which 
exacerbates with perimenopause (Çakmur, 2020; M. Evans et al., 2023; Opoku et al., 2023). 
During perimenopause, women experience a shift in the distribution of fat tissue, with more 
accumulation in the abdomen or visceral region, leading to an increased risk of CVD (Opoku et 
al., 2023). 
According to Abbasi (2023), women and ethnic minorities are underrepresented in 
research. Despite recent mandates from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to improve the 
representation of women and underrepresented racial/ethnic groups in biomedical research, 
African American women remains underrepresented (Chinn et al., 2021; M. Ma et al., 2021; 
Turner et al., 2022). As a result, interventions stemming from research may not fully address the 
unique needs of African American women (Chinn et al., 2021). Recently, the COVID-19 vaccine 
trials have brought attention to significant disparities. Despite African American individuals 
comprising 21% of COVID-19 deaths, the representation of African Americans in major vaccine 
trials was only 3% (Turner et al., 2022). The lack of diversity in clinical trials creates a racial and 
ethnic data gap, leading to skewed medical evidence and innovation favoring therapies with 
unexplored efficacy and safety for minority populations (Turner et al., 2022). 
Research Questions 
RQ1: How does resistance training with weights compare to resistance training with 
body weight impact body fat percentage in obese African American perimenopausal women in 
San Antonio? 

32 
 
 
 
 RQ2: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to age? 
RQ3: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to education attainment? 
 RQ4: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to religion? 
RQ5: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to marital status? 
Definitions 
1. Adipose tissue- Commonly known as fat tissue, a type of connective tissue that stores 
energy in the form of lipids (Forsyth & Roberts, 2019). 
2. Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis (BIA)-A method for estimating body composition, 
particularly body fat and muscle mass that uses a low-level electrical current through the 
body (Gibson et al., 2019). 
3. Body Composition- The percentage of fat, bone, muscle, organs, and water that make up 
an individual’s total body mass (Abdulnour et al., 2012). 
4. Body Mass Index (BMI)- A value derived from the mass or weight and height of a person. 
The BMI is defined as the body mass divided by the square of the body height, and is 
expressed in units of kg/m² (M. Evans et al., 2023). 
5. Cardiovascular Disease (CVD)- A group of disorders affecting the heart and blood 
vessels (Panay et al., 2020). 
6. Central Adiposity- Abdominal obesity or truncal obesity, refers to the accumulation of fat 
in the lower torso, particularly around the abdominal area (Forsyth & Roberts, 2019). 

33 
 
 
 
7. Estrogen- An ovarian hormone that maintains sexual and reproductive health (Forsyth & 
Roberts, 2019). 
8. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)-A hormone in women that helps mature the ovarian 
follicles that release eggs (C. Kim et al., 2020). 
9. Health Belief Model (HBM)- A social psychological health behavior change model 
developed to explain and predict health-related behaviors, particularly in regard to the 
uptake of health services (Wu et al., 2020). 
10. Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT)- Medication that contains female hormones and is 
used to replace the estrogen that the body stops making during menopause (Singhania et 
al., 2020). 
11. Lean Body Mass- The total weight of the human body minus the weight of all the fat 
(Fragala et al., 2019). 
12. Muscle Mass- The total weight of all the muscles in one’s body (Fragala et al., 2019). 
13. Obesity- An individual with body mass index (BMI) ≥30kg/m2 (M. Evans et al., 2023). 
14. Perimenopause- The period from the onset of menstrual irregularities to the end of the 
first year after the final menstrual cycle (Geraghty, 2022). 
15. Resistance Training- A form of exercise intended to increase muscular strength and 
endurance and involves working specific muscle groups using some form of resistance, 
which could be weights, bands, or even your own body weight working against gravity 
(Fragala et al., 2019). 
16. Subcutaneous Fat- Fat is found underneath the dermis, the outermost layer of skin and 
above the muscle layer (Abdulnour et al., 2012). 
17. Type II Diabetes (T2D)- A form of diabetes mellitus characterized by high blood sugar 
levels, insulin resistance, and relative lack of insulin (Faintuch & Faintuch, 2021). 

34 
 
 
 
18. Vasomotor Symptoms- Commonly known as hot flashes and night sweats, are 
characterized by women as an intense and overpowering sensation of heat that ascends 
through the upper body and face. This sensation typically endures for 1-5 minutes and is 
succeeded by a sense of cold and shivering (Patel & S. Dhillo, 2022). 
19. Visceral Fat- Fat that surrounds the organs in the abdomen and is located deep inside 
(Abdulnour et al., 2012). 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

35 
 
 
 
CHAPTER TWO: LITERATURE REVIEW 
Overview 
This literature review aimed to establish the framework and significance of resistance 
training's impact on perimenopausal women in the United States, San Antonio area. Chapter two 
encompassed a section on the theoretical or conceptual framework, focusing on the health belief 
model (HBM), which offered insight into the conditions under which individuals may adopt 
health behaviors, such as undergoing preventive screenings or seeking treatment for a health 
condition (Luger, 2020). Following this, the chapter explored related literature, providing 
information from existing sources on resistance training and the effects on obese perimenopausal 
women. Finally, a summary was presented. 
Conceptual or Theoretical Framework 
This study utilized the health belief model (HBM) to examine the correlation between 
health beliefs and resistance training in obese African American perimenopausal women. The 
HBM, which was developed by social psychologists Irwin M. Rosenstock, Godfrey M. 
Hochbaum, S. Stephen Kegeles, and Howard Leventhal, has been extensively utilized in health-
related behavior research since the early 1950s (Rosenstock, 1974). The HBM is unequivocally 
considered one of the most widely applied conceptual frameworks of health behavior by health 
educators, other health professionals, and psychologists (The Wiley Encyclopedia of Health 
Psychology, 2021). The model aimed to provide an understanding of the conditions under which 
an individual may engage in health behaviors such as preventive screenings or seeking treatment 
for a health condition (Luger, 2020). The health belief model was originally based on four 
cognitive constructs (Rosenstock, 1974): 
• Perceived Susceptibility: People will not change health behaviors unless people 
believe that risk is elevated. 

36 
 
 
 
• Perceived Seriousness: The level of emotional arousal provoked by the idea of a 
disease and the perceived challenges. 
• Perceived Benefits of Taking Action: Accepting one's susceptibility to a serious 
disease was thought to provide a force leading to action, but this does not define 
the particular course of action that was likely to be taken. 
• Barriers to Taking Action: The direction of the action is influenced by beliefs 
about the effectiveness of available alternatives in reducing the disease threat that 
an individual feels subjected to. 
Later, this model was refined in 1974 by Marshall Becker by adding two constructs: 
• Cue to action: This pertains to the stimulus required to initiate the decision-
making process to accept a recommended health action. The cues can manifest as 
internal or external. 
• Self-efficacy: This refers to an individual's confidence in the ability to perform a 
behavior successfully (Janz & Becker, 1984). 
Individuals' health-related beliefs and behaviors significantly impact their well-being 
(Çiftci & Kadıoğlu, 2023; Daddario, 2007). Health belief refers to people's thoughts and actions 
regarding health and illness (Çiftci & Kadıoğlu, 2023; Daddario, 2007; Elgzar et al., 2023). The 
HBM has effectively been used to assist with weight management, identifying and analyzing the 
psychological and cognitive factors that influence health preventive maintenance, and increasing 
physical activities (Çiftci & Kadıoğlu, 2023; Daddario, 2007). 
According to Daddario (2007), the primary motivation for change is the perceived threat 
or risk of a specific condition, and the HBM can be used to assist with weight management 
interventions. When using the HBM as a weight management intervention, the goal was to 

37 
 
 
 
understand how individuals’ health beliefs influence their motivation, decision-making, and 
adherence to weight-related behavior change. The HBM core application in weight management 
was captured as perceived susceptibility: individuals who believed they were at risk for obesity 
or obesity-related conditions (e.g., diabetes, cardiovascular disease) were more likely to engage 
in preventive behaviors. The individuals were asked, “What health risks do you think your 
weight poses for you?” Next, perceived severity: awareness of the serious consequences of 
obesity, such as chronic illness, reduced quality of life, and premature death, served as a strong 
motivator for change. The individuals were asked, “What do you think will happen if you don’t 
lose weight?” Thirdly, perceived benefits were seen as recognizing the advantages of weight loss, 
including improved health, physical appearance, and psychological well-being, which 
encouraged individuals to adopt healthier behaviors. The individuals were asked, “How do you 
think you will benefit by losing the weight?” Next were perceived barriers, common obstacles 
which included time constraints, lack of access to resources, emotional eating, and social 
influences. The question that was asked was “What prevents you from losing weight?” The 
construct cues to action were driven by external triggers such as media coverage, physician 
advice, or witnessing a loved one’s health decline, which prompted individuals to initiate weight 
management efforts. The individuals were asked, “What will motivate you to lose weight?” Self-
efficacy is key to making changes. When people believe they can improve their lifestyle, it helps 
to adopt healthier eating habits and increase physical activity. This confidence is an important 
part of managing weight effectively (Daddario, 2007). 
The HBM proved highly effective in studies of perimenopausal women, identifying and 
analyzing the psychological and cognitive factors that influence preventive health maintenance. 
Elgzar et al. (2023) used the HBM to identify high-risk groups that exhibited low levels of 
osteoporosis preventive behaviors. The researcher aimed to develop targeted educational 

38 
 
 
 
interventions tailored to the specific needs of the individuals (Elgzar et al., 2023). This study 
provided evidence that HBM constructs significantly improve osteoporosis preventive behaviors 
in perimenopausal women (Elgzar et al., 2023). Therefore, developing HBM-based educational 
interventions that specifically address perceived susceptibility, severity, benefits, and health 
motivation would enhance osteoporosis preventive behaviors (Elgzar et al., 2023). In a study 
conducted by Lau et al. (2024), the HBM was used to explore the menopausal knowledge, 
perceived severity of menopausal symptoms, perceived susceptibility to menopausal distress, 
perceived benefits of help-seeking, perceived barriers against help-seeking (related to both 
COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 factors), self-efficacy, and motivation to seek help among 
perimenopausal women. 
Studies that have used the HBM to assess physical activities have concluded with the 
following constructs: perceived susceptibility: people are more likely to engage in physical 
activity as a preventive measure due to the belief that inactivity is associated with a higher risk of 
diseases like obesity and diabetes (Çiftci & Kadıoğlu, 2023; Ekúndayò et al., 2020; Hosseini et 
al., 2017). Next, perceived severity is directly linked to understanding the consequences of 
inactivity, which can span from illness to death (Narmkul et al., 2024). Recognizing the gravity 
of the consequences, drives lifestyle changes and active participation, in physical activities 
(Narmkul et al., 2024). The third construct, perceived benefit, recognized the positive outcomes 
of exercise, encompassing physical, psychological, and social well-being (Hosseini et al., 2017). 
This understanding fosters a positive mindset and drives behavioral change (Hosseini et al., 
2017). The fourth construct is perceived barriers: recognizing and addressing factors or obstacles 
that can prevent individuals from engaging in physical activity, which is essential to overcome 
(Ma et al., 2023). The fifth construct is cues to action: prompts or reminders that strongly 
encouraged individuals to engage in physical activity. Family members' expectations are a 

39 
 
 
 
crucial cue that can significantly motivate individuals to initiate and maintain regular exercise 
routines (Shafieian & Kazemi, 2017). Lastly, self-efficacy pertains to an individual's belief in the 
capacity to execute physical activities proficiently, even in challenging circumstances (Shafieian 
& Kazemi, 2017). Elevated self-efficacy fosterd heightened confidence and an increased 
inclination to partake in physical activity (Hosseini et al., 2017). 
Studies have been conducted using the Health Belief Model (HBM) with African 
American women to help identify barriers to engaging in physical activities (Onyegbule et al., 
2021; Sillice et al., 2024). The prevailing estimates indicate that approximately 80% of African 
American women are classified as overweight or obese, rendering this demographic the cohort 
with the highest obesity prevalence in the United States (Miller & Platenburg, 2021). Onyegbule 
et al. (2021) found that perceived severity/susceptibility was found in the perceptions the 
participants had of family members. Quotes from the participants are “I could end up like my 
mama,” “It runs in my family,” “I could lose my legs to diabetes or end up with dialysis” 
(Onyegbule et al., 2021). Next, Onyegbule et al. (2021) identified benefits African American 
women expressed about working out such as being a role model, living longer life, and 
appearance. Researchers found the biggest barriers for African American women of physical 
activities are hair cost, hair maintenance, lack of child care, and gym membership cost 
(Onyegbule et al., 2021; Sillice et al., 2024). The cues to action that have been identified are 
appearance and family members' health conditions (Onyegbule et al., 2021). Researchers have 
found no statistically significant relationships between perceived self-efficacy and exercise 
(Onyegbule et al., 2021; Sillice et al., 2024). According to Onyegbule et al. (2021), participants 
stated “I really need help nothing works for me,” “I got the treadmill, but have not lost 
anything,” as well as “I have tried so hard.” 

40 
 
 
 
The proposed study used the HBM to help the participants recognize the importance of 
resistance training during perimenopause. The five of the six constructs the researcher used in 
this study were as follows: Perceived Susceptibility: the participants’ feelings about participating 
in resistance training. Perceived Severity: understanding why the participants may feel resistance 
training is unnecessary in perimenopause. Perceived Benefits: understanding participants’ views 
of resistance training benefits. Perceived Barriers: understanding what physical and mental 
obstacles keep the participants from engaging in resistance training. Self-Efficacy: increase 
confidence by encouraging the participants to engage in resistance training exercises beyond this 
study. The researcher also utilized HBM to assess differences in self-efficacy based on age, 
educational attainment, religion, and marital status. 
Related Literature 
Obesity 
According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), 1 out of 5 
adult Americans are obese, with a BMI equal to or greater than 30 kg/m2 (Obesity, 2024). WHO 
defines obesity as abnormal or excessive fat accumulation in adipose tissue, which may impair 
health (Rani & Kohli, 2024). The American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists and 
American College of Endocrinology has classified obesity as an adiposity-based chronic disease 
(Luzi, 2021). Obesity is unequivocally recognized as a disease according to the International 
Classification of Disease 10th revision code E66 and is considered a lifestyle non-communicable 
disease (Rani & Kohli, 2024). Overweight is undeniably becoming the new normal (Nestle, 
2022). 
History of Obesity 
 

41 
 
 
 
Globally, the prevalence of obesity is reaching pandemic proportions, and the rates are 
consistently escalating in developed and developing countries (Opoku et al., 2023; Small & 
Fuller, 2021). Based on the CDC guidelines, around the early 1960s, roughly 13% of the 
population was considered obese (Temple, 2022). The obesity epidemic has been a gradual 
process, with a significant increase starting in the 1980s and continuing to the present day 
(Neeland et al., 2019; Temple, 2022). Although there is a challenge to pinpoint an exact year, the 
1980s marked a notable shift in obesity rates (Temple, 2022). In 1997, the WHO declared obesity 
a global epidemic (Çakmur, 2020). Over the last 60 years, the United States obesity rates have 
tripled, and severe obesity, also known as morbid obesity, has risen tenfold (Evans et al., 2023; 
Okunogbe et al., 2021; Singhania et al., 2020; Temple, 2022). In 2020, the United States 
Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Minority Health reported that 
approximately 80% of African American women are classified as overweight or obese (Miller & 
Platenburg, 2021). As a result, African American women are considered as the demographic with 
the highest prevalence of obesity or overweight conditions when compared to other ethnic 
groups within the United States (Miller & Platenburg, 2021). 
Health Risk of Obesity 
BMI is a widely used metric that estimates weight appropriateness relative to height and 
serves as a standard screening tool for potential health risks associated with excess body fat 
(Bray, 2023; Çakmur, 2020). Body mass index (BMI) is a widely used indicator of obesity and is 
classified as according to (kg/m2): underweight, <18.5; normal weight, 18.5–24.9; overweight, 
25-29.9; class 1 obesity 30-34.9, class 2 obesity 35-39.9, and class 3 obesity > 40 as indicated on 
Table 5 (Çakmur, 2020; Luzi, 2021). The concept of BMI originated in 1832, when Adolphe 
Quetelet, a Belgian statistician, mathematician, and astronomer, sought to define quantifiable 

42 
 
 
 
attributes of the normal man based on his interest in statistical analysis and bell-shaped curves 
(Pray & Riskin, 2023). In 1972, physiologist Ancel Keys expanded upon the work of Adolphe 
Quetelet, who developed the Quetelet Index (Pray & Riskin, 2023). Keys officially introduced 
the term body mass index (BMI) and provided supporting evidence for its current application 
through a study that analyzed 12 samples consisting of 7,426 healthy men (Pray & Riskin, 2023). 
While BMI offers a convenient measure, it does not fully account for variations in body 
composition influenced by muscle mass, age, gender, and ethnicity (Çakmur, 2020; Luzi, 2021; 
Neeland et al., 2019; Pray & Riskin, 2023; Ross et al., 2020). Researchers have found that BMI 
is not a sufficient indicator of overall body composition (Neeland et al., 2019; Ross et al., 2020). 
This limitation arises from the insufficient consideration of central abdominal fat mass and the 
significant variances in intra-abdominal (visceral) fat distribution observed among individuals 
(Fahed et al., 2022; Neeland et al., 2019). Visceral adipose tissue (V AT), also known as intra-
abdominal fat, is a type of fat that accumulates deep within the abdominal cavity, which 
surrounds vital organs such as the liver, pancreas, and intestines (Luzi, 2021). Epidemiological 
studies indicate that V AT is a significant independent predictor of morbidity and mortality, while 
the accumulation of abdominal subcutaneous adipose tissue is a much less reliable indicator of 
cardiovascular risk (Luzi, 2021; Neeland et al., 2019). Unlike subcutaneous fat, which is found 
just beneath the skin and can be pinched, visceral fat is not visible and cannot be measured by 
simply pinching the skin (Neeland et al., 2019). 
Body mass index (BMI) is limited in diagnosing obesity in individuals and is considered 
a rough guide by WHO (Carey, 2019). African American women, despite being more insulin 
resistant compared to Caucasian women, have less V A T and hepatic steatosis and more 
subcutaneous adipose tissue (Bays et al., 2022). Additionally, African American women have 

43 
 
 
 
larger subcutaneous adipocyte size, which is linked to reduced adipogenic capacity and higher 
expression of inflammatory genes compared to Caucasian women (Bays et al., 2022). According 
to Liu et al. (2021), BMI classifications are determined based on the risks of obesity-related 
diseases in European adults; obesity-related comorbidities differ based on sex and race or 
ethnicity. Visceral fat accumulation has been shown to lead to many chronic diseases (Çakmur, 
2020). According to Çakmur (2020), obesity can affect the cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, 
genitourinary, metabolic/endocrine, musculoskeletal/orthopedic, neurological and central 
nervous systems, obstetric and perinatal, skin, psychological, respiratory/pulmonary, and 
reproductive systems. The aim of obesity treatment should focus not only on weight loss but also 
specifically on reducing visceral fat (Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). The complex link between obesity 
and conditions such as type II diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and hypertension undeniably 
contributes to a heightened prevalence of MetS (Olalekan et al., 2024; Palla et al., 2020; Rani & 
Kohli, 2024). One of the most pressing concerns is the strong association between obesity and 
metabolic syndrome (MetS), as well as chronic diseases (Rani & Kohli, 2024; Rippe & Foreyt, 
2022). 
Metabolic syndrome (MetS) encompasses a cluster of at least three of the five medical 
conditions: abdominal obesity, high blood pressure, elevated blood glucose levels, increased 
serum triglycerides, and reduced serum high-density lipoprotein levels (Olalekan et al., 2024; 
Palla et al., 2020; Rani & Kohli, 2024). According to Rani & Kohli (2024), MetS is 
overwhelmingly attributed to an underlying disorder of energy utilization and storage. According 
to the research conducted by Olalekan et al. (2024), the global prevalence of MetS is on the rise, 
demonstrating significant regional variations. Factors such as geographical location, diagnostic 
criteria, age, gender, and accompanying health conditions contribute to this variability (Olalekan 
et al., 2024). For instance, the prevalence of MetS in Africa is reported to be 32.4%, while in the 

44 
 
 
 
United States, there is a concerning upward trend, particularly among individuals with lower 
educational attainment (Olalekan et al., 2024). Researchers asserted that a diagnosis of MetS 
requires tailored treatment and significantly elevated the risk of cardiovascular disease beyond 
the sum of the individual components (Neeland et al., 2019; Rani & Kohli, 2024). The global 
burden of disease study estimated that diseases related to overweight or obesity result in 
approximately four million deaths per year (Menon et al., 2022; Shekar & Popkin, 2020). 
Economic Impact of Obesity 
 Individuals with obesity use more healthcare resources than those with a normal BMI, 
resulting in significant additional healthcare costs (Ramasamy et al., 2019). Reports from 2016 
indicate that obesity and overweight conditions, along with their associated chronic diseases, 
were estimated to cost more than $480 billion in direct healthcare expenses and $1.24 trillion in 
lost productivity in the United States (Ramasamy et al., 2019). Medical treatment for chronic 
diseases inevitably results in higher health expenditures (Hojjat, 2021). According to Shekar & 
Popkin (2020), estimating the economic cost of obesity is challenging due to researchers using 
different methodologies and definitions of direct and indirect costs. 
Direct costs of obesity refer to the financial expenses directly related to the prevention, 
diagnosis, and treatment of obesity and its associated health conditions (M. Evans et al., 2023; 
Ramasamy et al., 2019; Woods & Miljkovic, 2022). Studies conducted in the U.S. revealed that 
the direct medical costs for individuals with obesity are more than six times higher than for those 
who are overweight (Cawley et al., 2021). These costs are typically borne by individuals, 
healthcare systems, employers, and governments (M. Evans et al., 2023). Outpatient direct costs 
include outpatient physician visits, outpatient surgical visits, laboratory and pathology services, 
radiology, and other ancillary services (M. Evans et al., 2023; Knickman & Elbel, 2019). 

45 
 
 
 
Individuals with obesity have higher rates of hospital admissions and longer stays, which drives 
up costs (M. Evans et al., 2023; Knickman & Elbel, 2019). The cost of prescription drugs is a 
major component of direct costs. This includes medications for treating obesity, such as GLP-1 
agonists, and the medication used to treat co-morbidities like type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and 
high cholesterol (Morton et al., 2019; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Next, surgical procedures such as 
bariatric surgeries are a direct cost of treating severe obesity (Bhasker et al., 2021; Morton et al., 
2019). These procedures involve significant expenses for pre-operative evaluations, the surgery 
itself, hospital stays, and post-operative care (Bhasker et al., 2021; Morton et al., 2019). 
Preventive services is also considered direct costs for weight management programs, nutritional 
counseling, and physical activity interventions (Woods & Miljkovic, 2022) 
Indirect costs associated with obesity represent substantial financial burdens that extend 
beyond direct medical treatment and significantly affect the U.S. economy (Cawley et al., 2021; 
M. Evans et al., 2023; Woods & Miljkovic, 2022). These costs are largely driven by reduced 
workforce productivity, increased disability rates, and premature mortality (Cawley et al., 2021; 
M. Evans et al., 2023; Woods & Miljkovic, 2022). Evans et al. (2023) found that productivity 
losses alone often surpass direct healthcare expenditures. Specific components of indirect costs 
include disability-related expenses, workers’ compensation claims, absenteeism, and 
presenteeism (Ramasamy et al., 2019). Productivity losses due to obesity are particularly 
pronounced, with absenteeism and presenteeism costing over $1 billion annually in the U.S. 
workforce (Divino et al., 2021). Additionally, premature mortality linked to obesity-related 
conditions contributes hundreds of billions of dollars in lost economic output (Ramasamy et al., 
2019). These indirect costs impact stakeholders, government agencies, and society at large 
through both public and private spending on obesity-related challenges (Wulandari & Kristina, 
2018). 

46 
 
 
 
Productivity Loss of Obesity 
 
The obesity epidemic has led to a significant economic burden, with high healthcare costs 
and reduced worker productivity as major challenges (Shekar & Popkin, 2020). Reduced work 
productivity is significantly influenced by absenteeism, presenteeism, and premature mortality 
(Menon et al., 2022; Ramasamy et al., 2019; Shekar & Popkin, 2020). Obesity contributes to 
disability and leads to earlier retirement, which impacts productivity (Knickman & Elbel, 2019; 
Shekar & Popkin, 2020). Estimates of the economic costs of obesity vary significantly due to 
researchers using different methodologies and definitions of economic costs (Knickman & Elbel, 
2019; Shekar & Popkin, 2020). Individuals with a BMI of at least 35.0 kg/m² reported a health-
related productivity loss of nearly 5.0% and required additional time to complete physically 
demanding tasks (Kudel et al., 2018). According to MacEwan et al. (2024), individuals with a 
high body mass index (BMI) may experience challenges in the workplace. According to Menon 
et al. (2022), research indisputably demonstrates that individuals with obesity are significantly 
less likely to be employed compared to normal-weight counterparts. Understanding and 
quantifying the future economic impact of obesity on productivity is crucial, as work 
productivity drives the economy through income earnings, tax revenue, and gross domestic 
product (Knickman & Elbel, 2019; Menon et al., 2022). 
Absenteeism is defined as time away from work due to overweight and obesity, likely 
due to its ease of measurement, making it the most common measure of indirect cost (Goettler et 
al., 2017). Hojjat (2021) found that the annual cost breakdown is as follows: 18% for sick days, 
41% for reduced productivity due to health issues, and 41% for general medical expenses. 
Studies indicate that employees with obesity experience a higher rate of absenteeism, missing 
more workdays annually compared to their colleagues with a healthy weight (Goettler et al., 
2017; Ramasamy et al., 2019) Disability insurance premiums and labor market productivity are 

47 
 
 
 
significantly affected by the indirect costs of obesity (Hojjat, 2021; Knickman & Elbel, 2019). 
According to Goettler et al. (2017), a cost analysis revealed that employers incur an average 
productivity loss ranging from $108 to $1,857 per obese employee due to absenteeism. The costs 
encompassed future income lost from premature death, as well as income lost from decreased 
productivity, restricted activity, and work absence (Hojjat, 2021; Knickman & Elbel, 2019). The 
impact of obesity-related loss of employee productivity equals the significance of the medical 
expenses associated with such conditions (Hojjat, 2021). 
Woods and Miljkovic (2022) state that presenteeism causes up to three times more health-
related lost productivity than absenteeism and premature mortality. Presenteeism is defined as 
the loss of productivity that occurs when employees are physically present at work but are not 
performing at their full capacity (Goettler et al., 2017; Ramasamy et al., 2019; Woods & 
Miljkovic, 2022). The costs associated with presenteeism among individuals with obesity ranged 
from $1,146 to $4,175 (Goettler et al., 2017). Obesity and its related health issues, such as 
fatigue, pain, and sleep apnea, can impair concentration, energy levels, and cognitive function 
(Goettler et al., 2017; Ramasamy et al., 2019; Woods & Miljkovic, 2022). This leads to a slower 
work pace, errors, and a reduced ability to perform physically demanding tasks (Goettler et al., 
2017; Ramasamy et al., 2019; Woods & Miljkovic, 2022). 
The most severe form of productivity loss, representing a permanent loss of a worker's 
future contributions, is premature mortality (Goettler et al., 2017; Woods & Miljkovic, 2022). 
Premature mortality refers to the death that occurs before an individual reaches the average life 
expectancy (Hu et al., 2024). When obesity-related complications lead to an early death, it 
removes a skilled and experienced individual from the workforce (Goettler et al., 2017; Woods & 
Miljkovic, 2022). Early death due to obesity-related conditions leads to lost years of productive 
life, which translates into significant economic losses for both employers and society (Rippe & 

48 
 
 
 
Foreyt, 2022; Woods & Miljkovic, 2022). Premature mortality is a widely recognized indicator 
of population health globally and serves as a valuable metric for evaluating the avoidable or 
unnecessary burden of death (Hu et al., 2024). This is especially critical in workforce populations 
where obesity prevalence is high (Goettler et al., 2017; Ramasamy et al., 2019; Woods & 
Miljkovic, 2022). Estimates of obesity’s impact on morbidity include productivity loss from 
disability and premature mortality in the United States, with the total morbidity cost estimated at 
$177.9 billion (Woods & Miljkovic, 2022). A focus on reducing the incidence of obesity has 
been identified as a crucial strategy for preventing premature mortality (Hu et al., 2024) 
Global Impact of Obesity 
Obesity poses a steadily increasing public health challenge on a global scale, with 
significant health and economic implications (Hojjat, 2021). However, Okunogbe et al. (2021) 
found that the economic impact was substantial across countries in 2019 ranging from Australia 
$23.68 billion, Brazil $38.76B, India $23.24B, Mexico $26.04B, Saudi Arabia $19.16B, South 
Africa $5.54B, Spain $29.06B, and Thailand $6.89B. Shekar & Popkin (2020) reported that the 
United States estimated cost of obesity is $147 billion. The anticipated increase in obesity costs 
across countries can be attributed to the rising prevalence of obesity, changes in population 
demographics, and economic growth (Okunogbe et al., 2021). By 2050, the expected cost of 
obesity in Australia is $70.77 billion, Brazil $121.90B, India $217.45B, Mexico, $99.48B, Saudi 
Arabia $45.82B, South Africa $18.33B, Spain $47.03B, Thailand $45.28B, and United States 
$212B (Okunogbe et al., 2021; Shekar & Popkin, 2020). The factors that may contribute to 
differences in total costs between countries are income levels, wage variations, employment 
rates, national healthcare spending, and the age distribution of obesity associated with mortality 
(Okunogbe et al., 2021). Shekar and Popkin (2020) pointed out that there are two theories 

49 
 
 
 
regarding the economic causes of overweight and obesity: 1) a major shift in technology which 
leads to reduced activity, and 2) the relative price of healthy food, unfortunately, lower-priced 
foods tend to be ultra-processed foods, refined starchy, and a high-calorie. 
During 2017–2018, reports show that North America has long had the highest levels of 
overweight and obesity (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022; Knickman & Elbel, 2019). Several 
factors contribute to the rise in levels, including sedentary lifestyles, the prevalence of unhealthy, 
energy-dense foods high in fat and sugar, and the complexity of the global food supply chain 
(Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022). The prevalence of obesity varies significantly across the 
globe, highlighting the urgent need for concerted global action to address this issue (Chooi et al., 
2019). In 1975, less than 1% of Chinese adults were considered obese (Garcia-Alexander & 
Poston, 2022). However, by 2016, the figures had climbed to 12% among females and 21% 
among males (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022). This led to a substantial shift in global 
rankings, with females moving from 144th to 60th place and males from 131st to 16th (Garcia-
Alexander & Poston, 2022). Within Brazil, the prevalence of obesity has shown a concerning 
increase over the years. Notably, in 1975, the rates of obesity were 8% in females and 3% in 
males (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022). However, by 2016, the figures surged to 26% in 
females and 19% in males (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022). This trend is not limited to 
adults, as there has also been a worrying upsurge in obesity among children and adolescents in 
Brazil. In 1975, only 1.4% of girls and 1.3% of boys aged five were obese (Garcia-Alexander & 
Poston, 2022). By 2016, the proportions had risen to 12% of girls and 16% of boys (Garcia-
Alexander & Poston, 2022). According to Garcia-Alexander and Poston (2022), Brazil's youth 
now ranks 47th in the world for obesity prevalence. The escalating rates of obesity in Brazil 
raises significant concerns about the long-term health implications for a large portion of the 
population (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022). 

50 
 
 
 
Garcia-Alexander and Poston (2022) found that obesity rates in Iran are indicative of the 
Middle East as a whole, which has some of the highest obesity levels in the world. In 1975, the 
obesity rate for adult females was 11% and for men three percent (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 
2022). By 2016, the prevalence had significantly increased, with adult female obesity at 34% and 
male obesity at 20 percent (Abiri et al., 2023; Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022). The rise in 
obesity in Iran was faster than in the rest of the world (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022). 
Evidence shows that higher obesity rates have been identified in southwest and central parts of 
Iran and may be explained by lifestyle factors such as eating habits, high-calorie diets, and fast 
foods (Ghaderian et al., 2019). The factors appear to be more common in main cities than in the 
agricultural areas in Northern provinces (Ghaderian et al., 2019). Abiri et al. (2023) observed that 
the prevalence of obesity exhibits significant variances among the provinces of Iran. The 
variations can be attributed to differing cultural affiliations and the influence of socioeconomic 
factors (Abiri et al., 2023). 
Treatment of Obesity 
According to Morton et al. (2019), effective obesity treatment relied on a comprehensive 
approach incorporating five key components: nutrition, physical activity, behavior modification, 
pharmacotherapy, and bariatric surgery. Saxon et al. (2019) highlighted that lifestyle changes, 
pharmacological treatments, and bariatric surgery differ significantly in terms of anticipated 
weight loss, costs, risks, and potential side effects. By reviewing the patient's medical history, 
conducting a physical examination and analyzing laboratory data, clinicians can assess the risk 
factors related to high body mass index (BMI), fat distribution, weight gain and evaluate the 
level of physical activity in context (Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Cost-effective interventions are 
necessary to prevent overweight and obesity and to reduce the likelihood of weight gain (Rippe 

51 
 
 
 
& Foreyt, 2022). An intervention that plays a crucial role in treatment strategies is physical 
activity (Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans, 2018; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). The Physical 
Activity Guidelines for Americans (2018) recommend that all adults should engage in 150 
minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity per week (Maestroni et al., 2020; Morton et al., 
2019; Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans, 2018; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Engaging in 
regular aerobic activity is an important step towards achieving and maintaining a healthy weight 
(Rani & Kohli, 2024). Incorporating resistance training exercises, such as weight lifting, can 
significantly improve muscle mass, leading to a boosted metabolic rate and better long-term 
weight management (Lincoln, 2020; Maestroni et al., 2020; Rani & Kohli, 2024). According to 
Rippe and Foreyt (2022), losing 1% to 2% of weight takes six to 18 months on average. 
Behavior modification stands as a crucial intervention for addressing obesity and serves 
as the foundational element of long-term weight management programs (Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). 
The guideline from the American Heart Association/American College of Cardiology/The 
Obesity Society strongly advocates for behavior modification for all patients undergoing obesity 
treatment (Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is an established intervention 
designed to address thought patterns and behaviors associated with eating (Rani & Kohli, 2024). 
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy aims to equip individuals with effective coping strategies, thus 
contributing to sustainable weight loss (Rani & Kohli, 2024). 
Dietary modification is imperative for weight management (Rani & Kohli, 2024; Rippe 
& Foreyt, 2022). However, Morton et al. (2019) reported that with so many diets available, 
nutrition is the most controversial topic in the treatment of obesity. Appropriate dietary 
modifications impart essential nutrients through a balanced diet rich in whole foods (Morton et 
al., 2019; Rani & Kohli, 2024; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Portion control plays a pivotal role in 
educating individuals about appropriate serving sizes, thereby promoting mindful eating habits 

52 
 
 
 
(Rani & Kohli, 2024; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). This practice serves as a means to mitigate 
overeating and encourages the adoption of healthier dietary choices (Çakmur, 2020; Rani & 
Kohli, 2024; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). 
The current guidelines for managing obesity emphasize the use of medication in treating 
individuals with excess body fat (Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Numerous pharmaceuticals have 
received approval for the treatment of overweight and obesity within the past 70 years 
(Onakpoya et al., 2020). The guidelines include a body mass index (BMI) of 30 kg/m2 or higher, 
or a BMI of 27 kg/m2 or higher with at least one related health condition (Rani & Kohli, 2024; 
Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). The guidelines recommend using weight loss medications that are 
approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), along with making lifestyle changes 
such as adjusting diet, increasing physical activity, and receiving counseling to change behavior 
in order to create a calorie deficit (T. Liu et al., 2020; Morton et al., 2019). When working with a 
healthcare provider team, weight maintenance interventions should adhere to the FDA guidelines 
(Morton et al., 2019; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). 
One common pharmacological treatments for obesity is lipase inhibitors, or the common 
name orlistat (Liu et al., 2020; Porada et al., 2023; Rani & Kohli, 2024; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). 
Lipase inhibitor helps in weight loss by reducing fat absorption in the digestive tract (Rani & 
Kohli, 2024; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Lipase inhibitors are administered orally in conjunction 
with meals, resulting in a 30% reduction in the absorption of dietary fat into the small intestines 
(Liu et al., 2020; Mamrack, 2021). A minimal proportion of the drug is absorbed, with the 
majority being excreted unchanged in the feces (Mamrack, 2021). Furthermore, lipase inhibitors 
have exhibited a capacity to lower Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and reduce the 
incidence of diabetes compared to a placebo (Liu et al., 2020; Mamrack, 2021). The potential
