side effects of lipase inhibitors consist of oily spotting, fecal incontinence, flatus with discharge, 

53 
 
 
 
abdominal cramping, elevated blood pressure, dry mouth, constipation, headache, and insomnia 
(Liu et al., 2020). 
 Another pharmacological treatment for obesity involves the combined use of naltrexone 
and bupropion, or the common name mysimba (Onakpoya et al., 2020; Porada et al., 2023; Rippe 
& Foreyt, 2022). This combination formulation is used as a treatment option for long-term 
management of overweight and obesity, in conjunction with exercise and a reduced-calorie diet 
(Onakpoya et al., 2020; Porada et al., 2023; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Naltrexone, an opioid 
receptor antagonist used for alcohol and opioid dependence, when combined with bupropion, 
disrupts the feedback loop that limits the anorectic effects of bupropion (Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). 
Bupropion is a dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor approved for the treatment of 
depression and for aiding in smoking cessation by modulating the reward pathways (Rippe & 
Foreyt, 2022). According to Onakpoya et al. (2020), the concurrent effects of naltrexone and 
bupropion diminish food cravings. Side effects of naltrexone and bupropion are nausea, 
constipation, headache, vomiting, dizziness, insomnia, dry mouth, and diarrhea (Grilo et al., 
2021). 
Another pharmacological option is glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) analogs, liraglutide, 
and semaglutide (Frías et al., 2021; Porada et al., 2023; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). GLP-1, 
liraglutide, and semaglutide have been shown to delay gastric emptying, enhance feelings of 
fullness, and suppress appetite (Frías et al., 2021; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). The emptying of the 
stomach can be delayed for at least three reasons: 1) delaying gastric emptying can lower blood 
sugar levels after a meal; 2) delaying gastric emptying can reduce calorie intake, which can be 
beneficial for obesity; and 3) delaying gastric emptying can cause symptoms that require a 
slowing down of medication dosage increments (Maselli & Camilleri, 2021). The most common 

54 
 
 
 
side effects of GLP-1, liraglutide, and semaglutide are headaches, nasal pharyngitis, and upper 
respiratory tract infections (Gilbert & Pratley, 2020). 
The combination of phentermine and topiramate is formulated to specifically target the 
brain's appetite control centers, acting on Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptors to reduce 
appetite and increase satiety, resulting in decreased calorie intake (Rani & Kohli, 2024; Rippe & 
Foreyt, 2022). According to Lei et al. (2021), in addition to weight loss, phentermine and 
topiramate has been proven to improve the cardiovascular system, blood pressure, blood sugar, 
and blood lipid levels. Phentermine indirectly affects the nervous system and increases the 
release of norepinephrine and prevents its reabsorption (Kim et al., 2023; Lei et al., 2021). 
Additionally, phentermine prompts the release of serotonin and dopamine from nerve terminals 
as well as having weak reversible effects on certain enzymes and the reabsorption of serotonin, 
along with topiramate (Kim et al., 2023; Lei et al., 2021). Topiramate affects certain channels 
and receptors in the brain, helps to control the activity of calcium and sodium channels, as well 
as GABA receptors, and at the same time works against AMPA/KA receptors (Kim et al., 2023; 
Lei et al., 2021). The most common side effects are dry mouth and paresthesia, constipation, 
insomnia, dizziness and dysgeusia, anxiety-related adverse events, and depression (Lei et al., 
2021; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). 
When addressing obesity and the related comorbidities, surgical intervention represents a 
highly efficacious approach for treatment and the potential reversal of the conditions (Morton et 
al., 2019). Bhasker et al. (2021) recommend prioritizing dietary control, regular physical activity, 
and/or drug therapy over surgical interventions. One of the most common weight loss surgeries is 
bariatric surgery, which entails anatomical alterations aimed at restricting food intake or reducing 
the absorptive intestinal surface (Bhasker et al., 2021; Morton et al., 2019). There are three 
categories of bariatric surgery: restrictive, restrictive malabsorptive, and malabsorptive, which 

55 
 
 
 
includes with or without bowel diversion (Bhasker et al., 2021; Morton et al., 2019). Surgical 
bariatric procedures, with or without small bowel diversion, modify the digestive system's 
anatomy (Bhasker et al., 2021). The alterations profoundly impact overall gastrointestinal(GI) 
physiology (Bhasker et al., 2021; Morton et al., 2019). The alterations consist of restrict food 
intake, modify the digestive and absorptive processes, induce changes in GI hormones, motility, 
microbiota balance, neural signaling, and other lesser-known mechanisms (Bhasker et al., 2021; 
Morton et al., 2019). 
Perimenopause 
Symptoms of Perimenopause 
 
 Perimenopause is ill-defined; however, documentation has been reported that 
perimenopause begins with the first menstrual irregularity and ends one year of amenorrhea, 
which marks the beginning of menopause (Geraghty, 2022; Khan et al., 2023). During 
perimenopause, a woman's ovarian function and estrogen levels experience a gradual decline, 
which varies among individuals (Hao et al., 2021). This decline results in a persistent deficiency 
encompassing changes in endocrine, biological, and clinical characteristics associated with 
reduced ovarian function (Hao et al., 2021). Women transitioning into the perimenopausal phase 
typically experience changes in reproductive hormones accompanied by sleep disturbances and 
vasomotor symptoms such as irregular periods, hot flashes, weight gain, poor sleep, vaginal 
dryness, mood swings, brain fog, and bladder problems (Matthews et al., 2021; Harper et al., 
2022; Johnson, 2020). Approximately 80% of women worldwide experience vasomotor 
symptoms during the perimenopausal stage, with hot flashes and sweating being the most 
prevalent manifestations (Khan et al., 2023; Kingsberg et al., 2024). The intensity of these 
symptoms can vary significantly, impacting up to 75% of women, which are known to disrupt 
sleep, affect mood, and compromise overall health and quality of life (Khan et al., 2023; 

56 
 
 
 
Kingsberg et al., 2024; McCormick et al., 2020; Pinkerton & Santen, 2019). Another common 
and most bothersome symptom of perimenopause is sleep disturbance (Geraghty, 2022). Sleep is 
a multifaceted process impacted by physiological, psychological, social, and cultural factors, 
which is vital for the physical, mental, and social well-being of perimenopausal women 
(Geraghty, 2022). Sleep issues affect 40% to 60% of perimenopausal women and usually persist, 
potentially leading to heart disease, diabetes, depression, anxiety, and overuse of sleep 
medications (Zolfaghari et al., 2020). 
Perimenopausal women face a significantly increased risk of hyperlipidaemia, a 
condition marked by elevated blood lipid levels, including cholesterol and triglycerides, that is 
closely linked to chronic diseases (Hao et al., 2021). The increased risk is attributed to a decline 
in basal metabolic rate coupled with an increase in body mass and fat accumulation (Hao et al., 
2021). Consequently, perimenopausal women are particularly susceptible to the development of 
metabolic syndrome (Hao et al., 2021). Weight gain generally starts to occur in a linear pattern 
during or just before the perimenopause stage (Geraghty, 2022; Hao et al., 2021). However, this 
gain is often inconsistently categorized as a symptom of perimenopause, aging, or lifestyle 
changes (Geraghty, 2022). As the perimenopause begins, the rate of fat mass increase doubles, 
while lean mass concurrently declines (Geraghty, 2022; Hao et al., 2021). 
Hormonal Impact of Perimenopause 
Perimenopause is a sign of declining ovarian hormone levels impacting various aspects of 
health (De Franciscis et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019). Estrogen, a hormone produced in the ovaries, 
plays a vital role in regulating fat distribution in the breasts, buttocks, and thighs, as well as in 
the development of female reproductive organs (Ko & Kim, 2020; Löfqvist, 2022). Decreased 
estrogen levels may lead to a reduction in sexual desire, increased sensitivity to pain, joint pain, 
muscle pain, migraines, and weight gain (Godley et al., 2024; Löfqvist, 2022). During the 

57 
 
 
 
perimenopausal transition, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) gradually increases (Matthews et 
al., 2021). FSH is responsible for the development of female fertility and the dimensions and 
strength of the skeleton and connective tissue (Löfqvist, 2022). Progesterone plays a crucial role 
in facilitating menstruation by preparing the endometrium, the lining of the uterus, to support the 
implantation and growth of a fertilized egg (Godley et al., 2024; Trabert et al., 2020). 
Progesterone has been shown to improve sleep quality and enhance endothelial function, an 
important marker of cardiovascular health, as well as used to manage vasomotor symptoms in 
women who are unable to take estrogen (Geraghty, 2022; Tandon et al., 2022). Estradiol also 
decreases gradually, starting about two years before the final menstrual period and continuing to 
decline until two years after the final menstrual period (Matthews et al., 2021). Estradiol is the 
primary sex steroid hormone in women, which increases the production of endorphins and 
opioids and is produced in the placenta during pregnancy (Li et al., 2021; Löfqvist, 2022). 
 During perimenopause, women experience a shift of subcutaneous fat from the hips and 
thighs to the abdomen, which increases the risk of conditions like insulin resistance, type 2 
diabetes (T2D), and cardiovascular disease (Duralde et al., 2023; Karaflou & Goulis, 2024; 
Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Annually, approximately two million women in the United States reach 
perimenopause and are affected by the changes (Karaflou & Goulis, 2024). According to Ress et 
al. (2022), women gain on average 22 pounds from 40 to 60 years from lifestyle factors such as 
poor diet, reduced physical activities, smoking, and alcohol consumption. However, Porada et al. 
(2023) found that reduced estrogen causes weight gain. Estrogen acts to suppress appetite and 
reduce food intake through central mechanisms, resulting in the stabilization of body weight and 
the preferential distribution of adipose tissue to the femoral-gluteal region (Porada et al., 2023). 
Estrogen deficiency induces a shift in adipose tissue distribution, leading to an increase in central 
(abdominal) adiposity in preference to peripheral (gluteal, femoral) deposition (Porada et al., 

58 
 
 
 
2023). Central adiposity is a crucial factor linked to multiple risk factors for various metabolic 
diseases, including high blood pressure, elevated plasma glucose, increased triglycerides, and 
low levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Another hormone that 
contributes to weight gain during perimenopause is testosterone (Porada et al., 2023). 
Testosterone plays a crucial role in both the accumulation of visceral fat and the development of 
lean body mass (Porada et al., 2023). Lowered testosterone levels in perimenopausal women are 
associated with dysphoric mood, unexplained fatigue, alterations in sexual function such as 
reduced libido, changes in cognition, vasomotor symptoms, bone loss, and diminished muscle 
strength (Scott & Newson, 2020). 
 As individuals age, the basal metabolic rate decreases, resulting in an average annual 
weight gain of 1.5 pounds (Briga et al., 2021; Duralde et al., 2023). According to Vásquez-
Alvarez et al. (2021), an adult's basal metabolic rate decreases every decade due to the decline in 
skeletal muscle mass. This decline consequently lowers the energy requirement of adults and 
contributes to the prevalence of obesity (Vásquez-Alvarez et al., 2021). Weight gain during 
perimenopause can be attributed, in part, to the actions of fat adipokines, which impact 
metabolism, inflammation, and various physiological systems, including the immune, 
endothelial, and cardiovascular systems (Chapman-Lopez et al., 2022; Palla et al., 2020). 
Changes in body composition are considered to be the primary influencer of adipokines 
(Chapman-Lopez et al., 2022). Chapman-Lopez et al. (2022) observed that various therapeutic 
interventions, including medication, dietary modification, meditation, and exercise, are effective 
in targeting changes in body composition. Research highlighted that resistance training is most 
efficacious in positively enhancing body composition by modulating the ratio of lean muscle 
mass to fat mass (Chapman-Lopez et al., 2022). 

59 
 
 
 
Obese African American Women 
Based on the 2020 Census, African Americans represent the third-largest racial group in 
the United States with 62 distinct Black or African American ethnicities (Coritz et al., 2023). In 
2020, African American women accounted for 7% of the United States population, with 
expectations of an increase of over 15% by 2060 (Chinn et al., 2021; M. Williams et al., 2022). 
In the Study of Women’s Health Across the Nation (SWAN), weight gain was found to be 
significantly higher among African American and Hispanic women than among Caucasian peers 
(Abou-Fadel et al., 2022). Additionally, African American and Hispanic women showed a 
notably quicker progression to obesity over time (Abou-Fadel et al., 2022). Significant 
demographics of African American women in the United States are marital status: 48% are 
married, 30% never married, education level: 5% drop out of school, 26% high school diploma 
or General Educational Development (GED), 26% associate's degree, 24% bachelor’s degree, 
15% advanced degree, labor force: 57% employed, 43% not in labor force, poverty level: 13% 
below poverty level and 87% above poverty level (United States Census Bureau, 2021). 
Body Image of African American Women 
Obese African American women have been reported to perceive larger, curvier body 
figures as attractive and normal, aligning with culturally accepted social and body image norms 
and resisting Western normative body ideals (Dunn et al., 2019; Ford & Pickett, 2020; Lofton et 
al., 2023; Manjunath et al., 2021). However, Ford and Pickett (2020) found that African 
American women tend to underestimate body mass index (BMI) in comparison to women of 
other racial groups when considering weight. The historical experiences of slavery have deeply 
influenced the socialization of African American girls and women (Dunn et al., 2019). This has 
resulted in an emphasis on self-evaluation based on physical appearance within the African 

60 
 
 
 
American demographic (Dunn et al., 2019). Modica et al. (2023) discovered that African 
American women have an appreciation for diverse looks as beautiful, which is reflected in 
differences in ideal body images. African American women tend to have a positive body image at 
higher weight levels (Chinn et al., 2021). Achieving or maintaining a healthy weight is a 
complex endeavor influenced by external social and cultural factors such as social networks, 
family upbringing, stigma, bias, racism, body perception, cultural food practices, social 
influencers, stress, and religion (Ford & Pickett, 2020; Shockley & Norman Burrell, 2024). The 
elements play pivotal roles in the decision-making processes related to weight management 
(Shockley & Norman Burrell, 2024). 
Obesity and Socioeconomic Status in African American Women 
African American women have been historically underrepresented in obesity research 
(Abbasi, 2023; Chinn et al., 2021; Forsyth & Roberts, 2019; Tidwell Torres et al., 2024). This 
longstanding exclusion has resulted in the development of interventions that are not tailored to 
the specific needs and preferences of African American women (Tidwell Torres et al., 2024). 
Despite the increasing population of African American women, there are poorer health outcomes 
in comparison to Caucasian women (Williams et al., 2022). This disparity is evident across 
multiple health domains, including maternal health, cardiovascular disease, mental health 
conditions such as depression, and mortality rates associated with diabetes, as well as breast and 
gynecologic cancers (M. Williams et al., 2022). Addressing this research gap is crucial for 
developing effective solutions tailored to the African American women demographic. African 
American women face a disproportionate burden of chronic conditions, including anemia, 
cardiovascular disease (CVD), and obesity (Chinn et al., 2021; Lofton et al., 2023; Miller & 

61 
 
 
 
Platenburg, 2021). Within the African American population, obesity rates were notably higher 
among women at 56.9% compared to men, who had a rate of 41.1% (Lofton et al., 2023). 
According to recent data, approximately 80% of African American women are 
categorized as overweight or obese (Wilcox et al., 2020). Obesity is a significant cause of illness 
and death for all populations in the United States (Chinn et al., 2021). However, African 
Americans have a higher prevalence of obesity, with estimates ranging from 34% to fifty percent 
(Chinn et al., 2021). Patterns of obesity differ based on various factors within and across races, 
such as location, gender, and education (Chinn et al., 2021; Richardson et al., 2023). African 
Americans are often disproportionately exposed to neighborhood-level stressors, including crime 
and limited access to healthy foods and safe places for physical activity (Barrington et al., 2021a; 
Hojjat, 2021; Richardson et al., 2023). This is partially attributed to historic racist practices 
related to residential segregation (Richardson et al., 2023). 
Social determinants (SES), including poverty, access to health insurance, and dietary 
choices, play a critical role in the racial health disparities evident among African American 
women (Williams et al., 2022). The impact of racism within the medical field and its contribution 
to health disparities in African Americans have led to the recognition of racism as a public health 
crisis (Williams et al., 2022). Socioeconomic status plays a pivotal role in the obesity epidemic, 
particularly among African American women, where intersecting factors of race, income, and 
education shape health outcomes (Barrington et al., 2021; Hojjat, 2021; Wolfe et al., 2019). SES, 
defined by access to power, privilege, and resources, varies across individual, household, and 
neighborhood levels, influencing obesity risk through education, income, and occupation 
(Barrington et al., 2021; Woo et al., 2023). 

62 
 
 
 
At the individual level, SES encompasses factors such as education, earnings, and 
occupation (Barrington et al., 2021a). Educational attainment strongly correlates with obesity 
rates, adults without a high school diploma report the highest prevalence (35.0%), while college 
graduates report the lowest (24.7%) (Hojjat, 2021). Evidence shows that individuals with higher 
levels of education, along with increased health literacy and access to material and financial 
resources, are more likely to adopt healthier lifestyles and experience lower obesity rates (Assari, 
2019; Witkam et al., 2021). Education impacts living and working conditions, social and 
community networks, individual lifestyles, and health (Witkam et al., 2021). 
The demand for a skilled workforce has increased; therefore, obtaining higher education 
is necessary to gain import technical skills, technical knowledge, and cognitive ability (Hojjat, 
2021). African American women face compounded barriers due to racial and gender 
discrimination, wage gaps, and limited access to high-paying jobs. Earning 63 cents for every 
dollar earned by White non-Hispanic men, resulting in a lifetime income deficit nearing $1 
million (White, 2023). This disparity restricts access to essentials like housing, healthcare, and 
childcare, and hinders wealth-building opportunities (White, 2023). Despite high labor force 
participation, African American women are overrepresented in low-wage sectors such as retail, 
hospitality, and food service and face elevated unemployment rates across all education levels 
(Kijakazi & Runes, 2023; White, 2023). Structural racism and social determinants such as 
poverty, limited insurance, and constrained dietary choices contribute to persistent health 
disparities and have led to the recognition of racism as a public health crisis (Williams et al., 
2022; Okoro et al., 2020). 
Household-level socioeconomic status includes income, poverty, and wealth, which play 
a critical role in shaping obesity risk, particularly among marginalized communities (Barrington 

63 
 
 
 
et al., 2021). Food insecurity disproportionately affects low-income households, especially those 
led by non-Hispanic Black and Hispanic individuals, due to limited access to supermarkets and 
nutritious foods in socioeconomically disadvantaged neighborhoods (Wilcox et al., 2020). These 
areas, often labeled as food deserts, are marked by high poverty rates and geographic barriers to 
healthy food, contributing to poor diet quality and elevated obesity risk (Wilcox et al., 2020). 
Unemployment and poverty rates are higher among African Americans, compounding 
health disparities (Okoro et al., 2020). Housing wealth, central to net worth, has historically 
favored non-Hispanic Whites due to discriminatory policies, limiting African Americans’ access 
to homeownership and financial stability (Mehdipanah et al., 2020; Wolfe et al., 2019). 
Obesogenic environments, characterized by crime, traffic, and fast-food density, correlate with 
lower property values and higher BMI (Buszkiewicz et al., 2021; Wolfe et al., 2019). Despite the 
Fair Housing Act’s protections, systemic housing discrimination continues to hinder educational, 
employment, and economic opportunities for African American communities (Mehdipanah et al., 
2020). 
Neighborhood-level factors such as poverty, crime, and structural disadvantage shape 
health outcomes beyond individual or household SES (Barrington et al., 2021). African 
American families are disproportionately exposed to under-resourced neighborhoods, which 
limit access to education, safe spaces for physical activity, and health-promoting resources (Kim 
et al., 2023; Buszkiewicz et al., 2021; Song et al., 2023). These environments contribute to 
chronic stress and maladaptive coping behaviors, including emotional eating, particularly among 
African American women, who also face higher postpartum weight retention and earlier 
childbearing both linked to increased obesity risk (Song et al., 2023). 

64 
 
 
 
Obesogenic neighborhoods are marked by limited access to supermarkets and farmers’ markets, 
and a high density of fast-food outlets and convenience stores offering unhealthy options 
(Buszkiewicz et al., 2021; Kraft et al., 2020). The clustering of fast-food establishments near 
schools further exacerbates poor dietary patterns and long-term weight gain in low-income 
communities (Buszkiewicz et al., 2021). 
Underrepresentation of African American Women in Research 
In 1994, the United States National Institutes of Health mandated the inclusion of women 
and ethnic minorities in government-funded clinical studies (Abbasi, 2023). Clinical research is 
essential for providing evidence of the effectiveness and safety of new therapies (Clark et al., 
2019; Michos et al., 2021). Certain groups of patients, such as women compared to men, and 
individuals from different racial or ethnic backgrounds, may respond differently to medical 
treatments (Clark et al., 2019). 
Regrettably, in the United States, there persists an underrepresentation of racial and 
ethnic minority populations in clinical trials in comparison to Caucasian counterparts (Reopell et 
al., 2023). Despite the overrepresentation of African American women in negative health 
conditions and diseases, the representation in efforts to find treatments remains 
disproportionately low (Le et al., 2022). Diversity of clinical trial participants is essential to 
ensure that the trial population is representative of the patients who will use the medicine or 
medicinal product and to guarantee that the results are generalizable (Clark et al., 2019; Michos 
et al., 2021). The ongoing omission pertains specifically to research in the fields of 
endocrinology, diabetes, cancer, and cardiovascular disease (Reopell et al., 2023). This presents a 
significant concern as prevalent and fatal diseases in African American populations, such as 
hypertension and heart failure, have displayed varying responses to medications among different 

65 
 
 
 
racial and ethnic groups (Reopell et al., 2023). According to Michos et al. (2021), having a 
diverse group of investigators and clinical trial staff may help to better understand the language, 
customs, and beliefs of study populations and increase the participation of individuals from 
different backgrounds. 
The involvement of African American women in clinical research is crucial, especially in 
pediatric trials (Le et al., 2022). This is because mothers often have a significant impact on 
managing children's health and usually take on the responsibility of making health-related 
decisions, including whether children can participate in clinical research (Le et al., 2022). 
According to Clark et al. (2019), there are five identified barriers to the participation of racially 
and ethnically diverse patients in clinical trials. The obstacles include mistrust, inadequate 
comfort with the clinical trial process, lack of information about clinical trials, time and resource 
constraints associated with participation, as well as a lack of awareness about the existence and 
importance of clinical trials (Clark et al., 2019). 
San Antonio’s estimated population is over 1.5 million (U.S. Census Bureau, 2022a). 
According to Saenz and Casura (n.d.), African American and Asian American women are notably 
overrepresented among the elderly. In San Antonio, three-fourths of individuals aged 85 and 
older from the demographics are female (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). In the San Antonio area, there 
are differences in marriage prevalence among women of different racial and ethnic backgrounds. 
Specifically, 77% of Asian American women, 69% of Caucasian women, 55% of Latina women, 
and 37% of African American women were married (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). 
San Antonio has experienced significant disparities in educational opportunities and 
unequal funding of schools linked to race and socioeconomic status (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). The 
high school dropout rate of women 16 to 24 years of age in San Antonio is 6.5% of Latina 

66 
 
 
 
women, 4% of Asian American women, 2.6% of Caucasian women, and .6% of African 
American women (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). In San Antonio, women have closed the gender 
educational gap that has historically prevented them from advancing in the opportunity structure 
(Saenz & Casura, n.d.). In fact, the percentages of women with a bachelor's degree or higher in 
San Antonio are as follows: 47% of Asian American women, 43% of Caucasian women, 26.5% 
of African American women, and 16.4% of Latina women (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). 
There exists a significant disparity in the earnings of women in San Antonio based on 
racial and ethnic background. Among all workers, Caucasian women demonstrate the highest 
median earnings of $32,078, while Asian American women exhibit the highest median earnings 
among full-time, year-round employees at $47,468 (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). Conversely, African 
American and Latina women experience substantially lower earnings. Specifically, Latina 
women working full-time, year-round workers earn only 66 cents for every $1 earned by 
Caucasian women, whereas African American women earn 75 cents for every $1 earned by 
Caucasian women (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). 
There exist considerable disparities in poverty rates among women in San Antonio across 
various racial and ethnic groups. The incidence of poverty is contingent upon family composition 
as well as the presence of children (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). Poverty rates among African 
American and Latina female children are approximately 2.5 times higher than among Caucasians 
(Saenz & Casura, n.d.). Caucasian and Asian females exhibit the lowest poverty rates, while 
African American and Latina women demonstrate the highest levels of impoverishment (Saenz 
& Casura, n.d.). Around 30% of African American and Latina female children live in poverty, a 
figure that stands in stark contrast to the 12% of Caucasian girls in similar circumstances (Saenz 
& Casura, n.d.). 

67 
 
 
 
Resistance Training 
 Strength training, also known as weight or resistance training, is an effective and popular 
form of exercise for maintaining muscle quantity and quality (Beavers et al., 2017; Muñoz-
López et al., 2022; Otsuka et al., 2022). According to Muñoz-López et al. (2022), the benefits 
extend beyond enhancing sports performance to improve health-related fitness. In 2008, 
resistance training was added to the physical activity guidelines for Americans (Hart & Buck, 
2019). Adults should engage in moderate to high-intensity muscle-strengthening activities, 
working on all major muscle groups on two or more days per week (Hart & Buck, 2019). The 
same guidelines apply to older adults, as resistance training may benefit the older population 
even more (Hart & Buck, 2019). 
Benefits of Resistance Training 
 Engaging consistently in resistance training over the long term provides numerous 
benefits. Enhancing muscular strength and mass while reducing visceral fat leads to improved 
body composition, metabolism, and physical performance (Hollingsworth et al., 2020; 
Krzysztofik et al., 2019; Muñoz-López et al., 2022). In older populations, the advantages 
contribute to the prevention of sarcopenia and the preservation of functional strength 
(Hollingsworth et al., 2020). Resistance training serves as a foundational exercise intervention 
aimed at fostering strength and promoting muscle hypertrophy (Krzysztofik et al., 2019). 
According to Krysztofik et al. (2019), the expansion of muscle mass constitutes a critical element 
in conditioning for various sports, which is closely tied to muscle strength. Resistance training 
has a variety of short, medium, and long-term physiological adaptations (Muñoz-López et al., 
2022). This intervention significantly improves body composition, muscle hypertrophy, strength, 
power, motor performance, and improves blood pressure and bone mineral density (Gentil et al., 

68 
 
 
 
2020; Muñoz-López et al., 2022). Resistance training delivers a range of health benefits, such as 
notable changes in blood pressure, insulin sensitivity, lipid profile, and endocrine function, as 
well as enhanced performance in daily life activities (Muñoz-López et al., 2022). Which is 
crucial to emphasize the significance of muscle mass for overall health (Krzysztofik et al., 2019). 
Low levels of muscle mass are directly associated with heightened risks of various diseases such 
as cardiovascular disease and cardio-metabolic risks in adolescents, as well as type II diabetes in 
middle-aged and older adults (Krzysztofik et al., 2019). Losses in muscle mass usually start 
around middle age, averaging about -1% annually, and in extreme cases, this can lead to a 
cumulative decline of -50% by the time a person reaches age 80 (Buskard & Petrella, 2023). 
Resistance training yields a multitude of advantages; most programs are designed to 
develop muscle and bone strength (Forsyth & Roberts, 2019). According to Maestroni et al. 
(2020), enhanced muscular strength has a favorable impact on athletic performance, including 
increased rate of force development and power, improved jumping, sprinting, change of direction 
capabilities, heightened potentiation, and enhanced running economy. The World Health 
organization’s (WHO) global guidelines for the general population to mitigate non-communicable 
diseases encompass a minimum of 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic physical activity, 
complemented by muscle-strengthening exercises targeting major muscle groups on two or more 
days per week (Maestroni et al., 2020). Saeidifard et al., (2019) indicated that resistance training 
has the potential to enhance multiple cardiovascular risk factors, such as insulin resistance, 
glucose regulation, lipid metabolism, decreased body fat mass, hemoglobin A1c levels, Type II 
Diabetes, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. Resistance training offers numerous benefits 
beyond muscle hypertrophy. According to Waehner (2020), resistance training also contributes to 
the development of stronger bones, a particularly advantageous aspect for individuals grappling 
with osteoporosis. 

69 
 
 
 
Resistance training has a long history, dating back to ancient civilizations such as Rome 
and Greece (Waehner, 2020). The origins of the Olympics from that era showcased the 
importance of strength, power, and speed through events like discus throwing, shot put, and the 
hammer throw (Waehner, 2020). Resistance training is considered a crucial element of a 
comprehensive exercise program and complements the well-established positive effects of 
aerobic training on health and physical capacities (Fragala et al., 2019). Further, strong evidence 
suggests that resistance training can help alleviate the impact of aging on neuromuscular function 
and functional capacity (Fragala et al., 2019). 
Types of Resistance Training 
 There are several different types of resistance training. Dynamic Constant Training 
(DCT) is a resistance training model that keeps the resistance constant over the entire range of 
motion (Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019; Mesfar et al., 2022). A prime example of 
DCT is when employing free weights or machines that maintain a consistent resistance while 
redirecting the resistance (Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019; Mesfar et al., 2022). 
This method effectively emphasizes different planes of motion within the targeted muscle group, 
optimizing the workout experience (Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). Dynamic 
constant training is typically accomplished with free weights or weight machines with the 
advantage of low cost and easy progression to monitor (Powers et al., 2024). 
 Calisthenics is a form of bodyweight exercise that includes dynamic and rhythmic 
movements, requiring no equipment (Kotarsky et al., 2018; Lee et al., 2024). An effective 
workout option, offering efficiency and cost-effectiveness as an alternative to traditional 
resistance training, can be performed almost anywhere without requiring any equipment 
(Kotarsky et al., 2018; Lee et al., 2024). The versatility of calisthenics contributes significantly to 

70 
 
 
 
improving muscular strength, endurance, flexibility, and coordination. In fact, according to 
surveys conducted by the American College of Sports Medicine, calisthenics ranked as the 
second fitness trend in both 2017 and 2016, and was the number one trend in 2015 (Kotarsky et 
al., 2018). 
 Dynamic progressive training is frequently employed as a rehabilitative approach (Flynn 
et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). This method offers a form of resistance that increases 
gradually, allowing individuals to maintain complete control over the training process (Flynn et 
al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). Dynamic progressive training is effectively utilized with 
resistance bands or cables to rehabilitate torn ligaments, joints, muscles, and fractured bones 
(Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). This approach is highly beneficial for individuals 
traveling for business or leisure, as this approach enables to maintain training and recovery 
routines with ease, regardless of the person’s location (Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 
2019). Dynamic progressive training offers several advantages, including affordability, easy 
accessibility, and versatility in usage across various locations (Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & 
Peterson, 2019). 
 Dynamic Variable Training (DVT) utilizes unstable loads and varying resistance to 
challenge the body in multiple ways effectively (Markell & Peterson, 2019; Muñoz-López et al., 
2022; Powers et al., 2024). This approach has the potential to enhance strength, improve balance, 
and elevate athletic performance (Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). The capability 
to adjust resistance throughout the range of motion is a significant advantage of variable 
resistance training devices (Muñoz-López et al., 2022). DVT enables the modification of the 
force range of motion (ROM) curve to align with the specific requirements of a given exercise 
(Markell & Peterson, 2019; Muñoz-López et al., 2022). DVT is performed using elastic bands 

71 
 
 
 
and chains, either alone or in combination with traditional training methods that include free 
weights and variable resistance tools (Muñoz-López et al., 2022). The advantage of DVT is the 
adaptability for all fitness levels, making DVT an inclusive training method (Powers et al., 
2024). 
 Isokinetic training is regarded as an effective method for rehabilitation and conditioning 
of muscle function (Dvir & Müller, 2020; Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). In 
isokinetic training, resistance remains constant while the velocity is regulated, effectively 
targeting "single-joint" configurations such as the knee, shoulder, and hip. This approach 
facilitates the assessment of muscle performance and mobilizes the lever arm limb assembly 
around a fixed axis (Dvir & Müller, 2020; Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). 
Isokinetic training offers the benefit of providing maximal resistance throughout an entire range 
of motion, enabling exercises to be conducted at varying angular velocities (Powers et al., 2024). 
This capability facilitates targeted muscle development while maintaining consistent resistance, 
optimizing performance across different movement speeds (Powers et al., 2024). 
 Next is isometric training, which has been established as an effective and time-efficient 
strategy for reducing both resting and ambulatory blood pressure levels (Altan et al., 2020; Lea 
et al., 2021; Maestroni et al., 2020). Isometric training is an effective method for improving 
muscular strength while reducing the negative impacts on joints and tendons that are commonly 
linked to traditional strength training and heavy weightlifting (Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & 
Peterson, 2019). This type of training involves muscle contractions that occur without visible 
changes in the muscle's length, meaning the muscles do not lengthen or shorten during the 
exercise (Altan et al., 2020; Flynn et al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). The advantages of 

72 
 
 
 
isometric training are that there is minimal cost for equipment and less time is required to 
perform the exercises (Powers et al., 2024). 
 The final category of resistance training is isotonic training, which involves maintaining 
constant tension throughout the exercise (Flynn et al., 2024; Marinho et al., 2023; Markell & 
Peterson, 2019). This method typically utilizes free weights to achieve its effectiveness (Flynn et 
al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). Isotonic exercise effectively combines concentric 
contractions of the agonist, resulting in muscle shortening, with eccentric contractions of the 
antagonist, which leads to muscle lengthening or vice versa (Azeem & Zemková, 2022; Flynn et 
al., 2024; Markell & Peterson, 2019). This training method powerfully utilizes the stretch-
shortening cycle, where a muscle is lengthened and then immediately follows with a shortening 
contraction (Azeem & Zemková, 2022). Isotonic exercises offer several advantages. The 
exercises can be performed with or without gym equipment, contribute to increased muscle size 
and strength, enhance cardiovascular fitness, support daily activities without inducing fatigue, 
improve bone density, and may reduce the risk of sports injuries (Azeem & Zemková, 2022). 
Resistance Training with Women 
Unfortunately, despite the known benefits of resistance training, only 8.7% of older 
adults in the United States participate in muscle-strengthening activities as part of leisure time 
(Fragala et al., 2019). Waehner (2020) identified several barriers to participation in resistance 
training by older adults: fear of injury, fear of pain, believing in a “no pain, no gain” culture, 
ongoing physical issues, confusion on how to start, and time constraints. However, the 
immediate benefits of resistance training are stable blood sugar levels, increased hormones, like 
adrenaline and noradrenaline which boost energy and one’s mood, improve sleep, increase 
metabolism, lower blood pressure, and decrease arthritis pain (Waehner, 2020). Long-term 

73 
 
 
 
benefits of resistance training are the development of strong bones, weight management, 
enhanced quality of life, management of chronic conditions, and sharpens cognitive skills 
(Summers, 2021). 
Recently, there has been a significant rise in the preference for resistance training as a 
primary exercise modality, especially among women (Hagstrom et al., 2020). According to 
Hagstrom et al. (2020), resistance training is regarded as the premier exercise modality for 
enhancing the accrual of lean muscle mass. Loss of muscle mass is a key factor in the decline of 
muscle strength associated with aging (Sipilä et al., 2020). However, the decrease in muscle 
strength due to aging can be up to three times more significant than the loss of muscle mass 
(Sipilä et al., 2020). Jung et al. (2023) found that only 39% of all participants in the published 
data in sports and exercise science literature are women. Researchers have conclusively 
documented that the assessment of the field of sport and sociology argues that a clear gendered 
bias exists towards the discourse of power and masculinity within the literature (Walters & 
Hefferon, 2020). Walters and Hefferon (2020) have noted the significant progress made in the 
domains of weightlifting, bodybuilding, and competitive strongwoman sports. Nevertheless, 
there remains a need for further investigation into women's engagement in strength-based sports 
and physical activities focused on muscularity (Walters & Hefferon, 2020). 
In women, resistance training has been associated with the treatment and risk reduction of 
metabolic syndrome, fibromyalgia, and rheumatoid arthritis (Hagstrom et al., 2020). Studies 
show that there are a few noteworthy sex differences in response to resistance training such as 
disparities in fatigability, muscle perfusion, recovery time, muscle fiber size, and composition 
(Hagstrom et al., 2020). Evidence suggests that female sex hormones, such as estradiol, have an 
anabolic function due to the role in protein synthesis in the ovaries (Jung et al., 2023). Studies on 

74 
 
 
 
the menstrual cycle indicate that athletic performance and maximum strength may be higher 
during the follicular phase, characterized by high estrogen levels, compared to the luteal phase 
(Jung et al., 2023). Thompson et al. (2020) found a high concentration of estrogen in women is 
postulated to result in a greater release of growth hormone following resistance training. 
The process of aging is commonly associated with a gradual decrease in skeletal muscle 
mass and strength, leading to a decline in overall functional fitness and the ability to perform 
daily activities and increasing the risks of falls and fractures (Herda & Nabavizadeh, 2021; 
Isenmann et al., 2023; Ransdell et al., 2021). Herda and Nabavizadeh (2021) discovered that as 
men and women reach the ages 40s and 50s, there is a noticeable decrease in muscle mass, 
particularly in fast-twitch or type II muscle fibers. This decrease leads to a reduction in strength, 
balance, and overall function (Herda & Nabavizadeh, 2021). In older women, the causes of 
decreased muscle and bone mass and strength are multifactorial, primarily due to the loss of 
estrogen and physical inactivity (Ransdell et al., 2021). Hence, postmenopausal women are at an 
elevated risk of developing osteoporosis and other musculoskeletal conditions (Isenmann et al., 
2023). According to Ransdell et al. (2021), estrogen exhibits a wide array of physiological 
effects, such as the involvement in reproductive processes, the anti-inflammatory properties in 
the vasculature, and the contribution to maintaining bone integrity. Moreover, the presence of 
estrogen receptors in bone, tendons, ligaments, and muscles establishes its influence on 
metabolism (Ransdell et al., 2021). Furthermore, estrogen exerts an anabolic effect on the 
development of the tissues (Ransdell et al., 2021). Estrogen is crucial for altering connective 
tissue in response to physical activity involving mechanical forces such as resistance training 
(Ransdell et al., 2021). 

75 
 
 
 
Hormone replacement therapy presents potential side effects, including breast tenderness, 
enlargement, headaches, mood changes, and nausea (Isenmann et al., 2023). As an alternative to, 
or in conjunction with, hormone replacement therapy, resistance training interventions may be 
advised (Isenmann et al., 2023). Resistance training in perimenopausal women has positive 
effects on lean body mass, muscle mass, strength, functional capacity, bone mass, and bone 
mineral density (Hedrick, 2020; Isenmann et al., 2023). Isenmann et al. (2023) found that 
resistance training reduces risks of falls and fractures and promotes physical and mental well-
being, confidence, and happiness. 
Summary 
The study aimed to employ the health belief model (HBM) to analyze the impact between 
health beliefs and resistance training in obese African American perimenopausal women. The 
primary objective was to investigate the potential impact of resistance training on the target 
population. The HBM was applied to the participants to help gain higher confidence levels to be 
more inclined to engage in resistance training to improve health. 
The relationship between obesity, perimenopause, and resistance training is multifaceted 
and has significant implications for women’s health. Obesity is characterized by excess body fat, 
which can lead to various health complications such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and joint 
problems (Garland et al., 2023; Okunogbe et al., 2021; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). The obesity trend 
has been increasing globally since the 1970s (Garcia-Alexander & Poston, 2022; Opoku et al., 
2023). By 2030, half of Americans will be overweight, and 25% will be severely obese 
(Knickman & Elbel, 2019; Opoku et al., 2023). In 1997, the World Health Organization (WHO) 
declared obesity a global epidemic (Çakmur, 2020). Obesity is a pressing public health issue that 
is rapidly escalating worldwide, carrying substantial implications for both health and the 

76 
 
 
 
economy (Okunogbe et al., 2021). Obesity leads to several chronic conditions such as Type II 
Diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and hypertension (Roderka et al., 2020). Healthcare cost from 
obesity-related complications in the United States is estimated $147 billion in 2019 and expected 
to be $212B by 2050 (Shekar & Popkin, 2020). Next, obesity hinders work productivity 
primarily caused by absenteeism, presenteeism, and reduced workforce participation (Menon et 
al., 2022). 
The definition of perimenopause is unclear; nonetheless, it is commonly understood to 
commence with the onset of menstrual irregularities and to conclude after one year of 
amenorrhea, marking the onset of menopause (Geraghty, 2022; Khan et al., 2023). During 
perimenopause, there is a gradual decline in estrogen and progesterone levels, which impacts 
various aspects of health (Chapman-Lopez et al., 2022). The most prevalent symptoms reported 
during perimenopause are weight gain, physical and mental exhaustion, difficulty falling asleep, 
bladder problems, hot flashes, sexual problems, vaginal dryness, and anxiety (Harper et al., 
2022; Johnson, 2020). During perimenopause, women are more susceptible to metabolic 
disorders, such as dysregulated lipid metabolism, fat redistribution, visceral fat accumulation, 
and altered fatty acid metabolism (Ko & Kim, 2020). Regrettably, the lack of representation of 
African American perimenopausal women in research results in substandard or unsuitable 
treatment of women's health issues (Abbasi, 2023). 
Resistance training is widely recognized as an effective and popular exercise for 
preserving muscle mass and strength (Beavers et al., 2017; Muñoz-López et al., 2022; Otsuka et 
al., 2022). Adults are encouraged to participate in muscle-strengthening activities of moderate to 
high intensity, targeting all major muscle groups on two or more days per week (Hart & Buck, 
2019). Resistance training has several benefits such as improving body composition, muscle 

77 
 
 
 
hypertrophy, strength, power, and motor performance (Maestroni et al., 2020; Muñoz-López et 
al., 2022). Athletic performance benefits from an increased rate of force development and power, 
improved jumping, sprinting, and change of direction capabilities, heightened potentiation, and 
enhanced running economy (Maestroni et al., 2020). Compared to men, women have other 
benefits of resistance training, such as treatment and risk reduction of metabolic syndrome, 
fibromyalgia, rheumatoid arthritis, disparities in fatigability, muscle perfusion, recovery time, 
and muscle fiber size (Maestroni et al., 2020). Resistance training is essential in menopausal 
women because the elevated risk of developing osteoporosis and other musculoskeletal 
conditions has been proven that resistance training reduces risks of falls and fractures, and 
promotes physical and mental well-being, confidence and happiness (Waehner, 2020). 
Several studies have been presented regarding obesity, areas that result in lower quality of 
life for perimenopausal women and resistance training (Isenmann et al., 2023; Palla et al., 2020; 
Roderka et al., 2020). However, some gaps have been identified including when to incorporate 
resistance training for perimenopausal women and using resistance training during 
perimenopause to combat obesity training (Isenmann et al., 2023; Palla et al., 2020; Roderka et 
al., 2020). Another gap identified by this study helped bridge the gap in the underrepresentation 
of African American women in research (Abbasi, 2023; Forsyth & Roberts, 2019). 
 
 
 
 
 

78 
 
 
 
CHAPTER THREE: METHODS 
Overview 
The purpose of this randomized controlled trial study was to investigate how resistance 
training impacts body fat percentage in obese African American perimenopausal women in San 
Antonio, Texas. The chapter begins with an introduction to the design, followed by the 
presentation of the research question and null hypothesis. Next, a description of the data 
collection procedures, including details about the participants, setting, instrumentation, and 
procedures, will be provided. Finally, the selected statistical procedure and the appropriateness 
will be explained. 
Design 
The research methodology was a robust implementation of a randomized controlled trial 
(RCT). RCTs are universally recognized as the gold standard for evaluating the effectiveness of 
an intervention and are considered a rigorous form of evidence for establishing causal 
relationships in research (Hariton & Locascio, 2018; Twisk, 2021; Zabor et al., 2020). RTC was 
chosen for the study to assess and compare how resistance training impacts body fat in obese 
African American perimenopausal women by using two types of resistance training, with 
weights and with body weight (Hariton & Locascio, 2018; Kim, 2019). There is evidence of a 
causal relationship between the exposure or intervention studied and the observed outcome, as 
shown by prospective experimental designs that randomly assign interventions to trial 
participants (Hariton & Locascio, 2018; Zabor et al., 2020). Therefore, the participants will be 
randomly assigned to the proposed study, which investigates how resistance training impacts 
body fat percentage in obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio, Texas. 
The study incorporated one independent variable, which the condition did not change or 
was affected by other variables, and the dependent variable was the condition that responded to 

79 
 
 
 
the independent variable (Eldawlatly & Meo, 2019). The resistance training group was 
designated as the independent variable, as it represented the primary condition being examined in 
the study (Eldawlatly & Meo, 2019). Resistance training is a form of exercise intended to 
increase muscular strength and endurance, which involves working specific muscle groups using 
some form of resistance, which could be weights, bands, or even one’s own body weight 
working against gravity (Fragala et al., 2019). 
The independent variable is the condition that the researcher will manipulate (Thomas et 
al., 2015). Obesity in perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio was the 
dependent variable, as obesity was expected to be impacted by resistance training (Eldawlatly & 
Meo, 2019). The excessive accumulation of body fat characterizes obesity and is commonly 
assessed using the body mass index (BMI), which is derived from weight and height 
measurements (Çakmur, 2020). One covariate that was identified in this research was physical 
activity levels. Covariates are independent variables that may affect the outcome of a statistical 
analysis, but are not the main focus of the study (Joyner et al., 2018). Each participant was asked 
if they currently engage in resistance training. Participants who responded affirmatively agreed 
to cease participation in resistance training outside of the research study to ensure fair and 
accurate results. The dependent variable represents the outcome or result that is influenced by the 
independent variable (Thomas et al., 2015). Resistance training, a form of exercise, involves the 
utilization of weights or resistance to develop muscles, ligaments, and bones (Marinho et al., 
2023). The resistance training regimen for the group involved exercises utilizing external 
resistance, such as free weights, machine weights, or resistance bands. The primary goals are to 
enhance power and maintain posture. Randomization minimizes differences in group 
characteristics that may influence outcomes, providing evidence regarding the impact of 
exposure or intervention (Zabor et al., 2020). The intervention being assessed was resistance 

80 
 
 
 
training for obese perimenopausal women. Participants in the intervention group engaged in 
resistance training, whereas participants in the resistance training group with body weight group 
participated in bodyweight functional strength and stretching exercises. 
Research Questions 
RQ1: How does resistance training with weights compare to resistance training with 
body weight impact body fat percentage in obese African American perimenopausal women in 
San Antonio? 
 RQ2: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to age? 
RQ3: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to education attainment? 
 RQ4: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to religion? 
RQ5: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to marital status? 
Hypotheses 
H01: There is no statistically significant difference in body fat percentage between obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training with weights compared to 
resistance training with body weight in San Antonio. 
H02: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to age. 

81 
 
 
 
H03: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to educational attainment. 
H04: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to religion. 
H05: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to marital status. 
Participants and Setting 
Population 
This study's target population was obese African American perimenopausal women in 
San Antonio. In 2017, San Antonio’s estimated population was over 1.5 million, resulting in San 
Antonio being the second-largest city in Texas and the seventh most populous in the United 
States, which includes 63 zip codes (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). San Antonio is the only city where 
the Latino population exceeds 50% of the total populace (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). In 2017, 64% of 
the city's residents identified as Latino (Saenz & Casura, n.d.). 
Saenz and Casura (n.d) reported that women outnumber males in the city with 51% 
women to 49% men. According to the United States Census Bureau, San Antonio has 
approximately 91,000 women between the ages of 40-50 (U.S. Census Bureau, 2022a). 
Perimenopause usually starts to impact women in their 40s (Johnson, 2020); therefore, this 
study’s target population was women between the ages of 40 and 50 in San Antonio. The Texas 
Health and Human Services reports that 56.8% of women in San Antonio between the ages of 
40-50 are obese (Buendia, 2024). 

82 
 
 
 
Sampling Procedures 
The researcher solicited a sample from the population through the study’s advertisement 
flyers. The advertisement flyers were created to solicit participants and were posted at local 
gyms, local businesses, churches, Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn. Due to the lack of a clear 
definition of perimenopause and the classification based on vasomotor symptoms, individuals 
who exhibit at least three of the following seven symptoms are considered to be experiencing 
perimenopause: irregular periods, hot flashes, weight gain, poor sleep, vaginal dryness, mood 
swings, brain fog, or bladder problems (Harper et al., 2022; Johnson, 2020). To participate in this 
study, individuals had to be 40 years of age or older (Grandi et al., 2022) and obese, having a 
body mass index (BMI) greater than 30 kg/m2 (Çakmur, 2020; M. Evans et al., 2023; Luzi, 
2021). Women who were pregnant or had artificial electrical implants, such as a defibrillator or 
pacemaker, could not take an InBody Test and were therefore excluded (InBody USA, n.d.). In 
addition, women who were administered hormone replacement therapy, birth control, and 
pharmacological treatments for obesity were excluded. 
The random sampling method used to select a sample from the population was volunteer 
sampling, which is a nonrandom sampling procedure (T. Matthews & Kostelis, 2020). 
Volunteers who were interested in participating completed a survey. The survey link was on the 
advertisement flyers that were presented at local gyms, local businesses, churches, Facebook, 
Instagram, and LinkedIn. The survey asked about age, educational attainment, race, religion, 
marital status, vasomotor symptoms, weight loss medication, and hormone replacement therapy. 
All participants were offered personal training services and meal prep services at a discounted 
rate that can be redeemed after the study has concluded at the researcher’s gym. 
Sample Size 
The sample size came from San Antonio zip code 78148. In the 78148 zip code, African 

83 
 
 
 
Americans comprise 10% of the population (Neilsberg Research, 2024; The United States Postal 
Service, 2024). According to the Strategic Plan, there are approximately 448 obese women 
between the ages of 40-50. Based on this population, 106 perimenopausal women were expected 
to participate in this study. The Population Proportion calculated the sample population – Sample 
Size calculator used pre-determined levels of 5% margin of error, 95% confidence level, and 
10% sample proportion, which is typically used by studies which is demonstrated in Appendix Q 
(Hagstrom et al., 2020; Said et al., 2021; Shin et al., 2024). Seventy-nine women, ranging in age 
from under 40 to over 55, completed the intake survey to participate in the study. 
Sample Demographic 
 African Americans make up 10% of the total population for zip code 78148, equating to 
approximately 2000 people (Neilsberg Research, 2024; The United States Postal Service, 2024). 
The median age within zip code 78148 is 35.4, in accordance with the 2021 American

 Educational attainment for the population 25 years and older in zip code 78148 are as

84 
 
 
 
Americans in zip code 78148 was not available. Evidence of this study showed that out of the 79

 Data from the 2022 American Council on Education’s Race and Ethnicity in Higher

 Data from the 2022 American Council on Education’s Race and Ethnicity in Higher

According to the survey, 81% of women who completed the intake survey identified as

Protestantism has historically been the dominant religious tradition among African

Setting 
 The assigned groups, the resistance training group, and the resistance training group with 
body weight, met twice a week with a personal trainer. The resistance training group met at a 
local gym, and the resistance training group with body weight met virtually on Zoom. Each 
session lasted 30 minutes. 
All participants had their body fat percentage measured by an InBody 270 at a local gym 
prior to the training sessions. The InBody 270 measured the impedance of five body segments: 
the right arm, the left arm, the trunk, the right leg, and the left leg, with two frequencies, 20 kHz 
and 100 kHz (InBody270 User’s Manual for Measurement Guide and Setup, 2023). For the 
InBody 270 measurement, participants were required to stand barefoot on the floor electrodes 
and simultaneously hold both hand electrodes. 


88 
 
 
 
Groups 
 The participants of this study were randomly assigned into two groups: the resistance 
training group and the resistance training group with body weight group. The resistance training 
group performed exercises using dumbbells, barbells, cable pulley machines, weighted machines, 
and/or resistance bands for external resistance. Resistance training offers numerous benefits, 
such as improving several cardiovascular risk factors, including insulin resistance, glucose 
regulation, lipid metabolism, reduced body fat mass, hemoglobin A1c levels, Type 2 Diabetes, 
and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (Benitez et al., 2024; Saeidifard et al., 2019). Resistance 
training provides benefits beyond muscle hypertrophy, such as contributing to stronger bones, 
which is especially beneficial for individuals dealing with osteoporosis (Waehner, 2020). 
According to Choudhry et al. (2024), resistance training is an effective intervention 
during the perimenopausal stage for alleviating vasomotor symptoms. Resistance training 
contributes to the enhancement of muscle mass and promotes functional stability in older adults 
(Choudhry et al., 2024; Vikberg et al., 2019). This form of exercise is essential for supporting 
overall health and mobility in this population (Choudhry et al., 2024). 
The control training group performed exercises using bodyweight, focusing on functional 
strength and static stretching. Functional training is designed to enhance an individual's capacity 
to perform daily activities and thrive in professional pursuits effectively (Carr et al., 2022). This 
form of training contributes to an individual's overall cardiovascular, metabolic, and neurological 
well-being (Carr et al., 2022). Furthermore, functional training optimizes one's ability to execute 
daily tasks with vitality and attentiveness while also promoting secure engagement in 
recreational activities (Carr et al., 2022). Static stretching is the most widely recognized 
stretching technique, which involves a controlled, continuous movement that extends to the 
maximum range of motion (ROM) of one or more joints, with the muscles held in an elongated 

89 
 
 
 
position for a specified duration (Arntz et al., 2023; Nelson & Kokkonen, 2021). During static 
stretching, a specific muscle or group of muscles is extended until one notices an increase in 
tension or slight discomfort, holding that position for typically 15 to 60 seconds (Nelson & 
Kokkonen, 2021). This technique allows the muscles, fascia, ligaments, and tendons to gradually 
lengthen to increase ROM (Arntz et al., 2023; Nelson & Kokkonen, 2021). Static stretching 
enhances inherent flexibility, strength, power, and muscular endurance (Nelson & Kokkonen, 
2021). Additionally, static stretching contributes to improved mobility and the regulation of 
blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin levels (Nelson & Kokkonen, 2021). 
Group Formation 
 The groups consisted of the participants who volunteered for the study. Volunteers were 
recruited through advertisement flyers posted at local gyms, businesses, and churches and on 
social media platforms such as Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn. Next, the volunteers 
completed a survey to verify the eligibility criteria and completed a body composition analysis 
with an Inbody machine. Lastly, the researcher validated that the volunteers’ body mass index 
(BMI) was greater than 30 kg/m2, then the volunteers pulled a piece of paper from a jar which 
randomly assigned a group. The paper that had the letter ‘R’ assigned the volunteer to the 
resistance training group and the paper with the letter ‘C’, a number assigned the volunteers to 
the resistance training group with body weight group. 
Group Demographics 
 The groups consisted of African American women from the 78148 zip code. African 
Americans account for 10% of the population in zip code 78148, which is approximately 2000 
people (Neilsberg Research, 2024). The predominant demographic of women within this study 
was aged between 45 and 49, representing 7% of the total female population in 78148 (The 
United States Postal Service, 2024). Furthermore, women aged 40-44 constitute 6% of the 

90 
 
 
 
overall female cohort (The United States Postal Service, 2024). 
The resistance training group with body weight group was composed of seven 
perimenopausal African American women aged 40-50. Four of the participants were married, 
one was divorced, and two participants from the resistance training group with body weight 
group were single and never married, as indicated on Table 1. Four of the participants from the 
resistance training group with body weight group were of the Christian faith; one participant was 
of the Catholic faith; another participant identified as non-denominational, and the last 
participant from the resistance training group with body weight group identified as spiritual, as 
indicated in Table 2.
