Instrumentation 
InBody 270 
The instrument used to measure the participant's body fat was a bioelectrical impedance 
analysis (BIA) machine, the Inbody 270. In addition to measuring body fat percentage, the 
purpose of the InBody 270 machine is to measure the participants’ body composition. BIA is a 
highly effective, non-invasive, and non-intrusive device for accurately estimating body 
composition (Randhawa et al., 2021). BIA enables the evaluation of soft tissue hydration, a 
crucial component of lean soft tissue and muscle mass, as well as the integrity of an individual's 
cell membranes (Marini & Toselli, 2021). BIA is a method used to assess the impedance (Z) of 
an alternating electrical current, which relates to the presence of water and electrolytes in body 
fluids and tissues, and is commonly found in health and fitness facilities, occupational 
populations, and research studies (Randhawa et al., 2021). Additionally, BIA determines the 
delay of alternating current penetration at cell membranes and tissue interfaces, which are the 
Note. This table indicates the demographics of the resistance training with body weight 
group. 

92 
 
 
 
points of contact between neighboring tissues (Marini & Toselli, 2021). 
In 1996, the InBody was founded in South Korea by Dr. Kichul Cha (InBody270 User’s 
Manual for Measurement Guide and Setup, 2023). The InBody machine was developed to assess 
segmental and total body composition using an eight-point tactile electrode system to measure an 
individual’s body composition without relying on empirical data (Antonio et al., 2019; InBody 
USA, n.d.). The first Inbody was established in the United States in 2000 with Food and Drug 
Administration (FDA) approval (InBody USA, n.d.). The accuracy and dependability of 
bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) devices have been subject to scrutiny in previous times 
due to the utilization of a singular frequency of 50 kHz to assess body fat percentage, fat mass, 
fat-free mass, and total body water (McLester et al., 2020). Nonetheless, recent advancements in 
BIA technology have significantly improved the measurement capabilities (InBody USA, n.d.; 
McLester et al., 2020). The advances included the implementation of multiple device contact 
points, an increased number of utilized frequencies, and a higher quantity of obtained impedance 
measurements (InBody USA, n.d.; McLester et al., 2020). Hand-to-foot BIA operates by 
transmitting diverse frequencies of alternating current through the body, with each current 
traversing resistors and capacitors, thereby influencing the resultant voltage (McLester et al., 
2020). The intracellular and extracellular fluids represent the resistors, and the cell membranes 
represent the capacitors (McLester et al., 2020). Subsequently, the impedance values are 
employed to forecast several variables, encompassing body fat percentage, fat mass, fat-free 
mass, and total body water (McLester et al., 2020). 
Bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) is a device that precisely measures impedance, 
the opposition to the alternating current, by analyzing a low-level electrical current passing 
through the body (Yi et al., 2022). The InBody 270 is equipped with an 8-point tactile electrode 
system featuring overlapping voltage and current flow lines at the same point, thereby 

93 
 
 
 
establishing a secure and replicable measurement starting point for each individual (InBody270 
User’s Manual for Measurement Guide and Setup, 2023). There are eight electrodes: four foot 
electrodes and four hand electrodes that send multiple electrical currents through the body, 
resulting in up to six different impedance readings for the trunk and each of the four limbs 
(InBody270 User’s Manual for Measurement Guide and Setup, 2023). The InBody 270 assesses 
the overall body composition by measuring total body water, dry lean mass, body fat mass, and 
weight (InBody270 User’s Manual for Measurement Guide and Setup, 2023). The term "total 
body water" refers to the overall water content within the body, serving as a measure of the 
body's hydration status. " Dry lean mass" pertains to the weight of the protein and mineral 
components within the body, excluding any associated water weight that reveals how much body 
fat, both surface-level (subcutaneous) and internal (visceral), makes up one’s weight (InBody270 
User’s Manual for Measurement Guide and Setup, 2023). 
Next, the body fat percentage is measured, which indicates the proportion of fat mass in 
the person’s body (InBody270 User’s Manual for Measurement Guide and Setup, 2023). The 
weight component is precisely calculated and then directly compared to others of the same height 
and sex using percentages (InBody270 User’s Manual for Measurement Guide and Setup, 2023). 
The healthy range varies according to the calculation; the 100% mark signifies the healthy 
average for individuals of the same height and sex (InBody270 User’s Manual for Measurement 
Guide and Setup, 2023). The InBody 270 is highly regarded for its precise estimation of body 
composition, demonstrating outstanding inter-device relative and absolute reliability (Larsen et 
al., 2021). Results from multiple studies support the criterion validity and inter-device reliability 
of the Inbody 270 device in adults and children (Blue et al., 2022; Larsen et al., 2021; Yi et al., 
2022). 
Each participant completed two InBody 270 assessments: one before the intervention and 

94 
 
 
 
one after. Participants scheduled the first assessment before starting the intervention and the 
second assessment after completing the intervention. During the InBody 270 assessment, 
participants were required to stand barefoot on the device's platform with the soles of feet on the 
electrodes. The participants then held the unit's handles with thumbs and fingers to ensure direct 
contact with the electrodes. Participants stood still for approximately one minute, maintaining 
elbows fully extended and the shoulder joint abducted to approximately a 30-degree angle (See 
Appendix A for Inbody 270 and result sheets). 
Intake Survey 
The purpose of the intake survey was to gather demographic information and validate 
that the volunteers met the eligibility criteria to participate in the study (K. Matthews & Kostelis, 
2020). Tourangeau (2021) found that factual and demographic questions yield more accurate and 
reliable responses than other questions. Surveys have been documented as far back as Ancient 
Egypt (Bhattacherjee, 2019; Lavrakas, 2019). Social surveys were conducted in the United States 
starting in the 1800s; however, sociologist Paul Lazarsfeld spearheaded the common formal 
research method in the 1930s and 1940s (Bhattacherjee, 2019; Lam & Green, 2023). The 
pioneering work of sociologist Paul Lazarsfeld aimed to investigate the influence of radio on the 
formation of political opinions in the United States (Bhattacherjee, 2019). This method 
subsequently gained substantial popularity and has become widely utilized for quantitative 
research in the field of social sciences (Bhattacherjee, 2019). Several researchers report that 
surveys are valid tools for gathering participant data (Evans et al., 2021; Matthews & Kostelis, 
2020; Tourangeau, 2021). 
Volunteers interested in participating in the research completed a survey to verify 
eligibility. The survey consisted of 11 questions that gathered demographics and perimenopausal 
background information. Volunteers who had not had a menstrual cycle in the last 11 

95 
 
 
 
months, were pregnant, or had been administered hormone replacement therapy, birth control, or 
weight loss medication were excluded. The survey took less than five minutes to complete (See 
Appendix B for the survey and link). 
Dumbbells 
 Dumbbells, recognized for versatility, represent the optimal choice for this study. 
Dumbbells are an economical and multipurpose fitness tool that requires minimal space and can 
exercise the entire body effectively (Hedrick, 2020). The origins of the dumbbell can be traced 
back to ancient Greece, where a similar implement known as halteres was utilized (Hedrick, 
2020; Todd, 1995). Crafted from stone or metal, early precursors to modern-day dumbbells 
weighed between two and nine kilograms (Hedrick, 2020; Todd, 1995). Halteres featured a 
handle for easier gripping of the weights during exercise (Hedrick, 2020; Todd, 1995). While 
various ancient civilizations, including the Egyptians, Chinese, and Indians, engaged in 
resistance training, the Greeks are widely acknowledged for contributions in developing the 
forerunner of contemporary weight training equipment (Hedrick, 2020). 
Dumbbells are utilized to engage and activate various muscle groups in strength training 
and exercise routines (Sun et al., 2023). Dumbbells are compact barbells primarily designed for 
single-handed use (Stoppani, 2023). Dumbbells typically measure between eight and 12 inches in 
length, with a knurled gripping area of approximately six inches on most models (Stoppani, 
2023). While some dumbbells are crafted from solid steel with round or hexagonal ends, others 
utilize weighted plates and offer adjustable configurations to accommodate various resistance 
levels, see Appendix C to see picture of dumbbells (Stoppani, 2023). Dumbbells have been used 
in multiple studies, proving to be effective and reliable (Herda & Nabavizadeh, 2021; 
Saeterbakken et al., 2020; Solstad et al., 2020; S. Sun et al., 2023). The purpose of this 
instrument is to add resistance to the exercises. Exercises that will be performed using dumbbells 

96 
 
 
 
are squats, deadlifts, bench press, bicep curls, triceps extension, calf raises, and shoulder press. 
 To perform squats, the participant did the following: 
1. Set feet about shoulder-width apart and pointed the toes out just slightly. 
2. Held a dumbbell in each hand and gazed straight forward. Stood tall pulled the shoulder 
blades down and back away from one’s ears. 
3. Engaged core then unlocked the knees and hips and slowly descended to sit back into the 
heels. 
4. Lastly pushed with legs, while kept a big chest and standing tall returned to starting 
position and repeated. 
Each participant who performed this exercise completed 12-15 repetitions for three sets 
with 30 seconds rest between sets. This exercise will take approximately three minutes (See 
Appendix C for the dumbbell squats demonstration). 
To perform deadlifts, the participant did the following: 
1. Held a dumbbell in each hand with arms fully straight at one’s side. 
2. Stood with feet shoulder-width apart. 
3. Kept knees slightly bent. 
4. Arched back, lifted head, and maintained this position throughout the exercise. 
5. Hinged at the hips and slid the dumbbells down the sides of the legs, keeping knees 
slightly bent. 
6. Returned to the starting position while maintaining the position of knees and back, 
and repeated. 
Each participant who performed this exercise completed 12-15 reps for three sets with 30 
30-second rest between sets. This exercise took approximately three minutes ( See Appendix C 
for the dumbbell deadlift demonstration). 

97 
 
 
 
To perform a bench press, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Laid flat on an exercise bench with back and place feet flat on the floor or the bench. 
2. Held the dumbbells at chest height with arms bent. 
3. Pressed both dumbbells up simultaneously until arms were fully extended directly 
above the shoulders. 
4. Lowered the dumbbells under control back to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant who performed this exercise completed 12-15 repetitions for three sets 
with 30 seconds rested between sets. This exercise took approximately three minutes (See 
Appendix C for the dumbbell bench press demonstration). 
To perform bicep curls, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Held dumbbells with palms up. 
2. Extended arms to thigh height. 
3. Curled arms to shoulder height. 
4. Lowered dumbbells to start position and repeated. 
Each participant who performed this exercise completed 12-15 repetitions for three sets 
with 30 seconds rested between sets. This exercise will take approximately three minutes (See 
Appendix C for the dumbbell bicep curl demonstration). 
To perform triceps extension, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Turned the dumbbell sideways and held the dumbbell with both hands. 
2. Raised the dumbbell directly over the head. Arms were fully extended upwards while 
the dumbbell was above the head. 
3. Lowered the dumbbell behind the head by bending the elbows. 
4. Extended the elbows to return to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant who performed this exercise completed 12-15 repetitions for three sets 

98 
 
 
 
with 30 seconds rest between sets. This exercise took approximately three minutes (See 
Appendix C for the dumbbell triceps extension demonstration). 
To perform shoulder press, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Held the dumbbells at the shoulders with palms forward and elbows pointing down. 
2. Pressed the dumbbells straight up until the elbows were fully extended. 
3. Avoided leaning back and kept shoulders directly over hips at the top. 
4. Paused for one count, then lowered dumbbells under control to start position and 
repeated. 
Each participant who performed this exercise completed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 
seconds rest between sets. This exercise took approximately three minutes (See Appendix C for 
dumbbell shoulder press demonstration). 
 To perform calf raises, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Stood with the torso upright holding two dumbbells in each hand by each side of the 
body. This was the starting position. 
2. Ensured the toes were pointing straight ahead. While holding a dumbbell in each 
hand, raised the heels as high as possible by pushing through the balls of the feet and 
toes, simultaneously extended the ankles. 
3. Lowered heels back on the ground to return to the starting position, then repeated. 
Each participant who performed this exercise completed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 
seconds rest between sets. This exercise took approximately three minutes (See Appendix C for 
the dumbbell calf raise demonstration). 
Barbells 
Barbells are essential for performing multi-joint exercises that closely resemble the 
movements used in sports and everyday life (Malorgio et al., 2021; Solstad et al., 2020). In 1861, 

99 
 
 
 
Thomas Wentworth first mentioned barbells in an article for the prestigious Atlantic Monthly 
titled "Gymnastics" (Todd, 1995). The barbell first appeared in an illustration in 1854, which 
was an illustration of Triat’s gym included in French historian Edmund Desbonnet’s Les Rois de 
la Force (Todd, 1995). Around 1890, a man commonly referred to as “The Strongest Man,” 
Eugene Sandow, began selling barbells and dumbbells, earning $1,000 a week (Schwarzenegger 
& Dobbins, 1998). In 1928, Kaspar Berg introduced the inaugural "modern" Olympic barbell 
model (Todd, 1995). The Olympic barbell made a debut at the Olympic Games in Amsterdam in 
1928 and subsequently became the subject of replication by the York Barbell Company, the 
Jackson Barbell Company, and other manufacturers throughout the twentieth century (Todd, 
1995). 
Barbells typically range in length from five to seven feet, see Appendix D to see photo of 
barbells (Stoppani, 2023). Barbells were used to perform squats, deadlifts, bench presses, bicep 
curls, calf raises, and shoulder press. Barbells have been used in multiple studies, proving to be 
effective and reliable (Gentil et al., 2020; Saeterbakken et al., 2020; Schütz et al., 2022; Solstad 
et al., 2020). The purpose of this instrument is to add resistance to the exercises. 
To perform barbell squat, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Ensured the barbell was positioned on the upper trapezius muscles. Maintained an 
upright chest and forward-facing head position. Kept feet turned outward and at a hip-
width stance. This was the starting position. 
2. The exercise began by lowering the body through flexion of the knees, minimizing 
backward movement of the hips. This required forward movement of the knees, as 
well as being ensured the knees was in alignment with the feet. 
3. Lowered the body by bending the knees and hips, like sitting in a chair until thighs 
were parallel to the ground. 

100 
 
 
 
4. Drove the knees outward (away from each other) and squeezed the butt at the top to 
ensure the glutes are engaged. Returned to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix D for the barbell squats 
demonstration). 
To perform barbell bench press, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Laid on a flat bench with feet on the floor or on the bench to maintain balance. 
2. Grasped the bar with a medium-wide grip and lifted the bar off the rack, extending 
arms above the chest. This was the starting position. 
3. Lowered the bar in a controlled manner until the bar touched just below the pectoral 
muscles, keeping the elbows pointed outward to engage the chest muscles fully. 
4. Paused briefly when the bar touched the chest, then pressed the bar upward until the 
arms were fully extended, returning to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 reps for three sets with 30 seconds of rest between sets, 
which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix D for the barbell bench press 
demonstration). 
To perform barbell deadlift, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Placed a barbell on the floor in front of the body. 
2. Had a slight bend of the knees, leaned forward, and gripped the bar with hands in a 
medium-wide grip, ensuring that one hand was in an overhand grip and the other in 
an underhand grip. Kept the back reasonably straight to prevent a strain. This was the 
starting position. 
3. Lifted the barbell by driving with the legs, stood upright, pushed the chest out, and 
rolled the shoulders back. 

101 
 
 
 
4. To lower the weight back down, bent the knees, then leaned forward from the waist, 
gently touched the weight to the floor and returned to the starting position, and 
repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 reps for three sets with 60 seconds of rest between sets, 
which took approximately five minutes (See Appendix D for the barbell deadlift demonstration). 
To perform bicep curls, the participants followed the following steps: 
1. Held barbell with palms up with slightly wider than hip-width. 
2. Stood upright with the barbell resting on the thighs, then squeezed the bar which 
activated the muscles. This was the starting position. 
3. Curled arms to shoulder height without leaning back. 
4. Lowered barbell to start position, and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix D for the barbell bicep 
curl demonstration). 
 To perform shoulder press, the participant followed the following steps: 
1. Stood with feet shoulder-width apart. Held the barbell in front of the body, while the 
barbell rested on the front of the shoulders with the elbows pointing forward and 
hands shoulder-width apart. This was the starting position. 
2. Tightened core, with palms facing forward, raised the barbell to chest level. 
3. Lifted the bar up over the head by locking the arms. 
4. Slowly lowered the bar down to the shoulders to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix D for the barbell shoulder 
press demonstration). 

102 
 
 
 
To perform calf raises, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Ensured the barbell was positioned on the upper trapezius muscles, with the toes 
facing forward. This was the starting position. 
2. Raised both heels and contracted the calves on each leg. 
3. Gradually returned to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix D for the barbell calf raise 
demonstration). 
Leg Extension Machine 
 There are two types of leg movement exercises that are considered antagonistic: the leg 
curl and the leg extension (Botta et al., 2020; Souza et al., 2020). The leg extension exercise is 
widely regarded as the top choice for isolating and strengthening the quadriceps femoris by 
flexion and extension of the knee (Mitsuya et al., 2023; Shiao & Hoang, 2022). The machine was 
created by Jack LaLanne in the 1950s (Albert, 2024). To use a leg extension machine the back 
pad must be adjusted so that when the participant is seated, knees must align with the machine’s 
axis of rotation, and the shin pad will be placed on the shins with light pressure (Cybex 
International, Inc., 2013). The participant will push leg forward against the pad until legs are 
straight in front, see Appendix E for photo of leg extension (Cybex International, Inc., 2013). 
Leg extension machines have been used in multiple studies, proving to be effective and reliable 
(Mitsuya et al., 2023; Shiao & Hoang, 2022; Souza et al., 2020). The purpose of this instrument 
is to add resistance to leg exercises. 
To use the leg extension machine correctly, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Set up the machine so the pad was at the top of the lower legs at the ankles, with knees at 
90 degrees. This was the starting position. 

103 
 
 
 
2. Placed hands on the hand bars. 
3. Lifted the weight while exhaling until the legs were almost straight, but did not lock 
the knees. 
4. Slowly returned to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest between 
sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix E for a picture of the leg extension 
demonstration). 
Seated Leg Curl Machine 
 The leg curl machine targets a single joint, the hamstring muscle (Marinho et al., 2023; 
Ribeiro et al., 2020). Historical data on the leg curl invention is not available. Ribeiro et al. 
(2020) found that leg curls enhance functional performance (see Appendix E for photo of leg 
curl machine.) To use the leg curl machine, the participants followed the following steps: 
1. Adjusted the back pad so the knees were aligned with the machine’s axis of rotation. 
2. Ensured the leg pad was comfortable behind the ankles and the thigh pad was snug. This 
was the starting position. 
3. The participant pushed legs down until the feet were below the seat. 
4. Slowly returned to the starting position and repeated. 
 
Leg curl machines have been used in multiple studies, proving to be effective and reliable 
(Botta et al., 2020; Otsuka et al., 2022; Testa, 2021). The purpose of this instrument is to add 
resistance to leg exercises. Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 
seconds of rest between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix E for a 
picture of the leg curl demonstration). 

104 
 
 
 
Cable Pulley Machine 
 Cable pulley machines are exercise machines that use a simple system of cables and 
pulleys (Stoppani, 2023). In the most basic form, the cable pulley consists of a cable that routes 
through one or more pulleys and connects to a weight stack (Stoppani, 2023). Pulleys comprise a 
wheel that revolves on an axle and a rope, chain, or cable that traverses a groove on the wheel 
(Machut, 2020; Stoppani, 2023). The wheel and axle materials encompass wood, metal, or 
plastic. The sizing of the wheel is contingent upon the intended location and function of the 
pulley (Machut, 2020). Nunes et al. (2020) provided evidence that cable pulley machines provide 
similar results for strength and hypertrophy as barbells. 
The cable pulley system offers a diverse array of exercise options that can be easily 
adapted to suit individual preferences and specific requirements (Schütz et al., 2022). There are 
five types of pulleys: the fixed pulley, the movable pulley, the compound pulley, the block-and-
tackle pulley, and the cone pulley (Machut, 2020). Cable pulley machines have been used in 
multiple studies proving to be effective and reliable (Botta et al., 2020; Isenmann et al., 2023; 
Schütz et al., 2022). The purpose of this instrument is to add resistance to exercises. Exercises 
that will be performed with the cable pulley machine are squats, bench press, bicep curls, 
latissimus pulldown, tricep extension, and shoulder press (See Appendix F for a picture of a 
cable pulley machine). 
To perform squats, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Gripped a cable rope in each hand. Stood away from the cable machine so that the 
slack tightened. 
2. Kept back straight and the core tight, this is the starting position. 
3. Bent the knees and drove the hips back while keeping the chest up. 
4. Stood back up, kept the back muscles tight, then returned the handles to the starting 

105 
 
 
 
position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix F for a picture of the cable 
pulley squat demonstration). 
To perform bench press, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Positioned a bench between two low cable pulleys. 
2. Laid on the bench, grabbed a handle with each hand, placed feet on the floor or the 
bench, and slightly arched the back. This was the starting position. 
3. Positioned the handles to the sides of the chest. 
4. Extended the arms toward the ceiling and contracted the chest muscles. Ensured not 
to lock out at the top of the movement. 
5. Held the position for a couple of seconds. 
6. Returned to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix F for a picture of the cable 
pulley bench press demonstration). 
To perform bicep curls, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Stood in front of the cable machine, ensured that a short bar attachment was affixed to 
a low pulley. 
2. Grasped the handle with an underhand grip, kept the palms facing upward. This was 
the starting position. 
3. Kept the elbows in close proximity to the body while curling the weight upwards 
towards the shoulders. 
4. At the peak of the movement, briefly paused before gradually returning the weight to 

106 
 
 
 
its starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix F for a picture of the cable 
pulley bicep curl demonstration). 
To perform latissimus pulldown, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Secured a straight bar handle to the highest notch on the cable machine. 
2. Stood in front of the machine with feet approximately hip-width apart, and grasped 
the bar with both hands using an overhand grip. This is the starting position. 
3. Took a step backward from the machine to allow the arms to move up and down in 
front of the body. 
4. Gently leaned forward at the hips, elevated the chest, engaged the lats, and 
maintained a tight core. 
5. With the arms extended, utilized the lats to lower the bar until the hands are 
positioned in front of the thighs. 
6. Slowly reversed the movement until the arms was parallel to the floor, to returned to 
the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix F for a picture of the 
latissimus pulldown demonstration). 
To perform cable tricep extension, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Set the height of the cable pulley slightly above head level and affix a rope handle to 
the end of the cable. 
2. Stood facing away from the cable pulley machine, maintaining a distance of about 
two feet. Grasped the rope handle, ensured that each hand held the rope at the base, 

107 
 
 
 
and raised hands to the level of the forehead while keeping the elbows aligned with 
the hands. This was the starting position. 
3. Extended arms aligned with the cable, then extended the elbows into the contracted 
position. Returned to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix F for a picture of the cable 
tricep extension demonstration). 
To perform cable shoulder press, participants must follow the following steps: 
1. Moved the cables to the bottom of the towers and selected an appropriate weight. 
2. Stood directly in between the cable pulley upright. Grasped the cables and held the 
handles at shoulder height, palms faced forward. This was the starting position. 
3. Kept the head and chest up, extended through the elbow to press the handles directly 
overhead. 
4. After a pause at the top, returned to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix F for a picture of the cable 
shoulder press demonstration). 
Smith Machine 
 The Smith machine features a barbell that moves vertically along two guiding rods, 
ensuring stability and control during exercises (Stoppani, 2023). Safety catches are incorporated 
at multiple points along the machine to allow users to commence or cease the exercise at any 
desired position, enhancing both safety and versatility (Stoppani, 2023). One advantage of 
utilizing a Smith machine is that the bar follows a fixed path, requiring minimal balance from the 
lifter (Schick et al., 2010). According to Schicker et al. (2010), Smith machines are favored by 

108 
 
 
 
individuals engaged in rehabilitation, novice practitioners, and both younger and older trainees. 
Moreover, Smith machines are highly regarded by experienced lifters seeking to achieve 
maximum fatigue at the
sections.conclusion:
of a workout regimen (Schick et al., 2010). Smith machines 
have been used in multiple studies proving to be effective and reliable (Miras-Moreno et al., 
2023; Qu et al., 2024; Saeterbakken et al., 2020). The purpose of this instrument is to add 
resistance to exercises. Exercises that were performed with the Smith machine were squats, 
deadlifts, calf raises, bench press, and shoulder press (See Appendix G for a picture of a Smith 
machine). 
 To perform Smith machine squats, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Adjusted the height of the machine bar to be aligned with the shoulders. 
2. Positioned the body with feet shoulder-width apart directly beneath the bar, allowing 
the bar to rest on the trapezius muscles. Secured an overhand grip on the bar with 
palms facing outward. 
3. Released the bar by turning the bar backward to adjust the feet to a comfortable 
width and angle. Engaged the core muscles, maintained an upright torso, and 
preserved a natural arch in the lower back. This was the starting position. 
4. Ensured one’s body weight was in the heels and initiated the squat by pushing the 
hips back. 
5. Lowered the body by bending the knees until the thighs were parallel to the floor, 
ensuring that the chest remained elevated, weight was distributed to the heels, and 
toes remained grounded. 
6. Returned to a starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix G for a picture of the 

109 
 
 
 
Smith machine squat demonstration). 
To perform the Smith machine deadlift, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Set the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height around the middle of the tibia. 
2. Stood in front of the bar with the feet shoulder-width apart. 
3. Bent down to grip the barbell with an overhand grip. This was the starting position. 
4. Engaged the core and kept the back straight. 
5. Drove feet into the floor and used the legs to lift the weight up, pushed the hips 
forward. Returned to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 60 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately five minutes (See Appendix G for a picture of the Smith 
machine squat demonstration). 
To perform Smith machine calf raises, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Adjusted the Smith Machine's barbell to a height approximately level with the 
shoulders. 
2. Positioned oneself underneath the barbell so that the bar was resting on the upper 
traps and shoulders. 
3. Maintained a shoulder-width stance with the feet parallel to each other. 
4. Secured a wide grip on the bar and place the bar across the top of the trapezius 
muscles. This was the starting position. 
5. Engaged the core muscles, which promoted stability during the exercise. 
6. Pressure was applied through the balls of both feet, which raised the body upward. 
7. Elevated the heels as high as possible, which fully extended the ankles and contracted 
the calf muscle. 
8. Gradually lower the heels to the starting position and repeated. 

110 
 
 
 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix G for a picture of the 
demonstration of the Smith machine calf raises). 
To perform the Smith machine bench press, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Positioned oneself on the bench and pulled the shoulder blades together and 
downward, while be sure the chest is maintained upright. 
2. Held the bar with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. This was the 
starting position. 
3. Lowered the bar in a controlled manner until the bar made contact with the chest. 
4. Pushed the bar upwards to return to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix G for a picture of the 
Smith machine bench press demonstration). 
To perform the Smith machine shoulder press, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Set up the Smith machine with an upright bench. 
2. Sat and lifted the bar off the safety stops. 
3. Lowered the bar to chin level. This was the starting position. 
4. Pressed the bar up until the arms were almost fully extended and returned the bar to 
the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix G for a picture of the 
Smith machine shoulder press demonstration). 
Resistance Bands 
 Resistance bands offer a viable alternative to conventional resistance training equipment 

111 
 
 
 
(Gaamouri et al., 2023). Additionally, the bands can be integrated with free weights to deliver 
both isotonic resistance and linear variable resistance from the bands (Stoppani, 2023). 
Resistance bands are similar to springs as the resistance increases with lengthening (Page & 
Ellenbecker, 2020; Stoppani, 2023). The resistance offered by the bands provides a gradual 
stimulus to the muscles, fostering strength development and contributing to increased muscle 
mass (Page & Ellenbecker, 2020). With resistance band training, individuals can engage single 
or multiple joints simultaneously, leading to more functional and efficient exercises (Page & 
Ellenbecker, 2020). Resistance band training is highly versatile and offers accessibility for 
resistance training, introducing a range of benefits such as accommodating resistance, enhancing 
joint stability, isolated training, rehabilitative training, functional training, and increasing muscle 
activation, see Appendix H to see photo of resistance bands (Hammami & Zmijewski, 2024; 
Page & Ellenbecker, 2020). Resistance bands have been used in multiple studies, proving to be 
effective and reliable (Gaamouri et al., 2023; Hammami & Zmijewski, 2024; Herda & 
Nabavizadeh, 2021; Page & Ellenbecker, 2020). The purpose of this instrument is to add 
resistance to exercises. Exercises that were performed with resistance bands were leg curls, bicep 
curls, tricep extensions, and shoulder press (See Appendix H for a picture of resistance bands). 
 To perform resistance band leg curls, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Ensured the resistance band was secure around a sturdy object. 
2. Sat in front of the band and placed the loop around the ankles. This was the starting 
position. 
3. Kept the feet together and bent the knees then pulled the heels back. 
4. Stopped when the heels could not move back any further. Returned to the starting 
position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest 

112 
 
 
 
between sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix H for a picture of the 
resistance band leg curl demonstration). 
To perform resistance band bicep curls, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Positioned oneself on the resistance band with both feet, then grasped the handles 
adjacent to the torso with palms oriented forward. This was the starting position. 
2. Gradually elevated the hands towards the shoulders, exerting pressure on the biceps 
while keeping the elbows near the sides. 
3. Slowly returned the arms to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest between 
sets, which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix H for a picture of the resistance 
band bicep curl demonstration). 
To perform resistance band tricep extension, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Positioned the band on the floor and aligned the band's midpoint with the body's 
midpoint. 
2. Stepped onto the band with a stance the width of the shoulders. 
3. Grasped the bands behind the head and ensured the elbows were leveled with the 
ears. This was the starting position. 
4. Using only the forearms, the force was exerted to lift the band by flexing the triceps 
and extended the elbow near lockout. 
5. Maintained a slight bend in the elbows and contracted the triceps. 
6. Reversed the motion to return to the starting position and repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets with 30 seconds of rest between sets, 
which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix H for a picture of the resistance band 
tricep extension demonstration). 

113 
 
 
 
 To perform resistance band shoulder press, participants followed the following steps: 
1. Stood with both feet at hip-width apart in the center of the band. 
2. Held the band’s handles above the shoulders with the elbows bent at 90 degrees. This 
was the starting position. 
3. Pushed arms straight up and kept the shoulders down. 
4. Slowly lowered the arms back to the starting position above the shoulders and 
repeated. 
Each participant performed 12-15 repetitions for three sets, with 30 seconds of rest between sets, 
which took approximately three minutes (See Appendix H for a picture of the resistance band 
shoulder press demonstration). 
Operationalization of Constructs 
 The replicability of a scientific finding is crucial for establishing credibility (Haucke et 
al., 2021). Replicability is the ability to obtain consistent results across studies that are designed 
to answer the same scientific question, each of which has its own dataset (Committee on 
Reproducibility and Replicability in Science et al., 2019). According to Frikha and Telulier 
(2019), a significant challenge in research involves aligning the measurement with the object 
under investigation. Operationalization is the procedure of rendering a theoretical construct 
tangible, enabling the study through empirical observations (Haucke et al., 2021). Questionnaires 
and surveys are frequently used as tools for gathering information to comprehend a wide range 
of objects and abstract concepts systematically (Frikha & Teulier, 2019). See Table 3 for the 
intake survey scale.

shoulder press received a value of three. Exercises that used the Smith machine, squats, deadlifts, 
calf raises, bench presses, and shoulder presses will receive a value of four. Exercises that used 
resistance bands; leg curls, bicep curls, tricep extensions, and shoulder press received a value of 
five. Lastly, the leg curl machine that was used to perform leg curls received the value of six 
(See Table 4 for the exercise equipment scale).

Procedures 
 After obtaining permission from the Liberty University Institutional Review Board 
(IRB), advertisement flyers were used to solicit participants (See Appendix K for IRB approval). 
The flyers included the name of the study, the reason for the study, a brief explanation of 
procedures, the study's benefits, the volunteer’s qualifications, and the researcher's name and 
email (see Appendix P). The flyer had a link to a survey that had questions to validate 
participants' eligibility. The survey had questions regarding age, educational attainment, race, 
religion, marital status, vasomotor symptoms, weight loss medication, birth control, hormone 
replacement therapy, current resistance training routine, and availability to participate two times 
a week, which met the World Health Organization (WHO) resistance training 2020 guidelines 
(Bull et al., 2020). Compensation for participants was discounted for personal training services 
that could be redeemed after the study at the researcher’s privately owned gym and/or free 
shipping on prepared meals from the researcher’s meal prep company. The flyer was posted at 
local gyms, local businesses, churches, Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn ( See Appendix M 
for a copy of the letter indicating the advertising authorization). 
 Once the volunteers were vetted to participate, an InBody test was scheduled with the 
researcher to document the pre-intervention body fat percentage and body mass index (See 
Appendix A for an Inbody test result sheet). Volunteers with BMI less than 30kg/m2 were 
ineligible to participate in the research. The BMI categories for adults are as indicated in Table 5.

Volunteers with a BMI > 30 kg/m2 was given a research participation consent form to 
read and sign. A copy of the consent form can be viewed in Appendix L. Next, random 
allocation was used to determine which participants would be in the resistance training group or 
the resistance training group with body weight group. Random allocation is a methodology that 
involves the selection of individuals for treatment and resistance training group with body weight 
groups through a completely random process, without consideration for the preferences or 
conditions of researchers (J. Kim & Shin, 2014). Once the InBody test was completed, the 
volunteer pulled a piece of paper from a jar which randomly assigned the participant to a group. 
The paper that had the letter ‘R’ assigned the volunteer to the resistance training group and the 
paper with the letter ‘C’, a number assigned the volunteers to the resistance training group with 
body weight group. Next, the researcher then provided a schedule for the group assigned (See 
Appendix N for a copy of the groups’ workout schedule). 
 The resistance training group participated in exercises that targeted the upper and lower 
body at a low-to-moderate intensity, which will prevent arterial stiffness (Jung et al., 2023). 
Lower-body training involved exercises that targeted muscles at or below the hips, while upper-
body training consisted of exercises for muscles above the hip level (Jung et al., 2023). This 
Note. This table identified the Body Mass Index categories. Scale was taken from the 
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). 

119 
 
 
 
study’s lower body exercises were leg extensions, leg curls, squats, deadlifts, and calf raises. The 
upper body exercises used in this study were bench press, bicep curls, latissimus pulldown, tricep 
extension, and shoulder press. A leg extension machine was used to perform leg extensions. A 
leg curl machine or resistance bands were used to perform leg curls. Each participant in the 
resistance training group had an option of dumbbells, barbells, a Smith machine, a cable pulley, 
or a resistance band to perform shoulder press. Each participant in the resistance training group 
had an option of dumbbells, barbells, a Smith machine, or a cable pulley to perform squats and 
bench presses. Each participant in the resistance training group had an option of dumbbells, 
barbells, cable pulley, or resistance bands to perform bicep curls. Each participant in the 
resistance training group had an option of dumbbells, barbells, or a Smith machine to perform 
deadlifts or calf raises. Each participant in the resistance training group had an option of 
dumbbells, cable pulleys, or resistance bands to perform tricep extensions. Each participant in 
the resistance training group used the cable pulley to perform latissimus pulldown. Each 
participant in the resistant group met with a personal trainer twice a week for six weeks and 
performed each exercise with resistance for three sets and 12-15 repetitions at a low-to-moderate 
intensity while resting 30 seconds in between sets to meet the American College of Sports 
Medicine’s (ACSM) recommendation for increased local muscular endurance (Haff et al., 2016; 
Kenney et al., 2022). 
 While the resistance training group performed each exercise, the researcher documented 
which instrument each participant used to conduct the workout on a data collection form. Each 
instrument had a value assigned. Individual entities or objects represented by a variable can be 
summarized and analyzed using statistics when assigned numerical values (Riffe et al., 2024). 
The values assigned to the instruments were dumbbells =1, barbell = 2, cable pulley =3, smith 
machine =4, resistance bands =5, and leg curl machine = 6. Measurement failure results in 

120 
 
 
 
unreliable data, leading to inaccurate conclusions and significant resource wastage (Riffe et al., 
2024). See Appendix O for the data collection form that was used to document the instruments 
the participants use to perform each exercise. The data collection form included the participant’s 
name, pseudo number, body fat percentage measured by the Inbody 270, and the exercises. 
 Functional strength and stretching training comprises exercises designed to facilitate the 
performance of daily activities with greater ease (Carr et al., 2022; Keiner et al., 2022). The 
exercises engage multiple muscle groups and place particular emphasis on enhancing core 
stability (Carr et al., 2022; Keiner et al., 2022). The bodyweight functional exercises that were 
performed were single-leg glute bridge, squats, push-ups, planks with shoulder taps, walking 
jacks, and dips. Based on the physical activity guidelines for Americans, each participant in the 
resistance training group with body weight group performed each exercise using only body 
weight for three sets, with 12-15 repetitions and resting for 30 seconds in between each set for all 
functional exercises (Haff et al., 2016; Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans 2nd Ed., 
2018). The stretching exercises performed were 90/90 hip stretch, single-leg supine leg raises, T-
spine rotation, and the world’s greatest stretch. Each stretch was held for 20 seconds. The 
resistance training group with body weight group participants met with a personal trainer twice a 
week for virtual workout sessions (See Appendix I for the groups’ workout protocol). 
Data Analysis 
This study investigated how resistance training impacts body fat percentage in obese 
perimenopausal African American women. The data was analyzed using the Mann-Whitney U-
Test. The Mann-Whitney U-Test was selected for several reasons, such as comparing two 
samples from the same population (Beatty, 2018; Kim, 2019; MacFarland & Yates, 2016). 
Secondly, when a measurement or observation has been recorded, the measurement or 

121 
 
 
 
observation should be specific to a particular participant within the sample (Vierra et al., 2023). 
Lastly, this method is reliant on hypothesis testing (Kim, 2019). 
The Mann-Whitney U-test was used to determine if there was a significant difference in 
body fat percentage between the resistance training group using weights and the resistance 
training group using body weight. The Mann-Whitney U-Test was used to analyze each of the 
research questions. The Mann-Whitney U-test was chosen for its robustness to outliers and 
versatility, as this method only requires the order of observations (Field, 2018; K. Kim, 2019). 
The analysis of the Mann-Whitney U test was conducted using SPSS (Statistical Package for the 
Social Sciences), also recognized as IBM SPSS Statistics, a software package designed for the 
statistical analysis of data (Field, 2018). 
The Mann-Whitney test was used for RQ1 and RQ2; however, this test was not 
appropriate for RQ3- RQ5. The Mann-Whitney test requires variables to be continuous, meaning 
they should be numeric values that can take any value within a specified interval (Vierra et al., 
2023). The educational attainment, religion, and marital status variables were not continuous 
therefore, the one-way Multivariate Analysis of Variance (MANOVA) was performed to analyze 
the data. Next, identification of outliers occurred, as the presence of extreme values holds 
significance in research due to potential distortion in statistical analyses. The histogram in Figure 
5 shows the participants’ pre-body fat; there were no extreme values.

The alpha level was set at .05 (Collins & Watt, 2021; Thomas et al., 2015). The alpha 
level (α), denoting a selected probability level, is determined by the researcher to establish the 
threshold for rejecting the null hypothesis H0 (Willard, 2020). This threshold is commonly set at 
.05 or .01, and occasionally at .001 (Collins & Watt, 2021; J. R. Thomas et al., 2015; Willard, 
2020). Moreover, the alpha level delineates the inception of the critical region in hypothesis 
testing (Willard, 2020). 
Effect size is a quantitative measure that indicates the strength or magnitude of the 
relationship between variables in research (Berry et al., 2018; Field, 2018). This metric 
determines the meaningfulness of a result beyond mere statistical significance (Berry et al., 
2018; Field, 2018). There are several different methods used to calculate the effect size, the 
methods used in this study were the rank-biserial correlation (r) and partial Eta Squared. 


123 
 
 
 
While a p-value indicates whether an effect exists, effect size conveys how strong that 
effect is (Berry et al., 2018; Field, 2018). When using the Mann-Whitney test to calculate the 
effect size it is taken from the z-score for test statistic known as the rank-biserial correlation (r) 
(Berry et al., 2018; Field, 2018). The rank-biserial correlation (r) was used for RQ1. The 
remaining research questions used the MANOVA to analyze the data; therefore, partial Eta 
Squared was used to determine the effect size (Field, 2018). 
 

124 
 
 
 
CHAPTER FOUR: FINDINGS 
Overview 
The aim of this randomized controlled trial was to examine the effects of resistance 
training on body fat among obese perimenopausal African American women residing in San 
Antonio, Texas. The study was designed to explore how structured resistance exercises could 
influence body composition during a critical period of hormonal and metabolic changes. Chapter 
four provides an analysis, including the research questions that guided the study, the hypotheses 
tested, a summary of descriptive statistics outlining the sample characteristics, and a presentation 
of the findings, highlighting the statistical outcomes and the implications. 
Research Questions 
RQ1: How does resistance training with weights compare to resistance training with 
body weight impact body fat percentage in obese African American perimenopausal women in 
San Antonio? 
 RQ2: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to age? 
RQ3: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to education attainment? 
 RQ4: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to religion? 
RQ5: How does resistance training impact obese African American perimenopausal 
women's body fat percentage in San Antonio according to marital status? 

125 
 
 
 
Null Hypotheses 
H01: There is no statistically significant difference in body fat percentage between obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training with weights compared to 
resistance training with body weight in San Antonio. 
H02: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to age. 
H03: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to education attainment. 
H04: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to religion. 
H05: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to marital status. 
Descriptive Statistics 
 A total of 11 obese perimenopausal African American women met the criteria and 
participated in this study. The average age of the participants was 46.73 years SD= 4.002, 
indicating most participants’ ages fell in the age range of perimenopause of 40-50 years (Conklin 
et al., 2024). However, only eight women completed the six-week workout sessions; therefore, 
the post-body fat percentage data are available for eight participants. The participants were 
assigned to one of two groups n=11 SD=.522: resistance training with weights n=5 and 
resistance training with body weight n=6. Pre-body fat percentages range from 32.0% to 52.1%, 

126 
 
 
 
with a mean of 41.96% SD = 7.18%. The data demonstrate moderate variability in initial body 
fat levels. Post-body fat percentages, available for 8 participants, range from 30.9% to 50.5%. 
The mean percentage is 39.23% SD = 7.36%, suggesting a reduction in body fat levels compared 
to pre-study measurements. The statistics provide a snapshot of participant characteristics and 
changes in body fat percentage, which served as a foundation for further analysis and 
interpretation in the study. The descriptive statistics are reported in Table 6.

Results 
Assumption Tests 
 Assumption test in research is the process of verifying whether the fundamental 
assumptions underlying a study are valid (Field, 2018). Many statistical analyses rely on certain 
assumptions about the data, and violating the assumptions can lead to incorrect conclusions 
(Field, 2018). The statistical test proposed to use in this study was the Mann-Whitney test. Since 
the Mann-Whitney U test is non-parametric, this test does not assume normality, which omits the 
need for an assumption test regarding normality in the testing parameters (Vierra et al., 2023). 
However, this study also used one-way MANOVA in addition to the Mann-Whitney test. The 
assumption test used was the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to test the hypothesis that the one-way 
MANOVA analyzed. The Kolmogorov-Smirnov test showed p = .200, with no statistical 
significance (see Table 11). 

127 
 
 
 
Alpha Level 
The alpha level (α) is a probability threshold set by the researcher to determine when to 
reject the null hypothesis H01 (Collins & Watt, 2021; Thomas et al., 2015). Additionally, the 
alpha level defines the beginning of the critical region in hypothesis testing (Willard, 2020). 
There are two types of errors that can occur when testing hypotheses: Type I error and Type II 
error. A Type I error, also known as a false positive, happens when the null hypothesis is 
incorrectly rejected, even though it is actually true (Collins & Watt, 2021; Field, 2018). This 
implies that one may mistakenly conclude that an effect exists when it does not (Field, 2018). 
The probability of making a Type I error is represented by alpha (α), often set at 0.05, meaning a 
5% chance of rejecting a true null hypothesis (Collins & Watt, 2021; Field, 2018). A Type II 
error, commonly referred to as a false negative, occurs when the null hypothesis is erroneously 
accepted despite being false (Collins & Watt, 2021; Field, 2018). Type II error results in the 
failure to detect a genuine effect (Field, 2018). The likelihood of committing a Type II error is 
denoted by the symbol beta (β) and is contingent upon several factors, including sample size and 
effect size (Collins & Watt, 2021; Field, 2018). The alpha level of .05 was used to represent the 
maximum acceptable probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis, indicating a 5% probability 
of making a Type I error, which occurs when the null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected despite 
being true (Field, 2018). For this study, all research questions were evaluated using an alpha 
level of .05. 
Effect Size 
Effect size is an important quantitative measure that reflects the strength or magnitude of 
the relationship between variables in research (Berry et al., 2018; Field, 2018). The metric is 
essential for evaluating the significance of results, offering insights that extend well beyond mere 
statistical significance (Berry et al., 2018; Field, 2018). A large effect size indicates a meaningful 

128 
 
 
 
difference or strong relationship, while a small effect size suggests the difference or relationship 
is minor, even if it's statistically significant (Berry et al., 2018; Field, 2018). There are several 
different methods used to calculate the effect size; the methods used in this study were the rank-
biserial correlation (r) and partial Eta Squared. 
When using the Mann-Whitney U test to calculate the effect size, it is taken from the z-
score for the test statistic known as the rank-biserial correlation (r) (Hedrih & Hedrih, 2022). 
Rank-biserial correlation is a non-parametric measure of effect size that quantifies the strength 
and direction of the relationship between a dichotomous variable and a ranked variable (Berry et 
al., 2018; Field, 2018; Hedrih & Hedrih, 2022). It is a special case of Spearman's rank correlation 
and is often used as the effect size for non-parametric tests like the Mann-Whitney U test or the 
Wilcoxon signed-rank test (Berry et al., 2018; Field, 2018). Partial Eta Squared is a measure of 
effect size used in analysis of variance and related statistical models (Berry et al., 2018; Field, 
2018). Partial eta squared estimates the proportion of variance in the dependent variable that is 
attributable to a specific independent variable, while controlling for other variables in the model, 
with multiple groups (Berry et al., 2018; Field, 2018; Hedrih & Hedrih, 2022). 
Hypothesis 1 
H01: There is no statistically significant difference in body fat percentage between obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training with weights compared to 
resistance training with body weight in San Antonio. 
The findings from the nonparametric Mann-Whitney test retained the null hypothesis that 
there is no significant difference in the dependent variable between the pre-body fat percentage 
and post-body fat percentage results, as reported in Tables 7-9 and Figures 5-7. Pre-intervention 
body fat percentage: U = 15.000, Z = 0.000, p = 1.000 and post-intervention body fat percentage: 
U = 5.000, Z = 0.745, p = 0.456. The effect size was 𝑧 =

129 
 
 
 
effect size, suggesting the resistance training and the body fat percentage in obese 
perimenopausal African American women relationship was not meaningful in practical 
applications (Field, 2018).

132 
 
 
 
A one-way MANOVA was conducted to analyze the effects of two types of resistance 
training: weight training and body weight resistance training. The MANOVA results showed no 
statistically significant difference between the two groups: resistance training with weights and 
resistance training with body fat percentage, Wilks’ Λ= .844, F (2, 5) = .406, p= .655, ns. The 
one-way MANOVA statistical test was chosen in addition to the Mann-Whitney test to evaluate 
the impact of both training methods on body fat percentage. Unlike the Mann-Whitney test, 
which compares body fat percentage before and after the resistance training intervention, the 
one-way MANOVA allows for a simultaneous examination of both training types. The alpha 
level of .05 represents the maximum acceptable probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis 
(Field, 2018). The effect size was .898, which indicates a large effect size, suggesting the 
resistance training and the body fat percentage in obese perimenopausal African American 
women relationship was meaningful in practical applications, as indicated in Table 12 (Field, 
2018). Based on the results, the evidence was insufficient to reject the null hypothesis and 
concluded that there is no statistically significant difference in body fat percentage between 
obese perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training with weights 
compared to resistance training with body weight in San Antonio as seen in Tables 10-14 and 
Figures 8-9. However, the lack of statistical significance underscores the need for further 
research with larger, more diverse samples to validate these trends.

Hypothesis 2 
H02: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to age. 
 The hypothesis was an association between the age of women performing resistance 
training and body fat percentage. The second hypothesis theorized no statistically significant 
impact on body fat percentage among obese perimenopausal African American women in San 
Antonio who engage in resistance training, according to age. To test this, the relationship 
between age and body fat percentage was examined using both nonparametric and parametric 
methods. The Mann-Whitney test was applied to investigate how the age of obese 
perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio performing resistance training impacts 
age. The effect size was z= (-.745)/√8 = -0.263, which indicates a small effect size, suggesting 
that resistance training and the age relationship are not meaningful in practical applications 
(Field, 2018). 
First, the age variable must be converted into two age categories. There were eight 
different ages among the 11 women participating in the research, ranging from 40 to 55. The 
mean was calculated to determine which ages will be allotted in the two categories, which is 
displayed in Table 15. The variables used when applying the Mann-Whitney test were age 40 -46 
and 47- 55, pre-body fat percentage, and post-body fat percentage. However, according to SPSS, 
the Mann-Whitney test cannot be conducted with the variables, as indicated in Figure 13, 
therefore the one-way MANOVA test was applied.

The results of the one-way MANOVA yielded that there was not a statistically significant 
difference between the pre-body fat percentage and post-body fat percentage according to age, 
Wilks’ Λ= .010, F (10, 2) = .1.782, p= .413, ns. The alpha level of .05 represents the maximum 
acceptable probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis (Field, 2018). The effect size was .997, 
which indicates a large effect size on Table 16, indicating a relationship between resistance 
training and age in obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio (Field, 
2018). The large effect size could be attributed to variability within the small sample (N = 11), 
which included eight distinct ages ranging from 40 to 55. 
Further analysis of between-subjects effects revealed no significant differences in either 
pre-body fat percentage (F = 6.143, p = .146) or post-body fat percentage (F = 8.379, p = .110) 
across age groups. Based on the results, the evidence was insufficient to reject the null 
hypothesis, indicating no significant impact on body fat percentage in obese perimenopausal 
African American women who use resistance training according to age in San Antonio, as shown 
in Tables 16 and 17. While the effect size suggests a potential relationship between age and body 
fat percentage, the statistical evidence was insufficient to reject the null hypothesis. These results 

138 
 
 
 
underscore the need for future research with larger, more balanced samples to determine whether 
age plays a substantive role in body composition changes among this population.

Hypothesis 3 
H03: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to education attainment. 
The hypothesis was an association between the educational attainment of women 
performing resistance training and body fat percentage. The Mann-Whitney test was applied to 
investigate how the educational attainment of obese perimenopausal African American women 
in San Antonio performing resistance training impacts body fat. The Mann-Whitney test requires 
a continuous variable, defined as a numeric value that can assume any value within a specific 
interval (Vierra et al., 2023). Therefore, the one-way MANOVA was applied to test the variables 
education attainment and bodyfat percentage. 
The one-way MANOVA was applied to investigate how the educational attainment of 
obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio performing resistance training 
impacts body fat. The results of the one-way MANOVA yielded that there was no statistical 
significance between the educational attainment of obese perimenopausal African American 
women in San Antonio performing resistance training and body fat percentage, Wilks’ Λ=.024, F 
(8, 4) = 2.710, p=.176, ns. The effect size of .844, as indicated in Table 20, suggested a large 
effect size, indicating a meaningful relationship between resistance training and education 
attainment level among obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio (Field, 
2018). The analysis of between-subjects effects showed pre-intervention body fat percentage: F 
= 13.769, p = .028, statistically significant. Post-intervention body fat percentage: F = 7.705, p = 
.063, approaching significance. Based on the results, evidence was insufficient to reject the null 

140 
 
 
 
hypothesis; there is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to education level, as indicated in Tables 18-20. However, these results suggested that while 
educational attainment may have had a statistically significant association with pre-intervention 
body fat percentage, it did not significantly influence post-intervention outcomes. The near-
significant result for post-intervention data may reflect a trend worth exploring in future studies.

Hypothesis 4 
H04: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to religion. 
The hypothesis was an association between the religion of women performing resistance 
training and body fat percentage. The Mann-Whitney test was to be applied to investigate how 
the religion of obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio performing 
resistance training impacts body fat. The religion variable was not continuous and could not be 
selected in SPSS, as indicated in Figure 11. Therefore, the one-way MANOVA was applied to 
test the variables religion and body fat percentage. 
The one-way MANOVA was applied to investigate how the religion of obese 
perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio performing resistance training impacts 
body fat. The results of the one-way MANOVA yielded that there was no statistical significance 
between the religion of obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio 

142 
 
 
 
performing resistance training and body fat percentage, Wilks’ Λ=.194, F (4, 8) = 2.537, p=.122, 
ns. The effect size was .844, which indicates a large effect size on Table 23, suggesting there was 
a viable relationship between resistance training and religion in obese perimenopausal African 
American women in San Antonio (Field, 2018). Although the effect size was large, indicating a 
potentially meaningful relationship, the p-value exceeded the alpha threshold of .05, suggesting 
that the observed differences were not statistically significant. Further analysis of between-
subjects effects showed pre-intervention body fat percentage: F = 13.769, p = .028, statistically 
significant, and post-intervention body fat percentage: F = 7.705, p = .063, approaching 
significance. Based on these results, evidence was not sufficient to reject the null hypothesis; 
there is no statistically significant impact on body fat percentage in obese perimenopausal 
African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according to religion, as 
indicated in Tables 21-23.
