CHAPTER FIVE: CONCLUSIONS 
Overview 
In recent years, resistance training has gained popularity as a form of exercise, especially 
among women (Hagstrom et al., 2020). Resistance training leads to unique physiological 
adaptations that differ from other forms of exercise (Hagstrom et al., 2020). During the 
perimenopausal stage, many women undergo significant changes in body composition. One 
notable change is the redistribution of subcutaneous fat; instead of being predominantly stored in 
the hips and thighs, fat begins to accumulate in the abdominal region (Hagstrom et al., 2020). 
Consistent long-term engagement in resistance training offers numerous benefits. Increasing 
muscular strength and mass while reducing visceral fat contributes to enhanced body 
composition, metabolism, and physical performance (Hollingsworth et al., 2020; Krzysztofik et 
al., 2019; Muñoz-López et al., 2022). The purpose of this randomized controlled trial study was 
to investigate how resistance training impacts body fat in obese perimenopausal African 
American women in San Antonio, Texas. Chapter five discussed the study's findings and 
implications, followed by the limitations and recommendations for future research. 
Discussion 
The purpose of this quantitative randomized controlled trial research study was to 
investigate how resistance training impacts body fat in obese perimenopausal African American 
women in San Antonio, Texas. There were two types of resistance training that were used in this 
study: resistance training with weights and resistance training with body weight. This study was 
advertised with advertisement flyers, which were posted at local gyms, local businesses, 
churches, Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn that provided a link to the intake survey. A total of 
79 women completed the intake survey however, only 23 women met the criteria of African 
American woman over age 40, had a menstrual cycle in the past 11 months, and experienced at 

147 
 
 
 
least three of the following symptoms: irregular periods, hot flashes, weight gain, poor sleep, 
vaginal dryness, mood swings, brain fog, or bladder problems. Out of the 23 women who met the 
criteria, only 11 women scheduled an Inbody scan to participate in the study. 
These 11 women were placed into one of two groups: resistance training group with 
weights and resistance training group with body weight. Each group met with the researcher, a 
personal trainer, twice a week for 30 minutes for six weeks. The resistance training group with 
weights met at the researcher’s gym, while the resistance training group with body weight met 
virtually through Zoom. Three participants from the resistance training group with body weight 
withdrew from the study without a documented reason. 
Hypothesis 1 
H01: There is no statistically significant difference in body fat percentage between obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training with weights compared to 
resistance training with body weight in San Antonio. 
In light of the results, the nonparametric Mann-Whitney test supported the null 
hypothesis, indicating that there is no significant difference in the dependent variable between 
the pre-body fat percentage and the post-body fat percentage results between the two groups. In 
other words, the pre-body fat percentage results were not significantly different from the post-
body fat percentage results between the groups. The aim of the study was to compare resistance 
training to body fat percentage and not for the groups to be compared to one another. Therefore, 
the researcher chose an alternate test, the one-way Multivariate Analysis of Variance 
(MANOVA), to compare resistance training and body fat percentage. The one-way MANOVA 
concluded that there is no statistically significant difference in body fat percentage between 
obese perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training. In light of the 
results from the Mann-Whitney test and the one-way MANOVA, participants who completed the 

148 
 
 
 
study in entirety, except one, decreased body fat percentage after participating in resistance 
training. 
In light of the literature, resistance training is recommended for older adults to slow down 
and potentially reverse the loss of muscle mass and function caused by aging, while improving 
vital health indicators to extend active life expectancy (Nunes et al., 2021). Resistance training 
focuses on specific muscles through external resistance, achieving optimal results when 
integrated with exercises designed to improve endurance, balance, flexibility, and strength 
(Hedrick, 2020; Marinho et al., 2023). According to various reports, African American women 
represent the demographic group with the lowest levels of physical activity in the United States 
(Benitez et al., 2024; Obi et al., 2023; Sweeney et al., 2022). Furthermore, there is a significant 
increase in the prevalence of cardiometabolic diseases and obesity in this demographic (Benitez 
et al., 2024). However, this study found that over 60% of the African American women who 
completed the intake survey had participated in resistance training within the past three months. 
In light of other studies, researchers have provided evidence that resistance training has 
an impact on body fat percentage. Chapman-Lopez et al. (2024) proposed that a 10-week 
resistance training program can result in significant changes in body composition and adipokine 
concentrations among untrained perimenopausal and postmenopausal women. In this study, 35 
women were randomly divided into two groups: one receiving leucine and the other a placebo. 
Both groups consumed either a supplement or a placebo daily while participating in the 10-week 
resistance training program. Body composition was evaluated using dual-energy x-ray 
absorptiometry, and adipokine concentrations were measured before and after the intervention. 
The study provided evidence that there were no significant differences in any body composition 
parameter except for the visceral adipose tissue (VAT) area (Chapman-Lopez et al., 2024). VAT, 

149 
 
 
 
commonly referred to as intra-abdominal fat, accumulates deep within the abdominal cavity, 
surrounding crucial organs such as the liver, pancreas, and intestines (Luzi, 2021). 
In two studies conducted by Shuping Hao, evidence is provided that resistance training 
does have an impact on body fat percentage. Hao et al. (2022) sought to evaluate the impact of 
different dietary and exercise interventions on health indices in perimenopausal women. In this 
study, participants were divided into three groups: Group A received standard gynecological 
diagnosis and treatment, in addition to centralized lifestyle health education. Group B engaged in 
comprehensive educational content and received personalized dietary guidance from professional 
dietitians. Group C benefited from intensive education, individualized dietary interventions, and 
enhanced resistance exercise programs. The findings indicated that Group C achieved the highest 
total diet score and experienced a significant reduction in red meat consumption. Both Groups B 
and C demonstrated an increase in exercise frequency, particularly in resistance training. 
Additionally, Group C reported a notable increase in the amount of aerobic exercise performed 
weekly. Participants in Group C exhibited significant reductions in body fat and waist 
circumference, along with an increase in skeletal muscle weight. In Groups B and C, body mass 
index, trunk fat ratio, and waist-to-hip ratio decreased, while trunk muscle mass increased 
significantly in Group C. The combination of dietary guidance, health education, and resistance 
exercise resulted in the most significant improvements in health metrics. Notably, increasing 
resistance exercise had a particularly profound impact and is recommended for further promotion 
and implementation. 
In a third study, Hao et al. (2021), aimed to investigate the effects of personalized dietary 
and exercise interventions on metabolic health in perimenopausal women in Beijing. The 
participants were randomly assigned to one of three groups: Group A attended educational 
seminars; Group B participated in the seminars and received individualized dietary guidance 

150 
 
 
 
from professional nutritionists, while Group C received the same comprehensive education and 
personalized dietary guidance as Group B in addition to engaging in intensive resistance 
exercise. The findings of this study revealed a significant decrease in the number of patients with 
abnormal metabolic indices within the diet and comprehensive groups following the intervention. 
Additionally, there was a notable reduction in the number of patients with a waist circumference 
of ≥80 cm in both the diet and comprehensive groups. The control and diet groups exhibited a 
higher incidence of HDL levels <1.29 mmol/L compared to the comprehensive group. 
Furthermore, after the intervention, triglyceride levels in the comprehensive group were 
significantly lower than participants in the control group. A personalized dietary intervention 
combined with resistance training can significantly enhance eating and exercise habits, address 
metabolic disorders, and diminish the prevalence of metabolic syndrome. 
In light of the theory, the researcher of this study applied the health belief model (HBM) 
to improve exercise self-eﬃcacy with the participants. The HBM findings suggest that while 
both resistance training modalities are perceived positively, barriers and self-efficacy play a 
pivotal role in sustained engagement. Therefore, when comparing their impact on body fat 
percentage, it's essential to consider not just physiological outcomes but also behavioral 
feasibility. Resistance training may yield greater results, but resistance training could be more 
sustainable unless barriers are actively addressed. 
The researcher in this study had six weeks to enhance participants' self-efficacy, which 
successfully resulted in 45% of participants continuing to participate in resistance training 
beyond the study. Five of the six constructs of the HBM were used in this study: perception of 
susceptibility, perception of severity, perceived benefits, perceived barriers, and self-efficacy. 
The sixth construct that was not used was cue to action, which pertains to the stimulus required 
to initiate the decision-making process to accept a recommended health action (Elgzar et al., 

151 
 
 
 
2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). Triggers for action include a variety of factors such 
as personal perceptions of symptoms, social influences, health education campaigns, and a 
readiness to address health issues (Abraham & Sheeran, 2001). Studies focusing on behaviors 
driven by internal motivation may find the cue to action construct irrelevant as for this study 
(Abraham & Sheeran, 2001). During the 30-minute workout sessions, the researcher interacted 
with participants through conversation and posed questions regarding the perceived importance 
of resistance training; the responses are displayed in Figure 11. 
Perceived susceptibility refers to the assessment of the ability to engage in resistance 
training (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). While perceived severity is 
understanding why participants may feel that resistance training is unnecessary during 
perimenopause (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). The participants 
displayed a low level of perceived susceptibility & severity. Participants did not feel highly 
vulnerable to negative body fat outcomes and did not view perimenopause as a major barrier. 
Example questions were asked of the participants to help assess the perceived susceptibility and 
severity, which were: How often do you perform resistance training? Should perimenopausal 
women perform resistance training? Do you believe that perimenopause increases your 
vulnerability to health issues? What are your beliefs about the seriousness of obesity-related 
health outcomes during perimenopause? How do you feel about the impact of physical inactivity 
on long-term health and quality of life? Since both training modalities were viewed positively, 
modality preference may not be driven by fear or urgency, but rather by accessibility or 
perceived effectiveness. This suggests that both types of resistance training could be equally 
adopted, but differences in outcomes may stem from physiological factors rather than 
psychological resistance. The majority of participants expressed the belief that all forms of 
exercise hold importance, extending beyond resistance training. Findings suggest a perception of 

152 
 
 
 
low susceptibility to body fat percentage to resistance training. Over 70% of participants 
recognized the significance of resistance training for African American women, contradicting the 
notion that African American women struggle to understand the Center for Disease Control 
(CDC) guidelines (Howard & Bartholomew, 2024). The participants’ responses showed there 
was a low level of perceived severity to body fat percentage about resistance training. 
The participant’s displayed a high level of perceived benefits which refers to participants' 
understanding of the benefits of resistance training (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; 
Narmkul et al., 2024). According to Obi et al. (2023), a gap exists in qualitative studies to better 
understand African American women's perspectives on the benefits of engaging in physical 
activity, beyond what objective data reveals. To determine the level of perceived benefits in this 
study, participants were asked questions about the benefits of resistance training for African 
American women in perimenopause. Examples of questions asked were: What are the benefits of 
resistance training during perimenopause? Do you believe resistance training can help manage 
perimenopausal symptoms? The participant’s responses are displayed in Figure 13. According to 
the participants in this study, no negative responses were identified; in fact, the majority reported 
experiencing positive benefits associated with resistance training, resulting in the participants 
being highly motivated and receptive, which supports the feasibility of comparing modalities 
without concern for bias in perceived effectiveness. The participants’ responses showed there 
was a high level of perceived benefits to body fat percentage concerning resistance training. 
Next, the participants displayed a high level of perceived barriers, which is understanding 
what physical and mental obstacles prevent participants from engaging in resistance training 
(Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). According to Howard and 
Bartholomew (2024), African American women face overlapping marginalization due to being 
both African American and women. Consequently, various barriers related to physical activity 

153 
 
 
 
arise, including motivation, social support, access, cost, hair maintenance, and family 
responsibilities (Howard & Bartholomew, 2024; Onyegbule et al., 2021; Sillice et al., 2024). The 
identified barriers coincide with the barriers of the participants from this study, as indicated on 
Figure 14. Example questions asked of the participants were: What challenges do you face in 
engaging in resistance training? Are there psychological or social factors (e.g., stigma, body 
image, fatigue) that hinder participation? This resulted in the participants’ having a high level of 
perceived barriers to body fat percentage in relation to resistance training. 
Lastly, self-efficacy, which increased confidence, was used to encourage participants to 
continue resistance training exercises beyond the scope of this study. Exercise self-efficacy is the 
confidence in one's ability to assess and improve physical fitness (Xue-liu & Mu, 2021). 
Developing and maintaining this self-efficacy is essential to achieving and upholding fitness 
goals effectively (Patterson et al., 2022). Enhancing self-efficacy is essential for effectively 
achieving and maintaining fitness goals. The researcher in this study had six weeks to improve 
participants' self-efficacy. Example questions asked to the participants are How confident are 
you in their ability to perform resistance exercises regularly? Will you continue resistance 
training after this study is completed? This resulted in 45% to continue to participate, which 
indicated a high level of self-efficacy regarding body fat percentage in relation to resistance 
training. The results from the HBM suggest that addressing self-efficacy is crucial for sustained 
engagement, potentially overcoming perceived barriers.

Hypothesis 2 
H02: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to age. 
 In light of the results, the Mann-Whitney test was utilized to examine the influence of age 
on body fat among obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio who engage 
in resistance training. The Mann-Whitney test allowed two age groups to be compared. 
Therefore, the mean was calculated to determine which ages were allotted in the two categories: 
40 - 46 and 47- 55 years. The Mann-Whitney method could not be applied to test research 
question 2, so the one-way MANOVA was applied. The results of the MANOVA indicated that 
there was no statistically significant difference between pre-body fat percentage and post-body 
fat percentage when analyzed by age. In light of the results, younger participants achieved 


157 
 
 
 
greater reductions in body fat percentage compared to older participants, as demonstrated in 
Figure 17. 
Figure 16 
Body Fat Percentage Loss by Age 
 
In light of the literature, aging is marked by a substantial decline in physical activity, 
diminished mobility and functional independence, and heightened rates of morbidity 
(Cunningham et al., 2020). Alongside reduced physical activity, excessive food consumption 
contributes significantly to weight gain (Kopelman et al., 2022; Powers et al., 2024). In the 
United States, increased food intake has been a key factor in the growing obesity rates 
(Kopelman et al., 2022). Additionally, aging is characterized by a gradual decline in muscular 
strength, which is further exacerbated by changes in the nervous system and primarily driven by 
the loss of muscle mass (Herda & Nabavizadeh, 2021; Powers et al., 2024). Resistance training 
has proven to be an effective form of physical activity to reduce the age-related loss of muscle 
strength, with improvements ranging from 9% to 147% (DeLuca et al., 2020; Muñoz-López et 
al., 2022). 


158 
 
 
 
Weight loss in early to middle adulthood is associated with a slowing of biological aging, 
suggesting that effective weight management during these stages can provide lasting benefits for 
the aging process (Cao et al., 2023). On the other hand, transitioning from obesity to a non-obese 
state in middle to late adulthood is associated with faster biological aging, suggesting that late-
life weight loss may not completely counteract the adverse effects of prolonged obesity (Cao et 
al., 2023). In contrast, DeLuca et al. (2020) found that older adults achieved greater weight loss 
overall, even with lower engagement levels compared to younger adults. In a clinic-based weight 
loss program, younger adults were identified as the sole age group with the highest dropout rates 
(DeLuca et al., 2020). Conversely, adults aged 65 years and older exhibited higher self-
monitoring rates and attended a greater number of sessions than the younger counterparts 
(DeLuca et al., 2020). 
In light of other studies, several researchers have delved into studies that reveal a 
fascinating connection between age and body fat percentage, showing that age can indeed have a 
significant influence on how bodies store fat. Buskard and Petrella (2023) provided compelling 
evidence indicating that resistance training significantly mitigates the decline in muscle size and 
strength commonly associated with aging. Buskard and Petrella (2023) examined 24 published 
research articles focused on older adults, with a mean age exceeding 65 years, who engaged in 
exercise protocols centered solely on resistance training. The findings emphasize that changes in 
body composition, particularly the ratio of fat mass to lean mass, are more critical than total body 
mass in assessing the effectiveness of resistance training interventions. According to Buskard 
and Petrella’s (2023), changes in body composition, specifically the fat mass to lean mass ratio, 
are crucial variables to consider when evaluating the effectiveness of resistance training 
interventions aimed at reducing chronic disease in older adults. Weight loss alone is an 
incomplete and potentially problematic outcome measure for the older demographic. The review 

159 
 
 
 
ultimately concludes that shifts in body composition, rather than total body mass, are vital factors 
to consider when assessing the effectiveness of resistance training interventions aimed at 
reducing chronic disease in older adults. 
 Nunes et al. (2021) conducted a study examining the differing responses to resistance 
training among older women concerning muscle mass gains. The primary objective was to 
explore how variations in training volume and frequency impact muscle mass development in the 
older women's demographic. The study involved 39 women aged 60 and above, who engaged in 
a 24-week whole-body resistance training program consisted of eight exercises performed 2 to 3 
times per week. Participants were categorized as responders, 17 women demonstrated gains in 
skeletal muscle mass after 12 weeks of training, and among the non-responders, 22 women did 
not. Of the 22 non-responders, only three exhibited significant muscle mass gains following an 
additional 12 weeks of increased training volume, while 19 either maintained the initial status or 
experienced negative changes in skeletal muscle mass. In contrast, 17 responders continued to 
show increases in muscle mass during the subsequent training phase. Key findings from the 
study include: responsiveness: the variability in responsiveness to resistance training for muscle 
mass gain among older women. Training volume and duration: elevating training volume and 
duration did not significantly affect the condition of non-responders. Baseline characteristics: no 
noteworthy correlations were observed between baseline characteristics and changes in skeletal 
muscle mass. Nunes et al. (2021) concluded that the responsiveness to muscle mass gain varies 
among older women. 
 Lastly, according to the National Strength and Conditioning Association (NSCA), 
resistance training is identified as a powerful intervention to combat the decline in biological 
changes that decrease skeletal muscle mass, strength, and function, which occurs with aging 
(Fragala et al., 2019). Research has established that resistance training serves as an effective 

160 
 
 
 
intervention for mitigating the effects of muscle disuse (Buskard & Petrella, 2023; Fragala et al., 
2019; Nunes et al., 2021). Resistance training is instrumental in combating the loss of muscle 
strength and mass, commonly referred to as sarcopenia, as well as reducing physiological 
vulnerabilities or frailty (Fragala et al., 2019). Furthermore, resistance training contributes 
significantly to preserving overall physical functioning, enhancing mobility, maintaining 
independence, managing chronic diseases, improving psychological well-being, and ultimately 
elevating the quality of life (Buskard & Petrella, 2023; Fragala et al., 2019; Nunes et al., 2021). 
In light of the theory, the researcher of this study applied the health belief model (HBM) 
to improve exercise self-eﬃcacy with the participants according to age. The researcher in this 
study had six weeks to enhance participants' self-efficacy, which successfully resulted in 45% of 
participants continuing to participate in resistance training beyond the study. Muscle mass 
typically peaks during youth, between the ages of 20 and 40 (Branquinho et al., 2025; 
Steltenpohl et al., 2019). Between the ages of 20 and 40, various health parameters, including 
bone mineral density, reach peak values (Branquinho et al., 2025). After this peak, muscle mass 
begins to decline at a rate of 0.3% per year if resistance training is not included in a person's 
routine (Branquinho et al., 2025; Steltenpohl et al., 2019). 
Motivation to exercise evolves with age (Steltenpohl et al., 2019); thus, the researcher 
examined whether age influences exercise self-efficacy using five constructs of the health belief 
model (HBM). The five of the six constructs of the HBM that were used in this study were 
perception of susceptibility, perception of severity, perceived benefits, perceived barriers, and 
self-efficacy. The sixth construct that was not used was cue to action, which pertains to the 
stimulus required to initiate the decision-making process to accept a recommended health action 
(Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). Triggers for action include a variety 
of factors such as personal perceptions of symptoms, social influences, health education 

161 
 
 
 
campaigns, and a readiness to address health issues (Abraham & Sheeran, 2001). Studies 
focusing on behaviors driven by internal motivation may find the cue to action construct 
irrelevant, as in this study (Abraham & Sheeran, 2001). 
Perceived susceptibility refers to the assessment of the ability to engage in resistance 
training (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). While perceived severity is 
understanding why participants may feel that resistance training is unnecessary during 
perimenopause (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). The participants 
displayed a low level of perceived susceptibility & severity. Participants did not feel highly 
vulnerable to negative body fat outcomes and did not view perimenopause as a major barrier. 
Example questions were asked of the participants to help assess the perceived susceptibility and 
severity, which were: How often do you perform resistance training? Should perimenopausal 
women perform resistance training? Do you believe that perimenopause increases your 
vulnerability to health issues? What are your beliefs about the seriousness of obesity-related 
health outcomes during perimenopause? How do you feel about the impact of physical inactivity 
on long-term health and quality of life? Since both training modalities were viewed positively, 
modality preference may not be driven by fear or urgency, but rather by accessibility or 
perceived effectiveness. This suggests that both types of resistance training could be equally 
adopted, but differences in outcomes may stem from physiological factors rather than 
psychological resistance. The majority of participants expressed the belief that all forms of 
exercise hold importance, extending beyond resistance training. Findings suggest a perception of 
low susceptibility to body fat percentage to resistance training. Over 70% of participants 
recognized the significance of resistance training for African American women, contradicting the 
notion that African American women struggle to understand the Center for Disease Control 

162 
 
 
 
(CDC) guidelines (Howard & Bartholomew, 2024). The participants’ responses showed there 
was a low level of perceived severity to body fat percentage about resistance training. 
The participant’s displayed a high level of perceived benefits which refers to participants' 
understanding of the benefits of resistance training (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; 
Narmkul et al., 2024). According to Obi et al. (2023), a gap exists in qualitative studies to better 
understand African American women's perspectives on the benefits of engaging in physical 
activity, beyond what objective data reveals. To determine the level of perceived benefits in this 
study, participants were asked questions about the benefits of resistance training for African 
American women in perimenopause. Examples of questions asked were: What are the benefits of 
resistance training during perimenopause? Do you believe resistance training can help manage 
perimenopausal symptoms? The participant’s responses are displayed in Figure 13. According to 
the participants in this study, no negative responses were identified; in fact, the majority reported 
experiencing positive benefits associated with resistance training, resulting in the participants 
being highly motivated and receptive, which supports the feasibility of comparing modalities 
without concern for bias in perceived effectiveness. The participants’ responses showed there 
was a high level of perceived benefits to body fat percentage concerning resistance training. 
Next, the participants displayed a high level of perceived barriers, which is understanding 
what physical and mental obstacles prevent participants from engaging in resistance training 
(Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). According to Howard and 
Bartholomew (2024), African American women face overlapping marginalization due to being 
both African American and women. Consequently, various barriers related to physical activity 
arise, including motivation, social support, access, cost, hair maintenance, and family 
responsibilities (Howard & Bartholomew, 2024; Onyegbule et al., 2021; Sillice et al., 2024). The 
identified barriers coincide with the barriers of the participants from this study, as indicated on 

163 
 
 
 
Figure 14. Example questions asked of the participants were: What challenges do you face in 
engaging in resistance training? Are there psychological or social factors (e.g., stigma, body 
image, fatigue) that hinder participation? This resulted in the participants’ having a high level of 
perceived barriers to body fat percentage in relation to resistance training.

continue resistance training exercises beyond the scope of this study. Exercise self-efficacy is the 
confidence in one's ability to assess and improve physical fitness (Xue-liu & Mu, 2021).

training. The results from the HBM suggest that addressing self-efficacy is crucial for sustained 
engagement, potentially overcoming perceived barriers. 
 
Hypothesis 3 
H03: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to educational attainment. 
In light of the results, the Mann-Whitney test was set to be employed to examine the 
influence of educational attainment on body fat among obese perimenopausal African American 
women in San Antonio who are engaged in resistance training. However, the Mann-Whitney test 

164 
 
 
 
could not be performed since all the variables were not continuous; therefore, the MANOVA 
was applied. The results of the MANOVA yielded that there was no statistical significance 
between the educational attainment of obese perimenopausal African American women in San 
Antonio performing resistance training and body fat percentage. In light of the results, there is no 
relationship between educational attainment and the use of resistance training. In this study, half 
of the women had achieved a master’s degree, which shows a greater reduction in body fat 
percentage at this educational attainment, as shown in Figure 18. 
Figure 17 
Body Fat Percentage Loss by Educational Attainment 
 
 
There is no literature specifically addressing the intersection of educational attainment 
and resistance training among perimenopausal African American women. Direct research 
showed that higher educational attainment may be associated with lower body fat percentage in 
women due to various factors such as increased health awareness, access to resources, and 
potentially healthier lifestyle choices (Assari, 2019; Ekúndayò et al., 2020; Redondo Lourés & 
Cairns, 2020). In light of the literature that is available, there is a connection between educational 
attainment and women's overall health. Education has frequently been used as a proxy for socio-
economic status in various mortality studies (Redondo Lourés & Cairns, 2020). Data on the 


165 
 
 
 
educational background of both deceased individuals and the general population are more readily 
available than information on other socio-economic factors, such as income, wealth, or 
occupation (Redondo Lourés & Cairns, 2020). Individuals with lower educational attainment, 
particularly individuals who have not completed high school, face an increased risk of all-cause 
mortality and cardiovascular disease mortality (Li & Adair, 2024). Education plays a crucial role 
in understanding mortality related to obesity. Obesity is more prevalent among individuals with 
lower levels of education in the United States, a pattern observed across diverse ethnic groups 
(Li & Adair, 2024). Similar education-based disparities in obesity rates are evident in 
Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, with women 
experiencing more pronounced gaps compared to men (Li & Adair, 2024). 
In the light of other studies, the article "Educational Attainment and Exercise Frequency 
in American Women: Blacks’ Diminished Returns," which examined the relationship between 
educational attainment and exercise frequency among American women, specifically highlighted 
the differences among racial groups. The study utilized data from the National Survey of 
American Life, which included 3,175 women, comprising 876 Caucasian women and 2,299 
African American women (Assari, 2019). The independent variable was educational attainment, 
while the dependent variable was exercise frequency (Assari, 2019). The covariates included 
age, region, household income, financial distress, marital status, unemployment, and depression 
(Assari, 2019). Race served as the moderator in the analysis (Assari, 2019). According to Assari 
(2019), higher educational attainment among Caucasian women was linked to an increase in 
exercise frequency. In contrast, higher educational attainment did not show a significant 
association with exercise frequency for African American women. The study concluded that 
Caucasian women experience more significant health benefits from higher levels of educational 
attainment compared to African American women (Assari, 2019). 

166 
 
 
 
In contrast, Carr et al. (2020) discovered that educational attainment varied significantly 
between women who are obese and women who are not. The aim of the study was to explore the 
differences in attitudes towards exercise benefits and barriers among older African American 
women, both with and without obesity. Additionally, the study examined the impact of 
participants' attitudes on the relationship between weight status and exercise participation. The 
study analyzed 234 older African American women, with an average age of 63.8 years (± 7.9 
years), dividing the participants into two groups based on the presence or absence of obesity. The 
key findings related to educational attainment revealed that a higher percentage of women with 
obesity fell into the category of having less than a high school education compared to the 
counterparts without obesity, indicating that lower educational attainment is more prevalent 
among women with obesity. Additionally, the percentage of women with obesity who are high 
school graduates is slightly higher than that of women without obesity, showing that a significant 
portion of both groups has completed high school. Higher education levels are more common 
among women without obesity, with a greater likelihood of attending college compared to 
women with obesity. The obesity connection suggests increased educational attainment 
correlates with lower obesity rates among participants, potentially due to associations between 
higher education, healthier lifestyle choices, and improved health outcomes. According to the 
Social Determinants of Health framework, social and economic factors significantly influence 
health outcomes (Ingram et al., 2024). These factors include access to healthcare services, 
education, employment opportunities, socioeconomic status (SES), neighborhood and physical 
environment, social support networks, and cultural norms and values (Ingram et al., 2024; Lofton 
et al., 2023). There are significant racial disparities in obesity prevalence among women, even 
among women with higher education levels and incomes (Ingram et al., 2024; Lofton et al., 
2023). This indicates that race has an independent impact on weight status (Lofton et al., 2023). 

167 
 
 
 
African American women tend to have a higher body mass index (BMI) than Caucasian women 
across all levels of educational attainment, with the most pronounced difference seen in women 
who have completed more than a high school education (Lofton et al., 2023). According to 
Lofton et al (2023), the results provided evidence that the participants who had higher 
educational attainment had a greater impact on body fat percentage with resistance training. 
In light of the theory, the researcher of this study applied the health belief model (HBM) 
to improve exercise self-eﬃcacy with the participants according to educational attainment. The 
researcher in this study had six weeks to enhance participants' self-efficacy, which successfully 
resulted in 45% of participants continuing to participate in resistance training beyond the study. 
Research shows that higher education levels were associated with increased exercise frequency 
among women overall (Assari, 2019; Hall, 2020; Woo et al., 2023). Despite higher educational 
attainment, African American women exhibit a lower increase in exercise frequency compared to 
Caucasian counterparts (Assari, 2019). Five of the six constructs of the HBM were used in this 
study: perception of susceptibility, perception of severity, perceived benefits, perceived barriers, 
and self-efficacy. The six constructs that was not used was cue to action, which pertains to the 
stimulus required to initiate the decision-making process to accept a recommended health action 
(Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). Triggers for action include a variety 
of factors such as personal perceptions of symptoms, social influences, health education 
campaigns, and a readiness to address health issues (Abraham & Sheeran, 2001). Studies 
focusing on behaviors driven by internal motivation may find the cue to action construct 
irrelevant as for this study (Abraham & Sheeran, 2001). 
Perceived susceptibility refers to the assessment of the ability to engage in resistance 
training (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). While perceived severity is 
understanding why participants may feel that resistance training is unnecessary during 

168 
 
 
 
perimenopause (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). The participants 
displayed a low level of perceived susceptibility & severity. Participants did not feel highly 
vulnerable to negative body fat outcomes and did not view perimenopause as a major barrier. 
Example questions were asked of the participants to help assess the perceived susceptibility and 
severity, which were: How often do you perform resistance training? Should perimenopausal 
women perform resistance training? Do you believe that perimenopause increases your 
vulnerability to health issues? What are your beliefs about the seriousness of obesity-related 
health outcomes during perimenopause? How do you feel about the impact of physical inactivity 
on long-term health and quality of life? Since both training modalities were viewed positively, 
modality preference may not be driven by fear or urgency, but rather by accessibility or 
perceived effectiveness. This suggests that both types of resistance training could be equally 
adopted, but differences in outcomes may stem from physiological factors rather than 
psychological resistance. The majority of participants expressed the belief that all forms of 
exercise hold importance, extending beyond resistance training. Findings suggest a perception of 
low susceptibility to body fat percentage to resistance training. Over 70% of participants 
recognized the significance of resistance training for African American women, contradicting the 
notion that African American women struggle to understand the Center for Disease Control 
(CDC) guidelines (Howard & Bartholomew, 2024). The participants’ responses showed there 
was a low level of perceived severity to body fat percentage about resistance training.

Hypothesis 4 
H04: There is no statistically significant impact in body fat percentage with obese 
perimenopausal African American women who use resistance training in San Antonio according 
to religion. 
 In light of the results, the Mann-Whitney test was intended to investigate how the religion 
of obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio who are performing 
resistance training affects body fat. However, since the religion variable was not continuous and 
could not be selected in SPSS, a MANOVA was applied instead. The MANOVA results revealed 
no statistical significance between the religion of obese perimenopausal African American 
women in San Antonio engaging in resistance training and body fat percentage. A study could 
not be found that shows a direct correlation between religion and resistance training among 
African American women; however, research has documented that religion can influence 
physical activity levels with African American women. There is no relationship between religion 
and the use of resistance training as indicated in Figure 19. 
 

171 
 
 
 
Figure 18 
 
Body Fat Percentage by Religion 
 
No literature explicitly addresses the association between religion and resistance training 
performed by African American women. However, religion has played a significant role in the 
lives of African Americans throughout history (Besheer et al., 2021). In light of the literature that 
is available, the majority of African American adults rely on prayer to help guide in making 
important decisions and consider the fight against racism to be a fundamental aspect of religious 
beliefs (Besheer et al., 2021). Young African American adults in the United States have 
demonstrated lower levels of religious affiliation and reduced engagement with African 
American churches compared to older generations (Besheer et al., 2021). According to Shockley 
and Norman (2024), several factors significantly influence decision-making processes regarding 
weight management. These factors include stigma, bias, racism, body image perception, cultural 
dietary practices, social influencers, stress, and religious beliefs (Shockley & Norman Burrell, 
2024). Religion holds a significant cultural influence in shaping African American women's 
eating and physical activity habits, affecting perceptions of body image and weight (Shockley & 
Norman Burrell, 2024; Spinner, 2022; Waldstein et al., 2022). In some religious communities, 


172 
 
 
 
there may be less emphasis on thinness and more acceptance of diverse body shapes (Shockley 
& Norman Burrell, 2024; Spinner, 2022). Religious communities that emphasize acceptance of 
diverse body shapes can influence attitudes toward weight management and obesity, deeming 
body shapes less important (Shockley & Norman Burrell, 2024; Spinner, 2022). 
 According to Brewer et al. (2020), specific barriers created challenges in maintaining a 
healthy weight among African Americans; however, the church serves as a significant source of 
strength and support in overcoming the obstacles. Barriers to achieving and maintaining a 
healthy weight include various challenges, such as limited cultural acceptance of exercise and 
healthy eating, numerous family and work-related responsibilities, stress, fatigue, health issues, 
lack of motivation, financial constraints, and living in neighborhoods that may not be conducive 
to safe physical activity (Brewer et al., 2021). Research increasingly showed churches can be 
vital settings and effective partners for diet and physical activity interventions aimed at African-
American adults (Brewer et al., 2021; Derboghossian et al., 2025; Geller et al., 2019). Healthy 
dietary patterns and physical activity are connected to the structural dimensions of social 
networks (Derboghossian et al., 2025; Waldstein et al., 2022). The structural dimensions of 
social networks included characteristics of church environments, such as programs and policies 
that promote healthy eating and physical activity, as well as the availability of exercise facilities 
and classes. Additionally, educational activities that focus on nutrition and health are important 
(Derboghossian et al., 2025). 
In light of other studies, a pilot study indicated that a faith-based intervention for African 
Americans resulted in an average weight loss of 2.7% and a significant increase in physical 
activity (Brewer et al., 2021). Additionally, research has shown that incorporating spiritual 
messages, Bible verses, and prayer can enhance health improvements and promote physical 
activity behaviors among members of the African American church (Brewer et al., 2021). 

173 
 
 
 
According to Geller et al. (2019), social support from the church positively impacted various 
health behaviors. In particular, church-based support contributed to increased time spent 
walking, engaging in leisure activities, and participating in moderate physical exercise among 
African Americans. Additionally, encouragement from pastors and fellow church members led to 
higher physical activity levels among African American adults involved in a church-sponsored 
physical activity program. Moreover, social support within the church was linked to healthier 
dietary habits, with pastors' support positively influencing congregation members’ fruit and 
vegetable intake. In contrast, Geller et al. (2019) identified that negative social support from an 
individual’s congregation correlates with an increased likelihood of dieting among women who 
are attempting to lose weight. Negative social support may manifest through acts of sabotage by 
family and friends. Sabotage is defined as the refusal of a family member or friend to consume 
healthy foods with the individual or the act of eating unhealthy foods in the presence of the 
individual (Geller et al., 2019).

 In light of the results, the Mann-Whitney test was to be applied to investigate how the 
marital status of obese perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio performing 
resistance training impacts body fat. The martial status variable was not continuous; therefore, 
the one-way MANOVA was applied. The results of the MANOVA yielded that there was no

177 
 
 
 
results, there is no relationship between marital status and the use of resistance training, as 
indicated in Figure 20. 
Figure 19 
Body Fat Percentage Loss by Marital Status 
 
 
 
 
There is no literature specifically addressing the intersection of marital status and 
resistance training among perimenopausal African American women. Direct research indicates 
that there is a lack of specificity in the perimenopause African American women's population, 
requiring a broader search to be conducted using keywords such as “ perimenopausal women” or 
“African American women’s health” to use large-scale studies (Lee et al., 2025). In light of the 
literature that is available, the relationship between marital status and resistance training among 
African American women is multifaceted. Research suggested that various factors shape physical 
activity participation among middle-aged and older adults, with marital status playing a key role 
in influencing both exercise self-efficacy and related behaviors (Makambi & Adams-Campbell, 
2018; Woo et al., 2024). Waldstein et al. (2022) conducted an extensive review on marriage and 
physical health, revealing that marital conflict disproportionately affects women's health 


178 
 
 
 
compared to men's health. Furthermore, studies highlighted that both marital status and the 
overall quality of intimate relationships are significant determinants of engagement in physical 
activity (Makambi & Adams-Campbell, 2018; Waldstein et al., 2022; Yuan et al., 2024). 
Partner support, marital strain, marital and family responsibilities, and cultural factors 
could influence the association between marital status and resistance training. Partner support 
provides encouragement and practical help, such as childcare, shared activities, and 
accountability (Amirkhan & Vandenbelt, 2023; Makambi & Adams-Campbell, 2018). 
Conversely, a strained or unsupported marital relationship could create the need for self-care 
(Rosa et al., 2025). Marital and family responsibilities tend to create time constraints that 
disproportionately affect African American women, potentially limiting the ability to prioritize 
resistance training (Obi et al., 2023). Culture factors and expectations within the African 
American community regarding exercise and body image may play a part in the marital 
dynamics (Chinn et al., 2021; Dunn et al., 2019; Modica et al., 2023). 
 In light of other studies, research specifically connects marital status to resistance training 
among African American women; some broader insights can be explored. According to Knapik 
et al. (2025), marital status and other sociodemographic factors influence body image among 
adult women. Knapik et al. (2025) highlighted that perceptions of sexual attractiveness and 
concerns regarding weight significantly influence women's body image perceptions based on 
marital status. Makambi and Adams-Campbell (2018) found that marital status can affect the 
levels of physical activity among African American women, leading to variations in obesity rates 
among African American women based on marital status. Specifically, married women often 
navigate different social support systems and responsibilities compared to single women, 
influencing the ability to maintain regular physical activity (Makambi & Adams-Campbell, 
2018). 

179 
 
 
 
 In contrast, a prior study indicated that when single women enter into marriage, there is 
an increase in the women’s body mass index (BMI), a rise in the consumption of alcoholic 
beverages, and an elevation in systolic blood pressure (Dinour et al., 2012). Over a three-year 
period, while diastolic blood pressure exhibited a decline among both women who remained 
single and women who married, the reduction was less pronounced in the married cohort (Dinour 
et al., 2012). The same study revealed that married women who transitioned to single status due 
to divorce or separation demonstrated significant health improvements. Married women 
experienced reductions in body mass index (BMI), waist circumference, and diastolic blood 
pressure (Dinour et al., 2012). Furthermore, the participants reported enhanced adherence to 
healthy eating practices and increased levels of physical activity (Dinour et al., 2012). Notably, 
among who were non-smokers at the outset of the study, women who underwent divorce 
exhibited a higher likelihood of initiating smoking (Dinour et al., 2012).

was a low level of perceived severity to body fat percentage about resistance training. 
The participant’s displayed a high level of perceived benefits which refers to participants' 
understanding of the benefits of resistance training (Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; 

181 
 
 
 
Narmkul et al., 2024). According to Obi et al. (2023), a gap exists in qualitative studies to better 
understand African American women's perspectives on the benefits of engaging in physical 
activity, beyond what objective data reveals. To determine the level of perceived benefits in this 
study, participants were asked questions about the benefits of resistance training for African 
American women in perimenopause. Examples of questions asked were: What are the benefits of 
resistance training during perimenopause? Do you believe resistance training can help manage 
perimenopausal symptoms? The participant’s responses are displayed in Figure 13. According to 
the participants in this study, no negative responses were identified; in fact, the majority reported 
experiencing positive benefits associated with resistance training, resulting in the participants 
being highly motivated and receptive, which supports the feasibility of comparing modalities 
without concern for bias in perceived effectiveness. The participants’ responses showed there 
was a high level of perceived benefits to body fat percentage concerning resistance training. 
Next, the participants displayed a high level of perceived barriers, which is understanding 
what physical and mental obstacles prevent participants from engaging in resistance training 
(Elgzar et al., 2023; Lau et al., 2024; Narmkul et al., 2024). According to Howard and 
Bartholomew (2024), African American women face overlapping marginalization due to being 
both African American and women. Consequently, various barriers related to physical activity 
arise, including motivation, social support, access, cost, hair maintenance, and family 
responsibilities (Howard & Bartholomew, 2024; Onyegbule et al., 2021; Sillice et al., 2024). The 
identified barriers coincide with the barriers of the participants from this study, as indicated on 
Figure 14. Example questions asked of the participants were: What challenges do you face in 
engaging in resistance training? Are there psychological or social factors (e.g., stigma, body 
image, fatigue) that hinder participation? This resulted in the participants’ having a high level of 
perceived barriers to body fat percentage in relation to resistance training. 

182 
 
 
 
Lastly, self-efficacy, which increased confidence, was used to encourage participants to 
continue resistance training exercises beyond the scope of this study. Exercise self-efficacy is the 
confidence in one's ability to assess and improve physical fitness (Xue-liu & Mu, 2021). 
Developing and maintaining this self-efficacy is essential to achieving and upholding fitness 
goals effectively (Patterson et al., 2022). Enhancing self-efficacy is essential for effectively 
achieving and maintaining fitness goals. The researcher in this study had six weeks to improve 
participants' self-efficacy. Example questions asked to the participants are How confident are 
you in their ability to perform resistance exercises regularly? Will you continue resistance 
training after this study is completed? This resulted in 45% to continue to participate, which 
indicated a high level of self-efficacy regarding body fat percentage in relation to resistance 
training. The results from the HBM suggest that addressing self-efficacy is crucial for sustained 
engagement, potentially overcoming perceived barriers. 
 
Implications 
 Obesity has become a major global health issue over recent decades (Opoku et al., 2023; 
Porada et al., 2023; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Recognized as a primary factor in numerous medical 
conditions, obesity contributes to type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidaemia, arterial hypertension, 
cardiovascular diseases, osteoarthritis, depression, and various types of cancer (Opoku et al., 
2023; Porada et al., 2023; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). Obesity presents substantial challenges for 
African American populations, creating an imbalanced effect on health and well-being (Lofton et 
al., 2023). According to data from 2017-2018, the obesity rate among individuals aged 20 years 
and older was highest for African Americans, recorded at 49.6% (Lofton et al., 2023). This 
figure surpasses the rates observed in other racial demographics, such as non-Hispanic Whites, 
who had an obesity prevalence of 42.2% (Lofton et al., 2023). Furthermore, within the African 

183 
 
 
 
American community, the prevalence of obesity was notably higher among women, at 56.9%, in 
comparison to men, who recorded a rate of 41.1% (Lofton et al., 2023). This study enhanced the 
understanding of the challenges in managing and treating obesity among perimenopausal African 
American women through resistance training, which reflects various social, economic, and 
environmental factors (Lofton et al., 2023). 
African American women exhibit the highest prevalence of obesity among racial and 
ethnic groups, which increases the risk of premature mortality and morbidity (Derboghossian et 
al., 2025; Hall, 2020). Additionally, African American women have been identified as the least 
physically active demographic group in the United States (Sweeney et al., 2022). For this study, 
a total of 79 women demonstrated interest and successfully completed the intake survey, 
indicating a willingness to participate in this research initiative. In response to the survey 
question, “Have you performed any resistance or strength exercises in the past three months?”, 
48 women (60.8%) answered yes, while 31 women (39.2%) answered no as indicated in Figure 
22. This indicates that over half of the women have engaged in some form of resistance training. 
Figure 20 
Intake Survey Question "Have you performed any resistance or strength exercises in the past 
three months?" 
 


184 
 
 
 
 Out of the 79 women who completed the study, 33 had not experienced a menstrual cycle 
in the past 12 months, indicating a transition into menopause. Menopause is clinically diagnosed 
when a biological female stops menstruating for 12 months (Choudhry et al., 2024; Ko & Kim, 
2020). This challenging transitional phase typically occurs between the ages of 45 and 55, during 
which women may experience various bodily changes (Choudhry et al., 2024; Ko & Kim, 2020). 
This resulted in the researcher educating the women on the four phases of menopause; 
premenopause, perimenopause, menopause, and post-menopause. The first phase is 
premenopause, which spans from puberty to perimenopause (Pinchbeck et al., 2025). 
Perimenopause is the transitional phase that marks the beginning of changes in the menstrual 
cycle, including variations in frequency, duration, or flow, along with the onset of menopause-
related symptoms (Pinchbeck et al., 2025). During this time, estrogen levels fluctuate, resulting 
in irregular menstrual cycles and various symptoms such as hot flashes, night sweats, mood 
swings, and sleep disturbances (Percival, 2025). The changes occur as estrogen levels decline 
and can last from a few months to several years (Percival, 2025; Pinchbeck et al., 2025). 
Approximately half of women experience physical and/or emotional symptoms during the 
perimenopausal period, which can continue through menopause and up to one year afterward 
(Percival, 2025). Then women transition into menopause, which is officially defined as the point 
when a woman has not had a menstrual period for 12 consecutive months (Geraghty, 2022; 
Percival, 2025; Pinchbeck et al., 2025). Menopause signifies the permanent end of menstruation 
and fertility (Geraghty, 2022; Percival, 2025). Menopause is a normal, natural event that occurs 
due to reduced functioning of the ovaries, leading to lower levels of ovarian hormones (Percival, 
2025). The final stage of the menopausal transition is post-menopause, which refers to the period 
after menopause has occurred (Percival, 2025; Pinchbeck et al., 2025). During post-menopause, 
hormone fluctuations typically stabilize, and many of the symptoms experienced during 

185 
 
 
 
perimenopause tend to decrease (Percival, 2025). However, some women may continue to 
experience symptoms such as vaginal dryness and changes in bone density (Percival, 2025). 
 The next exclusion criterion that eliminated 43% of the women who completed the intake 
survey was the use of hormone or weight loss medication. The researcher excluded the women to 
isolate the effects of the variables, resistance training and body fat percentage, to ensure the 
accuracy and interpretability of the results. Hormones, particularly estrogen, play a significant 
role in fat distribution and metabolism in women (McCormick et al., 2020). Determining 
whether resistance training or hormone medication influences changes in body fat percentage is 
challenging due to the complexity of contributing factors (McCormick et al., 2020). Weight loss 
medications are designed to reduce body weight, often by targeting fat absorption, appetite, or 
metabolism (Mamrack, 2021; Morton et al., 2019; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). By including women 
who use hormone or weight loss medication, there would be a significant impact on body fat 
percentage, obscuring the effects of the intervention or the natural progression of the body fat 
changes (Mamrack, 2021; Morton et al., 2019; Rippe & Foreyt, 2022). 
Figure 21 
Intake Survey Question Regarding Hormone/Weight Loss Medication 
 


186 
 
 
 
Weight loss medication, a pharmacological approach to managing obesity, considers the 
unique challenges patients face in losing weight, the presence of coexisting comorbidities or 
social habits, potential drug-drug interactions, and contraindications to medication (Newberry et 
al., 2022). In 2013, the American Heart Association, the American College of Cardiology, and 
the Obesity Society jointly published a practice guideline for the management of overweight and 
obesity in adults (Newberry et al., 2022). The guideline emphasized that the initial intervention 
for patients classified as overweight or obese should involve a comprehensive lifestyle 
modification program (Newberry et al., 2022). Such a program must incorporate behavioral and 
dietary changes, along with the promotion of regular physical activity (Newberry et al., 2022). 
 Currently, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved obesity medications 
include orlistat, topiramate/phentermine, lorcaserin, bupropion/naltrexone, and liraglutide, with 
new medications and therapies in development (Byrd et al., 2018). According to Washington et 
al. (2023), fewer than 10% of individuals from African American and Hispanic communities 
who are classified as overweight or obese report utilizing weight loss medications. Research 
indicated that satisfaction levels regarding weight loss may be higher when weight-loss 
medications are employed, in comparison to lifestyle interventions that include dietary 
modifications, physical exercise, and the use of weight-loss supplements (Saxon et al., 2019). 
Conte et al. (2024) found that the introduction of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and other 
obesity medications has ushered in a new era in the pharmacological treatment of obesity. GLP-1 
has been associated with an average weight loss of 15% to 25% over a period of 1 to 1.5 years 
(Saxon et al., 2019). Furthermore, the administration of weight-loss medications is associated 
with a more substantial reduction in body weight (Saxon et al., 2019). 
 Intentional weight loss in individuals classified as obese mainly leads to a reduction in 
body fat, as well as a decrease in fat-free mass (FFM) (Conte et al., 2024). However, recent 

187 
 
 
 
concerns suggesting that significant weight loss induced by GLP-1-based and other obesity 
medications may cause physical frailty or sarcopenia are not supported by data (Conte et al., 
2024; Melson et al., 2024). Researchers have highlighted the importance of understanding the 
impact of reduced circulating amino acids, influenced by novel multi-agonists targeting the 
glucagon receptor, on lean muscle mass in the coming years (Melson et al., 2024). The 
importance of lean muscle mass is particularly important for populations with obesity who are at 
a high risk of sarcopenia, as well as for energy expenditure (Melson et al., 2024). Due to the 
limited data available on weight loss medication and the effect on muscle mass, women who 
have used weight loss medication were excluded from the current study. 
 Over 24% of the women who completed the intake survey were excluded as a result of 
taking medication with hormones, birth control, and hormone replacement therapy. Menopause 
hormone therapy (MHT) has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) 
for the treatment of women experiencing vasomotor symptoms (VMS), genitourinary syndrome 
related to menopause, and sexual dysfunction (Christmas et al., 2022; Conklin et al., 2024). 
Furthermore, MHT serves to prevent bone loss and subsequent fractures (Conklin et al., 2024). 
Research indicates that MHT can reduce the risk of colon cancer, cataracts, and sleep 
disturbances associated with night sweats. Additionally, when combined with a regular exercise 
regimen, MHT has been shown to decelerate muscle loss and yield favorable effects on mood 
(Conklin et al., 2024). According to Sipilä et al. (2020), hormone replacement therapy resulted in 
a 3% net increase in total body lean mass and a 5% increase in the cross-sectional area of thigh 
muscles after a duration of one year. The findings indicated that muscle tissue may be 
particularly sensitive to hormonal changes associated with menopause in middle-aged women 
(Sipilä et al., 2020). This observation highlighted the significance of understanding the impact of 
the hormonal fluctuations on muscle health during this critical life stage (Sipilä et al., 2020). The 

188 
 
 
 
impact of hormone replacement therapy on muscle mass and strength in perimenopausal and 
postmenopausal women is a topic that sparked lively debate among experts (Conklin et al., 2024; 
Mitoma et al., 2023; Sipilä et al., 2020). Some emphasized the benefits, while others questioned 
the effectiveness, making hormone replacement therapy a captivating area of exploration 
(Conklin et al., 2024; Mitoma et al., 2023; Sipilä et al., 2020). Due the hormone replacement 
therapy effects, women who take hormone replacement therapy were excluded. 
 Birth control is often prescribed to women during perimenopause to prevent unintended 
pregnancies (Grandi et al., 2022). The additional benefits of birth control are menstrual cycle 
regulation, reduction of hot flashes, and protection against bone loss (Grandi et al., 2022). 
However, birth control influences body fat distribution and water retention, which could add a 
confounding variable (Grandi et al., 2022). Significant disparities exist in reproductive health 
outcomes for African American women in the United States when compared to other racial and 
ethnic groups (Thompson et al., 2022). Among women aged 15 to 44, African American women 
exhibited higher rates of unintended pregnancies and abortions and are substantially more likely 
to contract sexually transmitted infections than Caucasian women (T. M. Thompson et al., 2022). 
Furthermore, African American women experience elevated rates of obesity, hypertension, 
diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases, conditions that increase the risk for complications during 
pregnancy (Thompson et al., 2022). 
Research on the effects of birth control on body composition before and after resistance 
training is limited, showing inconsistent results (A. Cavalcante et al., 2025). The impact of 
hormonal contraceptives on body composition after resistance training remains unclear (A. 
Cavalcante et al., 2025). Mercer et al. (2020) found that research primarily conducted on male 
athletes is often applied to female athletes based on the assumption that resting, post-exercise, 
and post-prandial muscle protein synthesis responses are similar. However, Mercer et al. (2020) 

189 
 
 
 
overlooked the impact of differences in sex steroid hormones on exercise metabolism. Research 
indicated that variations in hormone levels throughout different phases of the menstrual cycle, as 
well as the use of hormonal contraceptives, may have small but variable effects on exercise 
performance (Mercer et al., 2020). As a result, women who utilize birth control were excluded 
from consideration. 
Limitations 
This study provided evidence that resistance training does impact body fat percentage in 
perimenopausal African American women. Although results were deemed not statistically 
significant, a combined total of 3.6% body fat and 21.3 pounds of body fat mass were lost among 
the participants, as indicated in Table 27. Two types of resistance training were used in this 
study: exercises that used weights from free weights, machines, and cable pulleys, and exercises 
that used body weight. Figure 9 indicated that the group that performed resistance training using 
body weight lost more body fat compared to the group that used weights.

190 
 
 
 
 The primary goal of 106 participants was not met. Seventy-nine women initially showed 
interest in the research study by completing the survey. Of the 79 women, only 23 women met 
all the criteria. Of the 23 women who met the criteria, 12 women failed to respond to follow-up 
communication from the researcher to schedule the next steps of scheduling an InBody scan or to 
be assigned to a workout group, leaving 11 women to participate. Of the 11 women who did 
commit, three participants dropped out, leaving a total of eight women to participate, which 
contributed to the not statistically significant findings. 
 Another limitation of this study is the exclusion of nutrition as a variable. According to 
Geraghty (2022), identifying the optimal diet for weight loss posed significant challenges due to 
the diverse pathophysiological factors that contribute to individual obesity, including variations 
in basal metabolic rates and differing homeostatic and hedonic drivers of food intake. 
Traditionally, the calories in versus calories out model has been widely endorsed; however, there 
is a growing emphasis on the significance of both the quantity and quality of caloric intake 
(Geraghty, 2022). To lose weight, a caloric deficit diet is important to maintain (Geraghty, 
2022). Experts recommended following a hypocaloric diet, which typically consists of 1,200 to 
1,500 calories per day for women and 1,500 to 1,800 calories per day for men. The approach of a 
hypocaloric diet aims to create a daily deficit of 500 to 750 calories (Geraghty, 2022). 
Threats to internal validity can hinder or diminish a study's comparability or applicability 
(Creswell & Poth, 2018). Terms such as credibility, authenticity, transferability, dependability, 
and confirmability represent the naturalist’s equivalents for internal validation, external 
validation, reliability, and objectivity which are essential for ensuring the rigor and 
trustworthiness of research. Internal validity is defined as the degree to which a researcher can 
confidently assert that the independent variable has a causal effect on the dependent variable 

191 
 
 
 
(Crano et al., 2023; Joyner et al., 2018). There were three threats to internal validity: history, 
maturation, and attrition. 
Differences in outcomes may be attributed to events that occurred independently of the 
experimental treatment during the interval between the independent and dependent variables 
(Crano et al., 2023; Creswell & Poth, 2018). Events that occurred independently of the 
experimental treatment are recognized as the history threat to internal validity (Crano et al., 
2023; Creswell & Poth, 2018). Internal validity was seen in participant C2, who gained body fat 
within the study, and participant R2, who lost the least amount of body fat. This study took place 
at the end of the year, during the Christmas and New Year holiday season. As a result, 
participants C2 and R2 experienced approximately a two-week break between the final workout 
session and the post-body fat scan. The break may have contributed to an increase in body fat for 
C2 and the .1% body fat decrease with participant R2. Next, maturation pertains to changes in 
outcomes that arise from shifts in the internal or physical characteristics of the participants, such 
as aging, increased fatigue, or a decline in interest (Crano et al., 2023; Creswell & Poth, 2018). 
Participant R8 achieved a notable reduction in body fat, but was observed decreasing the weight 
used during the workout. Interactions with other participants demonstrated the presence of social 
support from participant R8 (Derboghossian et al., 2025; Patterson et al., 2022). Social 
relationships significantly influence health behaviors through interpersonal exchanges within a 
network (Derboghossian et al., 2025; Patterson et al., 2022). Comparisons made within social 
circles provided valuable guidance (Derboghossian et al., 2025; Patterson et al., 2022). 
Interpersonal exchanges promoted healthful habits, including consistent exercise and balanced 
nutrition (Derboghossian et al., 2025). Lastly, attrition was the final threat to internal validity that 
was identified. Attrition refers to losing participants during a study (Crano et al., 2023). Threat to 

192 
 
 
 
internal validity was demonstrated with three participants from the resistance training with 
bodyweight group. 
External validity refers to how well the findings of a study can be accurately applied to 
other situations, populations, or settings beyond the specific context in which the research was 
conducted (Findley et al., 2021; Joyner et al., 2018). Threats to external validation are factors 
that hinder a study’s comparability or translatability (Creswell & Poth, 2018; Findley et al., 
2021). There were two threats to external validity: the novelty effect and population validity 
which both contributed to limited generalizability. The novelty effect described a temporary 
improvement in performance or behavior resulting from the introduction of something new 
(Joyner et al., 2018). The effect is not necessarily due to the inherent value or effectiveness of the 
new element but rather the excitement, interest, or attention that is generated (Joyner et al., 
2018). The novelty effect occurrence was observed in participants R1, C1, and C5, as the study 
marked the initial experience of performing resistance training. Except for participant C8, 
participants R1, C1, and C5 reduced the most body fat percentage compared to all the 
participants. The excitement surrounding the introduction of new exercises contributed to the 
novelty effect. The improvements observed may have been driven more by the enthusiasm for 
the new exercise regimen than by its long-term effectiveness. This suggests that the positive 
outcomes may not be replicable in individuals who are already familiar with resistance training, 
which limits the generalizability of these findings for that population. 
Population validity refers to the extent to which study findings can be generalized to 
individuals beyond the sample group, ideally achieved through a diverse and representative 
participant pool (Crano et al., 2023; Findley et al., 2021). In this study, several recruitment 
challenges were identified, including limited time to solicit participants, scheduling conflicts, and 
missing contact information, resulted in a small, homogenous sample. These constraints 

193 
 
 
 
restricted participant diversity in terms of demographics, fitness experience, and availability, 
thereby limiting the applicability of the findings to broader populations. A more inclusive sample 
would have strengthened population validity and enhanced confidence in generalizing the results. 
The lack of diversity directly undermines the external validity of the study and contributes to its 
limited generalizability. 
Recommendations for Future Research 
Research indicated that obesity rates are significantly higher among African American 
women, with a trend evident as early as school age (Chinn et al., 2021; Hall, 2020; Lofton et al., 
2023). Health disparities persist among African American women compared to Caucasian 
women (M. Williams et al., 2022). Health disparities differences are reflected in various health 
areas, including maternal health, cardiovascular disease, mental health conditions such as 
depression, and mortality rates linked to diabetes, breast cancer, and gynecologic cancers (M. 
Williams et al., 2022). The research finding underscores need for targeted health initiatives and 
interventions to address obesity within the African American women's demographic. Conducting 
research focused on African American women is recommended, incorporating culturally tailored 
lifestyle interventions such as nutrition education, physical activity promotion, and or behavioral 
self-management, which play a crucial role in addressing obesity within African American 
women. 
This study found no statistically significant relationship between the religion of obese 
perimenopausal African American women in San Antonio and body fat percentage while 
engaging in resistance training. However, previous research has indicated that church 
involvement is associated with improved dietary quality and higher levels of physical activity 
among parishioners (Brewer et al., 2021). Therefore, a recommendation to conduct research on 

194 
 
 
 
community-based and faith-based approaches such as church-based programs, community health 
workers peer educators, family involvement, and or community partnership should be executed. 
Obesity poses significant challenges across the United States, with a particularly severe 
impact in African American communities (Chinn et al., 2021; Coritz et al., 2023; Shockley & 
Norman Burrell, 2024). The situation is especially concerning for African American women, 
who experience the highest obesity rates among racial and ethnic groups (Chinn et al., 2021; 
Coritz et al., 2023; Shockley & Norman Burrell, 2024). Addressing the underlying causes and 
recognizing the intricate connections among social, cultural, and environmental factors allows 
public health initiatives to be strategically designed to reduce this critical health disparity 
(Shockley & Norman Burrell, 2024). Future research should investigate structural inequalities by 
recognizing and addressing the impact of systemic racism, socioeconomic disparities, and 
limited access to resources on obesity rates.
